Section Title: IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT THIS OFFERING MEMORANDUM
Subsubsection Text: This Offering Memorandum is a confidential document that we are providing only to prospective purchasers of the Notes. You should read this Offering Memorandum before making a decision whether to purchase any Notes. You must not: - use this Offering Memorandum for any other purpose; - make copies of any part of this Offering Memorandum or give a copy of it to any other person; or - disclose any information in this Offering Memorandum to any other person, other than a person retained to advise you in connection with the purchase of the Notes. We have prepared this Offering Memorandum based on information we have or have obtained from sources we believe to be reliable. Summaries of documents contained in this Offering Memorandum may not be complete. We and the Initial Purchasers have not authorized anyone to provide you with information that is different from the information contained herein. You must not rely on unauthorized information or representations. You should not assume that the information contained in this Offering Memorandum is accurate as of any date other than the date on the front cover of this Offering Memorandum. Neither the delivery of this Offering Memorandum at any time after the date of publication nor any subsequent commitment to purchase the Notes shall, under any circumstances, create an implication that there has been no change in the information set forth in this Offering Memorandum or in our business since the date of this Offering Memorandum. References to any website contained herein do not form part of this Offering Memorandum. In making an investment decision, you must rely on your own examination of the Issuer, Topco and its subsidiaries and the terms of this Offering, including the merits and risks. We will make copies of actual documents available to you upon request. Neither we nor the Initial Purchasers nor the Trustee, Registrar, Paying Agent, Security Agent or Transfer Agent are providing you with any legal, investment, business, tax or other advice in this Offering Memorandum. You should consult with your own counsel, accountants and other advisors as needed to assist you in making your investment decision and to advise you whether you are legally permitted to purchase the Notes. By receiving this Offering Memorandum, you acknowledge that (1) you have been afforded an opportunity to request from us, and to review, and that you have received all additional information considered by you to be necessary to verify the accuracy of, or to supplement, the information contained herein, (2) you have not relied on the Initial Purchasers or any person affiliated with the Initial Purchasers in connection with any investigation of the accuracy of such information or your investment decision and (3) we have not authorized any person to deliver any information different from that contained in this Offering Memorandum. This Offering Memorandum does not constitute an offer or solicitation by anyone in any jurisdiction in which such offer or solicitation is not authorized or to any person to whom it is unlawful to make such offer or solicitation. No action has been, or will be, taken to permit a public offering in any jurisdiction where action would be required for that purpose. Accordingly, the Notes may not be offered or sold, directly or indirectly, and this Offering Memorandum may not be distributed, in any jurisdiction except in accordance with the legal requirements applicable in such jurisdiction. You must comply with all laws applicable in any jurisdiction in which you buy, offer or sell the Notes or possess or distribute this Offering Memorandum, and you must obtain all applicable consents and approvals; neither we nor the Initial Purchasers shall have any responsibility for any of the foregoing legal requirements. We are offering the Notes, and the Guarantors are issuing the Guarantees, in reliance on (i) an exemption from registration under the U.S. Securities Act for an offer and sale of securities that does not involve a public offering and (ii) a transaction pursuant to Regulation S that is not subject to the registration requirements of the U.S. Securities Act. If you purchase the Notes, you will be deemed to have made certain acknowledgments, representations and warranties as detailed under “Transfer Restrictions”. The Notes are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale and may not be transferred or resold except as permitted under the U.S. Securities Act and applicable securities laws of any other jurisdiction pursuant to registration or exemption therefrom; see “Transfer Restrictions”. You may be required to bear the financial risk of an investment in the Notes for an indefinite period. Neither we nor the Initial Purchasers are making an offer to sell the Notes in any jurisdiction where the offer and sale of the Notes is prohibited. Neither we nor the Initial Purchasers are making any representation to you that the Notes are a legal investment for you. iii ----- Each prospective purchaser of the Notes must comply with all applicable laws and rules and regulations in force in any jurisdiction in which it purchases, offers or sells the Notes and must obtain any consent, approval or permission required by it for the purchase, offer or sale by it of the Notes under the laws and regulations in force in any jurisdiction to which it is subject or in which it makes such purchases, offers or sales, and neither we nor the Initial Purchasers shall have any responsibility therefor. Neither the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (the “SEC”), any U.S. state securities commission nor any non-U.S. securities authority nor other authority has approved or disapproved of the Notes or determined if this Offering Memorandum is truthful or complete. Any representation to the contrary is a criminal offense. We accept responsibility for the information contained in this Offering Memorandum. Nothing contained in this Offering Memorandum is, or shall be relied upon as, a promise or representation by the Initial Purchasers as to the past, the present or the future. We and the Initial Purchasers may reject any offer to purchase the Notes in whole or in part for any reason or no reason, sell less than the entire principal amount of the Notes offered hereby or allocate to any purchaser less than all of the Notes for which it has subscribed. Subsection Title: PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL AND OTHER DATA Financial Data
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer is a public limited company incorporated on October 30, 2017 for the purpose of consummating the 2017 Acquisition (as defined below) and the related financing thereof. The Issuer conducts no business operations of its own and as of the Issue Date its only material assets will be its holding of the entire issued share capital of Gym Topco Limited (“Topco”) and its consolidated subsidiaries (collectively, the “Topco Group”), including Fitness World (as defined below) (the Issuer, together with its consolidated subsidiaries and together with Fitness World collectively, the “Combined Group”), as well as rights and claims under intercompany financings. The Issuer’s only material liabilities will be its outstanding indebtedness under the Existing Notes, the Notes and certain subordinated shareholder debt. For further information, please see “Summary—Corporate and Financing Structure”, “Business” and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements”. The Issuer acquired Topco on November 30, 2017 (the “2017 Acquisition Date”) and the 2018 Pure Gym 14-Month Financial Statements (as defined below) encompass the 14-month period of trading from the 2017 Acquisition Date to December 31, 2018. As a result, the 2018 Pure Gym 14-Month Financial Statements are not directly comparable to the 2017 Topco Financial Statements or the 2019 Pure Gym Financial Statements (each as defined below), both of which were prepared on a 12-month basis. As a result, for the year ended December 31, 2018, this Offering Memorandum provides the 2018 Topco Financial Statements (as defined below) for comparative purposes rather than the 2018 Pure Gym 14-Month Financial Statements. The 2018 Pure Gym 14-Month Financial Statements have been included in the F-pages to this Offering Memorandum for reference purposes only. The financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum includes: - the audited consolidated financial statements of the Topco Group as of and for the year ended December 31, 2017, which have been audited by PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP and prepared in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union (“IFRS”), including the related notes thereto (the “2017 Topco Financial Statements”); - the audited consolidated financial statements of the Topco Group as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018, which have been audited by PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP (with unaudited comparative financial information as at and for the year ended December 31, 2017) and prepared in accordance with IFRS, including the related notes thereto (the “2018 Topco Financial Statements”); - the audited consolidated financial statements of the Issuer and its consolidated subsidiaries as of and for the 14-month period from the 2017 Acquisition Date to December 31, 2018 which have been audited by PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP and prepared in accordance with IFRS, including the related notes thereto (the “2018 Pure Gym 14-Month Financial Statements”); - the audited consolidated financial statements of the Issuer and its consolidated subsidiaries as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019, which have been audited by PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP and prepared in accordance with IFRS, including the related notes thereto (the “2019 Pure Gym Financial

Subsubsection Text: Forward TopCo A/S, a public limited liability company (Aktieselskab) incorporated under the laws of Denmark, was established on March 30, 2015. Forward TopCo A/S and its consolidated subsidiaries (collectively, “Fitness World”) operate in the fitness industry in Denmark, Switzerland and Poland. As of the Issue Date, its material assets are equipment, leasehold improvements and deposits and its material liabilities are leasing obligations, lease ix ----- liabilities and credit obligations. For further information, please see “Summary—Corporate and Financing Structure”, “Business” and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements”. The financial information presented with respect to Fitness World in this Offering Memorandum includes: - the audited consolidated financial statements of Fitness World as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019, which have been audited by EY Godkendt Revisionspartnerselskab (with comparative figures as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018) and prepared in accordance with IFRS as adopted by the European Union, including the related notes thereto (the “2019 **Fitness World Financial

Section Title: THIS OFFERING MEMORANDUM CONTAINS IMPORTANT INFORMATION WHICH YOU SHOULD READ BEFORE YOU MAKE ANY DECISION WITH RESPECT TO AN INVESTMENT IN THE NOTES.
Subsection Title: Statements” and, together with the 2017 Topco Financial Statements and the 2018 Topco Financial
Subsubsection Text: Statements, the “Pure Gym Financial Statements”); and - the unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements of the Issuer and its consolidated subsidiaries as of and for the six months ended June 30, 2020 (including Fitness World from the Acquisition Date) (prepared in accordance with IAS 34 Interim Financial Reporting as adopted by the European Union) with comparable information as of and for the six months ended June 30, 2019 and the notes thereto (the “Unaudited Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements”). In this Offering Memorandum, we present financial and other operating data as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019. In addition to its usefulness as regards our historical performance, this data represents the ordinary course operations of our business before the Acquisition and before the impact of COVID-19. We have also presented viii ----- financial and other operating data as of and for the six months ended June 30, 2020, which include the results of the Fitness World Group from January 14, 2020 and which represent the impact on our business of the Acquisition and COVID-19. The preparation of financial statements in conformity with IFRS requires the use of certain critical accounting estimates. It also requires management to exercise its judgment in the process of applying our accounting policies. The areas involving a higher degree of judgment or complexity, or areas where assumptions and estimates are significant to the financial statements, are disclosed in the Pure Gym Financial Statements. With respect to the 2019 Pure Gym Financial Statements, Pure Gym applied the new IFRS 16 (Leases) accounting standard, effective from January 1, 2019 using the modified retrospective method, for transition and measuring right of use assets using the retrospective calculation, both as defined by the IFRS 16 accounting standard. Cumulative effects of applying this new accounting standard were therefore recognized as an adjustment to retained earnings as of January 1, 2019 (the date of initial application), while comparative figures were not restated. The 2017 Topco Financial Statements and the 2018 Topco Financial Statements have not been restated for the adoption of IFRS 16. IFRS 16 eliminates the classification of leases as either operating leases or finance leases and introduces a single lessee accounting model with some exemptions for short-term and low-value leases. The lessee recognizes a right-ofuse asset representing its right to use the underlying asset and a lease liability representing its obligation to make lease payments. The effect of applying IFRS 16 is to align the presentation of leases more closely to that of owned assets, rent expense is no longer deducted in arriving at operating profit or Pure Gym EBITDA and instead profit before tax includes an interest charge on the unwinding of the lease liability and a depreciation charge on the right of use asset. See Note 27 “Change in Accounting Policies” of the 2019 Pure Gym Financial Statements. The financial information included in this Offering Memorandum is not intended to comply with the applicable accounting requirements of the U.S. Securities Act and the related rules and regulations of the SEC, which would apply if the Notes were being registered with the SEC. There could be significant differences between IFRS and generally accepted accounting principles in the United States of America (“U.S. GAAP”), as applied to Pure Gym. We neither describe the differences between IFRS and U.S. GAAP nor reconcile Pure Gym’s IFRS financial statements to U.S. GAAP. Accordingly, such information is not available to investors, and investors should consider this in making their investment decision. The Indenture will impose no obligation on us to reconcile our future financial statements prepared under IFRS to U.S. GAAP. See “Independent Auditors” for a description of the independent auditors’ reports of PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP. In accordance with guidance issued by The Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales, the independent auditor’s reports from PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP state that the reports including the opinions were prepared for and only for Pure Gym’s members as a body in accordance with Chapter 3 of Part 16 of the Companies Act of 2006 and for no other purpose; the independent auditors did not, in giving these opinions, accept or assume responsibility for any other purpose or to any other person to whom this report is shown or into whose hands it may come save where expressly agreed by their prior consent in writing. Investors in the Notes should understand that in making these statements, the independent auditor has confirmed that it does not accept or assume any liability to parties (such as the purchasers of the Notes) other than to Pure Gym and its members as a body, with respect to the report and to the independent auditor’s audit work and opinions. The SEC would not permit such limiting language to be included in a registration statement or a prospectus used in connection with an offering of securities registered under the U.S. Securities Act or in a report filed under the U.S. Exchange Act. If a U.S. court (or any other court) were to give effect to such limiting language, the recourse that investors in the Notes may have against the independent auditor based on its report or the consolidated financial statements to which it relates could be limited. See “Risk Factors—Risks relating to the Notes, the Guarantees and _the Collateral—Investors in the Notes may have limited or no recourse against the independent auditors”._

Subsubsection Text: The 2019 Fitness World Financial Statements and the 2017 Fitness World Financial Statements have been included in the F-pages to this Offering Memorandum. This Offering Memorandum provides selected historical financial information from the 2017 Fitness World Financial Statements (as defined below) for comparative purposes and in order to demonstrate growth trends for key Fitness World metrics. Comparative figures for 2018 are provided due to the final valuation of acquired identifiable net assets being completed in 2019 for the acquisitions made in 2018, leading to adjustments to previously reported fair values for Basefit. Consequently, the adjusted comparative figures as presented in the 2019 Fitness World Financial Statements have been provided in lieu of Fitness World’s 2018 audited financials. Please see Note 28 “Business Combinations” to the 2019 Fitness World Financial Statements. The preparation of financial statements in conformity with IFRS requires the use of certain critical accounting estimates. It also requires management to exercise its judgment in the process of applying our accounting policies. The areas involving a higher degree of judgment or complexity, or areas where assumptions and estimates are significant to the financial statements, are disclosed in the 2019 Fitness World Financial Statements. With respect to the 2019 Fitness World Financial Statements, Fitness World applied the new IFRS 16 (Leases) accounting standard, effective from January 1, 2019 using the modified retrospective method. Cumulative effects of applying this new accounting standard were therefore recognized as an adjustment to retained earnings as of January 1, 2019 (the date of initial application), while comparative figures were not restated. IFRS 16 eliminates the classification of leases as either operating leases or finance leases and introduces a single lessee accounting model with some exemptions for short-term and low-value leases. The lessee recognizes a right-of-use asset representing its right to use the underlying asset and a lease liability representing its obligation to make lease payments. The effect of applying IFRS 16 was to align the presentation of leases more closely to that of owned assets, rent expense is no longer deducted in arriving at operating profit or Fitness World EBITDA and instead profit before tax includes an interest charge on the unwinding of the lease liability and a depreciation charge on the right of use asset. See Note 29 “Changes in accounting policies and disclosures” of the 2019 Fitness World Financial Statements. The financial information included in this Offering Memorandum is not intended to comply with the applicable accounting requirements of the U.S. Securities Act and the related rules and regulations of the SEC, which would apply if the Notes were being registered with the SEC. There could be significant differences between IFRS and U.S. GAAP, as applied to Fitness World. We neither describe the differences between IFRS and U.S. GAAP nor reconcile Fitness World’s IFRS financial statements to U.S. GAAP. Accordingly, such information is not available to investors, and investors should consider this in making their investment decision. The Indenture will impose no obligation on us to reconcile our future financial statements prepared under IFRS to U.S. GAAP. See “Independent Auditors” for a description of the independent auditors’ reports of EY Godkendt Revisionspartnerselskab. x -----

Section Title: THIS OFFERING MEMORANDUM CONTAINS IMPORTANT INFORMATION WHICH YOU SHOULD READ BEFORE YOU MAKE ANY DECISION WITH RESPECT TO AN INVESTMENT IN THE NOTES.
Subsubsection Text: This Offering Memorandum contains certain non-IFRS measures and ratios, including Combined Group Adjusted EBITDA, Combined Group Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA, Combined Group Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA and certain other measures (the “Non-IFRS Measures”) that are not required by, or presented in accordance with, IFRS or the accounting standards of any other jurisdiction. We define the following Non-IFRS Measures as follows: - “Adjusted EBITDA” as the profit or loss for a certain period before income tax expense, net finance cost, depreciation of property, plant and equipment and right of use assets, amortization of intangible fixed assets, impairment of property, plant and equipment, profit/loss on disposal of property, plant and equipment, profit/loss on lease modifications, exceptional administrative expenses, and other extraordinary items, after adding back Pre-Opening Costs, share based payment charges and the Cash Rent Adjustment. - **“Adjusted EBITDA margin” as Adjusted EBITDA for that period divided by revenue for that period. - “As adjusted Net Debt” represents total senior secured indebtedness of the Combined Group less cash and cash equivalents, after giving pro forma effect to the Transactions, the application of the proceeds therefrom and the Equity Injection as if the Transactions and the Equity Injection had occurred on December 31, 2019. - “As adjusted Net Interest Expense” represents the net of interest payable/receivable for the 12 months ended December 31, 2019 after giving pro forma effect to the Transactions and the application of the proceeds therefrom as if the Transactions occurred on January 1, 2019. - “Average Continuous Membership Tenure” as the average monthly tenure of all active and paying members, including members who have frozen their membership, as of a given point in time. This includes previous memberships where the gap in membership was 30 days or less, but excludes the period(s) of non-membership. - “Average Gym ROCE” as Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA for the relevant portfolio of gyms for that period divided by the Initial Capital Investment attributable to that portfolio of gyms. - “Average Initial Capital Investment for Mature Gyms” as the Initial Capital Investment for all Mature Gyms for a certain period divided by the number of Mature Gyms in that period. - “Average Mature Gym Adjusted EBITDA” as Mature Gym Adjusted EBITDA for a certain period divided by the number of Mature Gyms in that period. - “Average Mature Gym Adjusted EBITDA Margin” as Mature Gym Adjusted EBITDA for a certain period divided by the revenue attributable to Mature Gyms for that period. - “Average Mature Gym ROCE” as Mature Gym Adjusted EBITDA for a certain portfolio of gyms for a certain period divided by the Initial Capital Investment attributable to that portfolio of gyms. - “Average Revenue per Member per Month” as revenue for that period divided by the number of months in that period and further divided by the average number of members during that period. The average number of members during that period is calculated as the average of the number of members as of the beginning of the first month and the end of every month in that period. - “Cash Rent Adjustment” from January 1, 2019, as the deduction of the cash rent payable during the period which otherwise was not reflected in EBITDA (as reported on a post-IFRS 16 basis). Pre January 1, 2019, under IAS17, the total rent payable over the life of the lease is spread over the lease term and charged to the income statement on a straight line basis in arriving at EBITDA. As we typically receive a rent free period of a year or more as an incentive from developers or landlords to lease space in their buildings this results in rent charged to EBITDA being greater than the cash outlay in the early years of the lease term and less than the cash outlay in the later years of the lease term. The Cash Rent Adjustment xi ----- adds back any non-cash element of the rent expensed in the period during these early years (less any amounts already added back as a Pre-Opening Cost) and deducts any shortfall in rent expense in the later years to reflect the actual cash outlay due for that period under our lease arrangements. Management believes that adjusting EBITDA to reflect cash rent is a better reflection of our actual earnings. - “Combined Group Adjusted EBITDA” as Adjusted EBITDA of Pure Gym plus Adjusted EBITDA of Fitness World. - _“Combined Group Adjusted EBITDA Margin” as Combined Group Adjusted EBITDA for a certain period divided by the Combined Group Revenue. - “Combined Group EBITDA” as EBITDA of Pure Gym plus EBITDA of Fitness World. - “Combined Group Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA” Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA of Pure Gym plus Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA of Fitness World. - “Combined Group Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA margin” Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA of Pure Gym plus Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA of Fitness World for a certain period, divided by the Combined Group Revenue. - **“Combined Group Operating Cash Flow” as Operating Cash Flow of Pure Gym plus Operating Cash Flow of Fitness World. - “Combined Group Revenue” as revenue of Pure Gym plus revenue of Fitness World. - “Combined Group Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA” as Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of Pure Gym plus Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of Fitness World. - “EBITDA” as the profit or loss for a certain period before income tax expense, net finance cost, depreciation of property, plant and equipment and right of use assets, amortization of intangible fixed assets, impairment of property, plant and equipment, profit/loss on disposal of property, plant and equipment, profit/loss on lease modifications and exceptional administrative expenses. - “Expansionary Capital Expenditure” as the Initial Capital Investment and the capital costs of expanding gym sites incurred in that period. - “Gym cohorts” as groups of Pure Gym or Fitness World clubs, as applicable, that opened during a specified period. - **“Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA” as Adjusted EBITDA for that period, excluding Head Office Costs. - **“Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA margin” as Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA divided by revenue for that period. - “Head Office Costs” as all non-gym specific costs, other than depreciation and amortization, related to the operation of head office functions in a given period. - “Initial Capital Investment” refers to the capital cost of bringing a new gym into operation or extending a gym, including expenditures on site fit out, fixtures, fittings and equipment and excluding the cost of any right of use property assets, ongoing maintenance and refurbishment capex. - “Maintenance and Refurbishment Capital Expenditures” as the total capital expenditure incurred in a period less Expansionary Capital Expenditure incurred in that period. - “Mature Gym Adjusted EBITDA” as profit for a certain period before income tax expense, net finance cost, depreciation of property, plant and equipment and right of use assets, amortization of intangible xii ----- fixed assets, impairment of property, plant and equipment, profit/loss on disposal of property, plant and equipment, profit/loss on lease modifications and exceptional administrative expenses for mature sites, after adding back the Cash Rent Adjustment and Pre-Opening Costs for mature sites and after adding back Head Office Costs. - “Mature Gym EBITDA” as profit for a certain period before income tax expense, net finance cost, depreciation of property, plant and equipment and right of use assets, amortization of intangible fixed assets, impairment of property, plant and equipment, profit/loss on disposal of property, plant and equipment, profit/loss on lease modifications, exceptional administrative expenses and Head Office Costs for Mature Gyms. Mature Gym EBITDA does not include the Cash Rent Adjustment or adjustments for Pre-Opening Costs or other extraordinary items that were added back to Adjusted EBITDA and Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA. - “Mature Gyms” as the gyms that have been open for 24 months or more as of the end of the relevant reporting period. - “New Gyms” as the gyms that have been open for less than 24 months as of the end of the relevant reporting period. - **“Operating Cash Flow” as Adjusted EBITDA plus Working Capital Cash Flow and less Maintenance and Refurbishment Capital Expenditures for that period. - **“Operating Cash Flow Conversion” as the Operating Cash Flow for that period divided by Adjusted EBITDA for that period. - “Pre-Opening Costs” as the total of all gym site operating costs incurred during the pre-opening periods of gyms in that period. Pre-Opening Costs primarily consist of staff, marketing and also rent expenses when reporting under IAS17. - “ROCE” as Adjusted EBITDA divided by Initial Capital Investment and refers to return on capital employed. - **“Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA” as the Adjusted EBITDA including any Run-Rate Adjustment. - “Run-Rate Adjustment” as the adjustment made to those gyms which are less than three years old at the end of the reporting period. These adjustments replace the Adjusted EBITDA earned by these sites in the last twelve month period with the projected Adjusted EBITDA for their third year of operation. - “Working Capital Cash Flow” as cash movements in working capital less the Cash Rent Adjustment, where this is applicable under IAS17. We present a reconciliation of the Non-IFRS Measures to the most directly comparable measure calculated and presented in accordance with IFRS and discuss its limitations. For a reconciliation of these Non-IFRS Measures and such discussions, refer to “Summary Consolidated Financial and Other Information—Other financial, operational _and pro forma data”._ We believe that the presentation of the Non-IFRS Measures enhances an investor’s understanding of our operating performance and our ability to service our debt. In addition, we believe that EBITDA is a measure commonly used by investors. Our Non-IFRS Measures may not be comparable with similarly titled measures used by other companies. Our EBITDA and related leverage and coverage ratios are not measurements of financial performance under IFRS and should not be considered as alternatives to other indicators of our operating performance, cash flows or any other measure of performance derived in accordance with IFRS. Our Non-IFRS Measures have important limitations as analytical tools, and you should not consider them in isolation or as substitutes for analysis of our results of operations as reported under IFRS. In addition, EBITDA may be defined differently from the definition of “RunRate Adjusted EBITDA” under the Indenture. Some limitations of EBITDA-based measures include: xiii ----- - they do not reflect the interest expense or cash requirements necessary to service interest or principal payments on our debt; - they do not reflect any cash income and certain other taxes that we may be required to pay; - they are not adjusted for all cash income or expense items that are reflected in our statements of cash flows; and - they do not reflect the impact of earnings or charges resulting from certain matters we consider not to be indicative of our ongoing operations. Because of these limitations, our Non-IFRS Measures should not be considered as measures of discretionary cash available to us to invest in the growth of our business or as measures of cash that will be available to us to meet our obligations. You should compensate for these limitations by relying primarily on our IFRS results and using these Non-IFRS Measures only in a supplemental manner to evaluate our performance. Key performance indicators and the other non-financial operational data included in this Offering Memorandum are not part of our financial statements and have not been audited. Our use or computation of these indicators may not be comparable with the use or computation of similarly titled measures reported by other companies. None of the key performance indicators or other non-financial operating data included in this Offering Memorandum should be considered in isolation or as an alternative to any indicator of our operating performance, cash flows or other measure of performance derived in accordance with IFRS.

Section Title: MARKET AND INDUSTRY DATA
Subsection Title: UK Low Cost Gyms Report”). The report provides a detailed analysis of the UK health and fitness
Subsubsection Text: sector with an assessment of the market headroom for low cost gyms in the UK This source provides statistics on the market share of low cost gyms over time and research on how people approach their own fitness and wellness, giving insight into new market opportunities. - EuropeActive, a knowledge centre for the European health and fitness sector, collaborates with Deloitte to publish the European Health & Fitness Market Report (the “Deloitte/EuropeActive Report”). The report summarizes the latest marketing developments for the previous year, including rankings of the major European fitness club operators, views on market trends and analyses of major national fitness markets in Europe. Where we make reference to the Deloitte/EuropeActive Report, we refer to the 2020 Deloitte European Health & Fitness Market Report. This source provides statistics on market growth and membership as well as major drivers behind trends in the European health and fitness market. - A third party was commissioned by Fitness World to produce a commercial due diligence report (the “Fitness World Acquisition Report”) as part of the marketing process for the Acquisition. This source provides detailed information on the European gym markets, specifically in Poland, Switzerland and Denmark where Fitness World operates. The report provides descriptions of market dynamics and trends, membership statistics, data on Fitness World’s competitive positioning and potential expansion opportunities for value operators. - OC&C, an international strategy consulting firm, was commissioned by the Company to create a Commercial Diligence report for the Company (the “OC&C Report”) in connection with the Acquisition. This source provides information on the UK gym market, specifically, the competitive landscape, customer behaviour and ratings as well as Pure Gym’s historic performance and growth opportunities. - LDC, a UK-based retail location insight company, produced a report on the state of the UK fitness industry in 2019 (the “LDC Report”). The report provides statistics on key market metrics, including penetration rates and membership growth, detailed information on new benefits and discounts operators are offering and forecasts for where the market is heading in the future. This source gives an in-depth analysis of the UK population to provide insight on membership growth potential, rankings and statistics on the top fitness industry operators and information on public versus private gyms broken down into geographical regions, including London. - OC&C, an international strategy consulting firm, was commissioned by Pure Gym to create the Commercial & Strategic Review Report (the “CSR Report”). This source provides information on the UK gym market, specifically, the competitive landscape, customer behaviour and ratings as well as Pure Gym’s historic performance and growth opportunities. The CSR Report obtained some data from LDC xvi ----- prior to publication of LDC’s 2017 State of the UK Fitness Industry Report. References to CSR Report estimates are based on the numbers provided by LDC to the CSR Report providers prior to publication of the LDC report and may slightly differ from the numbers that LDC provided in its final report. In addition to the foregoing, certain information regarding markets, market size, market share, market position, growth rates and other industry data pertaining to the Combined Group contained in this Offering Memorandum were estimated or derived based on assumptions we deem reasonable and from our own research, surveys or studies conducted by third parties and other industry or general publications. While we believe the Combined Group’s internal estimates to be reasonable, these estimates have not been verified by any independent sources and neither the Issuer nor the Initial Purchasers can assure you as to their accuracy or the accuracy of the underlying assumptions used to estimate such data. In addition, the markets in which we operate and compete may have shifted or changed since the date that each industry report was prepared. Therefore, the industry reports may not accurately reflect certain aspects of the current market and industry, and in particular, the industry reports may no longer be accurate or relevant to current expectations as they do not contemplate the effects of COVID-19. Our estimates involve risks and uncertainties and are subject to change based on various factors. See “Risk Factors”, “Industry Overview” and “Business” for further discussion.
