Section Title: EXCHANGE RATE AND CURRENCY INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The following tables set forth, for the periods indicated below, the high, low, average and period end OANDA Exchange Rate expressed as pounds sterling per U.S.$1.00, pounds sterling per €1.00 and pounds sterling per DKK1.00. The OANDA Exchange Rate is a “best market” calculation, in which, at any point in time, the bid rate is equal to the highest bid rate of all contributing bank indications and the ask rate is set to the lowest ask rate offered by these banks. The OANDA Exchange Rate is a mid-value rate between the applied highest bid rate and the lowest ask rate. The below rates may differ from the actual rates used in the preparation of the consolidated financial information and other financial information appearing in this Offering Memorandum. We make no representation that the pounds sterling amounts referred to below could have been or could, in the future, be converted into U.S. dollars, euro, or DKK, as applicable, at any particular rate, if at all.

Section Title: CERTAIN DEFINITIONS
Subsubsection Text: In this Offering Memorandum, the following words and expressions have the following meanings, unless the context otherwise requires or unless otherwise so defined. In particular, capitalized terms set forth and used in the sections entitled “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility _Agreement”, “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement” and “Description of the Notes” may have different meanings from the meanings given to such terms and used elsewhere in this Offering_ Memorandum. - “2017 Acquisition” refers to the acquisition by the Issuer of Topco on November 30, 2017. - “Acquisition” refers to the acquisition by Pinnacle Europe Holdings Limited of Fitness World in accordance with and on the terms of the sale and purchase agreement. - “Acquisition Date” refers to January 14, 2020, the date on which the Acquisition was completed. - “Additional RCF Amount (January 2020)” refers to the aggregate principal amount of £35.0 million, made available by the lenders thereunder pursuant to the additional facility notice dated January 9, 2020 in respect of the additional facility described therein. - “Additional RCF Amount (September 2020)” refers to the £50.0 million increased commitment under Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility pursuant to the Amendment and Restatement Deed (No. 1). - “Agreed Security Principles” refers to the “Agreed Security Principles” set out in a schedule to the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility Agreement as in effect on the Issue Date, as interpreted and applied mutatis mutandis with respect to the Notes in good faith by the Issuer. - “Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility” refers to the revolving credit facility made available under the terms of the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility Agreement in an aggregate principal amount of £145.0 million, comprising the Original RCF Amount, the Additional RCF Amount (January 2020) and the Additional RCF Amount (September 2020). - “Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility Agreement” refers to the Original Revolving Credit Facility Agreement as amended and restated by the Amendment and Restatement Deed (No. 1) and the Amendment and Restatement Deed (No. 2). - “Amendment and Restatement Deed (No. 1)” refers to the amendment and restatement deed dated September 10, 2020, entered into between, among others, the Issuer as company and obligors’ agent, Barclays Bank PLC, as facility agent and Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch, as security agent, providing for the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility. - “Amendment and Restatement Deed (No. 2)” means an amendment and restatement deed dated on or about the Issue Date, entered into between, among others, the Issuer as company and obligors’ agent, the Fitness World Guarantors, Barclays Bank PLC, as facility agent and Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch, as security agent. - “Basefit” refers to the brand that Fitness World operates through its subsidiary, Basefit.ch AG, in Switzerland. - “Brexit” refers to the exit of the United Kingdom from the European Union on January 31, 2020. - “Bridge Facility” refers to the credit facility made available under the terms of the Bridge Facility Agreement. - “Bridge Facility Agreement” refers to the senior secured term loan facility agreement dated January 9, 2020 with Barclays Bank PLC, Jefferies Finance LLC, Royal Bank of Canada, Credit Suisse xx ----- International, Danske Bank A/S, and ING Bank N.V., London Branch as original lenders, Barclays Bank PLC, as facility agent and Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch, as security agent, providing for a credit facility in an aggregate principal amount of €445 million, as amended by an amendment deed dated September 18, 2020. - “Clearstream” refers to Clearstream Banking S.A. - “Closing members” refers to the total number of members as the total number of active members, _including the total number of members who have suspended (or “frozen”) their memberships, but_ excluding_ “pay-as-you-go” customers, members who have cancelled their memberships and preopening members of organic gyms that have yet to open, as of the specified date or the last day of the relevant period. - “Combined **Group” refers to the Issuer and its Restricted Subsidiaries, including Fitness World. - “Companies Act” refers to the Companies Act of 2006 (United Kingdom), as amended. - “COVID-19” refers to the infectious disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2, the pandemic resulting therefrom which was continuing as of the date of this Offering Memorandum and public health events related thereto. - “CPA” refers to costs incurred during the period related to customer acquisition divided by customers acquired. - “Danish Guarantors” refers to Fitness World Group A/S and Fitness World A/S. - “EEA” refers to the European Economic Area. - “Equity Injection” refers to the contribution of £100.0 million in additional cash by way of a subordinated shareholder loan by Pinnacle Midco 2 Limited to Pinnacle Bidco plc on September 18, 2020. - “EU” refers to the European Union. - “EU member state” refers to a member state of the European Union. - “Euroclear” refers to Euroclear Bank SA/NV. - “Existing Indenture” refers to the indenture governing the Existing Notes, dated January 24, 2018, by and among, inter alios, the Issuer and the Trustee. - “Existing Notes” refers to the Issuer’s £430,000,000 aggregate principal amount of 6[3]∕8% Senior Secured Notes due 2025. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Existing Notes”. - “FCA” refers to the Financial Conduct Authority acting in its capacity as the competent authority for the purposes of Part VI of FSMA. - “FCs” refers to Fitness Coaches at Pure Gym locations who are employed by Pure Gym for 12 hours per week under the terms of a standard employment contract. FCs may spend these 12 hours leading induction sessions for new members at Pure Gym, taking exercise classes, undertaking light cleaning, answering any questions members may have and generally having a visible presence on the gym floor. - “Fitness World” refers to Forward TopCo A/S and its subsidiaries. - “Fitness World Guarantors” refers to the Swiss Guarantor and the Danish Guarantors. xxi ----- - _“Forward TopCo A/S” refers to Forward TopCo A/S, a public limited liability company (Aktieselskab) incorporated under the laws of Denmark and registered in the central business register (CVR) of the Danish Business Authority (Erhvervsstyrelsen) under registration number 36699884. - “FSMA” refers to the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000, as amended. - “Guarantees” collectively refers to the guarantees issued by each of the Guarantors on a senior basis, in respect of the Notes. - “Guarantors” collectively refers to the Pure Gym Guarantors and the Fitness World Guarantors. - “HRMC” refers to Her Majesty’s Revenue & Customs. - “Indenture” refers to the indenture governing the Notes, to be dated the Issue Date, by and among, _inter alios, the Issuer and the Trustee._ - “Initial Purchasers” refers to Barclays Bank PLC, Jefferies International Limited, RBC Europe Limited, Credit Suisse Securities (Europe) Limited, Danske Bank A/S and ING Bank N.V., London Branch and “Initial Purchaser” refers to each of them. - “Intercreditor Agreement” refers to the intercreditor agreement dated November 28, 2017 between, _inter alios, the Issuer, the Security Agent and the agent under the Original Revolving Credit Facility_ Agreement on behalf of the lenders thereunder and to which the trustee under the Indenture is expected to accede on or about the Issue Date, as amended pursuant to an amendment deed dated January 23, 2018. - “Issue Date” refers to the date of original issuance of the Notes. - “Issuer” refers to Pinnacle Bidco plc, a public limited company organized under the laws of England and Wales. - “Liquidity Test Date” means (i) each quarter date occurring during the Waiver Period; and (ii) if the Available Liquidity (as defined in the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) on any quarter date occurring during the Waiver Period is less than £50,000,000, the last day of each month of the subsequent financial quarter (provided that, if on any subsequent quarter date, the Available Liquidity is not less than £50,000,000, the Liquidity Test Date shall again be only the following quarter date and not the last day of a month) but in any case no later than the end of the Waiver Period. - “M&A Conversion” refers to a site acquired for consideration by the Group from another gym operator. For an M&A Conversion, Pure Gym acquires the site and its membership and converts the site to the Pure Gym brand and operating model. - “Notes” refers to the €445,000,000 aggregate principal amount of % Senior Secured Notes due 2025 offered hereby. - “Number of gyms” as the total number of gyms that are open and trading as of the specified date or the end date of the relevant period. - “Number of members” as the total number of active members of Pure Gym and/or Fitness World, as applicable, including the total number of members who have suspended (to “freeze” or have “frozen”) their memberships, but excluding “pay-as-you-go” customers, the total number of members who have cancelled their memberships and the total number of pre-opening members of organic gyms that have yet to open, as of the specified date or the end date of the relevant period. - “Offering” refers to the offering of the Notes pursuant to this Offering Memorandum. xxii ----- - “Organic Conversion” refers to a site where a gym was previously operated by another operator but has been converted to the Pure Gym brand and operating model. For an Organic Conversion, Pure Gym takes on a lease directly from another gym operator via a lease assignment or sublease agreement, or enters a new lease directly with the landlord following relinquishment of a lease by another gym operator. - “Organic Greenfield” refers to a site where a gym was not previously operated. For an Organic Greenfield, Pure Gym or Fitness World, as applicable, enters a lease directly with a landlord. - “Original RCF Amount” refers to the aggregate principal amount of £60 million, made available by the lenders thereunder pursuant to the Original Revolving Credit Facility Agreement. - “Original Revolving Credit Facility Agreement” refers to the revolving credit facility agreement dated November 28, 2017 (as amended and restated pursuant to an amendment and restatement agreement dated February 20, 2018), with Barclays Bank PLC, Jefferies Finance LLC, Royal Bank of Canada, Credit Suisse AG, London Branch and ING Bank N.V., London Branch, as mandated lead arrangers, Barclays Bank PLC, as facility agent and Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch, as security agent which provided for the Original RCF Amount. - _“Paying Agent” refers to Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch. - “pre-opening offer” refers to a special pre-opening rate offered to certain members that join a gym prior to or shortly after its opening date. - “Prospectus Regulation” refers to Regulation (EU) 2017/1129. - “PT/FCs” refers to individuals at Pure Gym locations who perform the role of both Rent PT and FC. - “Pure Gym” refers to Pinnacle Bidco plc and its consolidated subsidiaries, excluding Fitness World. - “Pure Gym Guarantors” refers to Gym Topco Limited, Gym Midco Limited, Gym Midco 2 Limited, Gym Bidco Limited and Pure Gym Limited. - “QIB” refers to “qualified institutional buyers” within the meaning of Rule 144A. - _“Registrar” refers to Deutsche Bank Luxembourg S.A. - “Regulation S” refers to Regulation S under the U.S. Securities Act. - “Rent PTs” refers to self-employed personal trainers at Pure Gym locations who pay rent to use Pure Gym premises to train their clients. Rent rates are set contractually for each gym using the market rate for each locality and is paid on the 1[st] of each month. - “RFID” refers to radio-frequency identification. - “Rule 144A” refers to Rule 144A under the U.S. Securities Act. - “SEC” refers to the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. - “Security Agent” refers to Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch, as security agent under the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, the Security Documents, the Indenture and the Intercreditor Agreement. - “Security Documents” has the meaning ascribed to it under “Description of the Notes—Certain _Definitions”._ xxiii ----- - _“Subordinated Shareholder Funding”_ refers collectively to (i) £281.0 million in subordinated shareholder indebtedness incurred by the Issuer in connection with the 2017 Acquisition and (ii) the £100.0 million Equity Injection made as contribution of additional cash by way of a subordinated shareholder loan by Pinnacle Midco 2 Limited to Pinnacle Bidco plc on September 18, 2020, each as described more fully under “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Subordinated _Shareholder Funding”._ - “Supplemental Indenture” refers to the New York Law governed supplemental indenture entered into on or about the Issue Date between, among others, Pinnacle Bidco plc as Issuer, Fitness World Group A/S, Fitness World A/S and Basefit.ch AG as Guarantors and Deutsche Trustee Company Limited as Trustee, relating to the Existing Indenture. - “Swiss Guarantor” refers to Basefit.ch AG. - “Topco” refers to Gym Topco Limited. - “Transactions” refers to consummation of the Acquisition, refinancing of Fitness World’s existing indebtedness, incurrence of indebtedness under the Bridge Facility, entry into the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, the Offering and the application of the use of proceeds as set out in the section “Use of Proceeds”, as described more fully under “Summary—The _Transactions”._ - _“Transfer Agent” refers to Deutsche Bank Luxembourg S.A. - “Trustee” refers to Deutsche Trustee Company Limited as trustee under the Indenture. - “Unaudited **_Pro Forma Combined Financial Information” refers to the unaudited_** _pro forma combined statement of comprehensive income for the year ended December 31, 2019 and related explanatory notes. The Unaudited Pro Forma Combined Financial Information has been prepared as though the Transactions had occurred as of January 1, 2019 for the purpose of the unaudited pro forma combined statement of comprehensive income for the year ended December 31, 2019. - “U.S. Exchange Act” refers to the U.S. Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended. - “U.S. Securities Act” refers to the U.S. Securities Act of 1933, as amended, and the rules and regulations promulgated by the SEC thereunder. - “Waiver Period” means the period on and from September 18, 2020 and ending on the earlier to occur of: (i) 30 September 2022 and (ii) the date on which the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility is reduced to no more than £95,000,000. In addition to the terms defined above, the terms “we”, “us”, “our”, “Company” and other similar terms refer, unless the context otherwise requires, to the Issuer and its consolidated subsidiaries. xxiv -----

Section Title: INFORMATION REGARDING FORWARD-LOOKING STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: This Offering Memorandum includes statements that are, or may deemed to be, “forward-looking statements,” within the meaning of the securities laws of certain jurisdictions, including statements under the headings “Market and Industry Data”, “Summary”, “Risk Factors”, “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial _Condition and Results of Operations of Pure Gym”, “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations of Fitness World”, “Business” and other sections. These forward-looking statements can be_ identified by the use of forward-looking terminology, including the terms “anticipate,” “expect,” “suggests,” “plan,” “believe,” “intend,” “estimates,” “targets,” “projects,” “should,” “could,” “would,” “may,” “will,” “forecast,” and other similar expressions or, in each case, their negative or other variations or comparable terminology. These forwardlooking statements include all matters that are not historical facts. They appear in a number of places throughout this Offering Memorandum and include statements regarding our intentions, beliefs or current expectations concerning, among other things, our results of operations, financial condition, liquidity, prospects, growth, strategies and the industry in which we operate. We caution you that forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance and that our actual results of operations, financial condition and liquidity, and the development of the industry in which we operate may differ materially from those made in or suggested by the forward-looking statements contained in this Offering Memorandum. In addition, even if our results of operations, financial condition and liquidity, and the development of the industry in which we operate are consistent with the forward-looking statements contained in this Offering Memorandum, those results or developments may not be indicative of results or developments in subsequent periods. Any forward-looking statements that we make in this Offering Memorandum speak only as of the date of such statement, and we undertake no obligation and do not intend to update such statements. Comparisons of results for current and any prior periods are not intended to express any future trends or indications of future performance, unless expressed as such, and should only be viewed as historical data. By their nature, forward-looking statements, including management's projections included herein, involve risks and uncertainties because they relate to events and depend on circumstances that may or may not occur in the future. We believe that these risks and uncertainties include, but are not limited to, those described in the “Risk _Factors” section of this Offering Memorandum:_ - the impact of COVID-19 on our customers, employees, suppliers, the capital markets and our financial condition, and results of operations, all of which may aggravate the other risks and uncertainties we face; - the strategic decision to not invest resources in our Polish operations; - the use of unaudited financial data and company projections; - our ability to attract and retain gym members while maintaining sustainable and profitable membership fees; - our ability to identify and secure sites for new gyms on favourable terms; - failure of our gyms’ locations to be economically viable; - our ability to achieve expected return on capital employed; - our ability to control costs; - the possibility of increased litigation following the period in which a rent moratorium or similar governmental measure relating to rent is lifted; - our ability to renew our existing leases or to terminate unprofitable leases; - failure to obtain the requisite planning permissions to open new gyms; - opening new gyms near our existing locations; - our ability to acquire other health and fitness businesses and related integration risks; - risks of disruptions or failures involving our information technology systems; - our dependence on our brand and reputation; - risks related to operating a sports nutrition brand; xxv ----- - our ability to successfully execute our growth strategy or effectively manage our growth; - our growth placing strains on our management, employees, information systems and internal controls; - our ability to invest in new business lines; - our ability to expand into new international markets; - risks related to operating in new international markets in which we have no operating history; - our inability to realize the anticipated benefits of the Acquisition and achieve our strategic goals; - our ability to retain key individuals and personal trainers; - risks related to any change in the employment status of personal trainers; - maintaining corporate culture; - risks related to incurring additional indebtedness; - dependence on third-party contractors and suppliers; - the risk of infringement, misappropriation of or a challenge to our intellectual property rights; - risk of inadequate insurance coverage; - risks related to any forced closures of our gyms; - risks related to foreign exchange; - competitive nature of the health and fitness industry; - dependence on continuing popularity of health and fitness in the countries in which we operate and the popularity of value gyms; - adverse changes in consumer discretionary spending and general economic conditions; - risk of fines and claims related to health and safety risks at our gyms; - failure to comply with data protection legislation or a security breach or system failure; - risks related to licensing regimes, tariffs or taxes; - significant risks related to the projections and unaudited financial information included herein; - factors affecting our leverage and our ability to service our debt; - the effects of our restrictive debt covenants on our ability to finance our future operations and capital needs and to pursue business opportunities and activities; and - other factors discussed or referred to in this Offering Memorandum. The foregoing factors and others described under “Risk Factors” should not be construed as exhaustive. Due to such uncertainties and risks, readers are cautioned not to place undue reliance on these forward-looking statements, which speak only as of the date on the front cover of this Offering Memorandum. We urge you to read this Offering Memorandum, including the sections entitled “Risk Factors”, “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial _Condition and Results of Operations of Pure Gym”, “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations of Fitness World”, and “Business” for a more complete discussion of the factors that could_ affect our future performance and the industries in which we operate. Any forward-looking statements are only made as of the date on the front cover of this Offering Memorandum and, except as required by law or the rules and regulations of any stock exchange on which the Notes are listed, we undertake no obligation to publicly update or publicly revise any forward-looking statement, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. All subsequent written and oral forward-looking statements attributable to us or to persons acting on our behalf are expressly qualified in their entirety by the cautionary statements referred to above and contained elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, including those set forth under “Risk Factors”. xxvi -----

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: Pure Gym has a powerful and highly disruptive customer proposition that is differentiated from traditional gym operators and appeals to a broad range of consumers. The key elements of the proposition include affordable membership fees, no fixed term contracts and 24x7x365 access to high-quality gyms. The proposition is underpinned by the differentiated, capital efficient and technology-enabled gym operating model, which enables Pure Gyms to support high levels of membership, operate on low costs and generate strong unit economics, cash flow conversion and ROCE. As of December 31, 2019, Pure Gym operated 263 gyms in cities and towns across the UK, including 68 gyms within greater London, and had 1,134,683 members overall.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: Since it was founded in 2005, Fitness World has disrupted the Danish fitness market with its convenient, value-for-money, flexible offer. Fitness World has a market-leading position in Denmark with an estimated 43% market share measured by members as of December 2019 (Source: Deloitte/EuropeActive Report). With a clear focus on property and ecosystem management, Fitness World created a smart footprint across cities with a complementary offering across clubs, creating local barriers to entry and satisfying the number one key purchasing criteria, which is proximity (Source: Fitness World Acquisition Report). 2 ----- Fitness World is a household name, with membership including close to 10% of the population over the age of 14 in Denmark (as of December 31, 2019) and is proud of the contribution it has made to public health. Fitness World’s inclusive vision is to promote “healthy habits for all” and thereby enable people from all walks of life to live a healthier lifestyle through fitness training. As of December, 31, 2019, Fitness World had 185 gyms and 485,690 members overall in Denmark. For the year ended December 31, 2019, Fitness World generated revenue of DKK 1,362.1 million (£159.8 million) and Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of DKK 365.8 (£42.9 million) from its operations in Denmark, representing 83% of Fitness World’s total Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: Fitness World entered the Swiss market in 2018 by acquiring Basefit, the second largest gym operator and the leading value operator in Switzerland. In 2019, Basefit was the first player in the Swiss market to offer a flexible monthly membership option, BaseFree, which has been well received by the market as 45% of joiners have opted for BaseFree since its launch in December 2019. As of December 31, 2019, Basefit was the largest Swiss value operator with 39 gyms and 78,677 members and a member churn rate of 46%. Prior to its acquisition by Fitness World, Basefit generated revenue of £11 million and had a Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of £4 million for the year ended December 31, 2016. This increased to revenue of £16 million and a Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of £6 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. Following its acquisition by Fitness World, Basefit’s revenue increased to £21 million and its Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA was £6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. Fitness World has continued to invest in the Basefit brand and its operations in Switzerland. For the year ended December 31, 2019, Basefit generated revenue of DKK 232.7 million (£27.3 million) and Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of DKK 69.0 (£8.1 million) from its operations in Switzerland, representing 16% of Fitness World’s total Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: In 2015, Fitness World entered Poland by acquiring Condizione and its three fitness clubs and has since grown organically through bolt-on acquisitions. In light of the government-mandated closure of our Polish gyms, we have taken the strategic view that we will not be investing additional Group resources in our Polish business at this time. Consequently, we have decided to cease operating in Poland. Our Polish subsidiary has applied to the Polish courts to open an insolvency proceeding under Polish bankruptcy laws with the goal of appointing a trustee to oversee the orderly distribution of our Polish assets. For the year ended December 31, 2019, Fitness World generated revenue of DKK 46.9 million (£5.5 million) and Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of DKK 6.2 million (£0.7 million) from its operations in Poland, representing 1% of Fitness World's total Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: On January 14, 2020, our business combined Pure Gym, a value gym operator that has rapidly become the largest operator of gyms in the United Kingdom both by number of gyms and members, and Fitness World, a leading European gym and value fitness operator with sites across Denmark and Switzerland. We believe that the Combined Group has strong growth prospects and common core competencies, including shared market leadership positions in the UK and Denmark, an inclusive philosophy, a modern technology-enabled customer offer based on high-quality, affordable gyms that can be accessed on a flexible basis, and a strong platform for expansion. Our vision is to provide affordable, flexible, and “value-for-money” memberships to high-quality gyms to all people who want to increase their level of fitness, as demonstrated by our inclusive “everybody welcome” philosophy. In response to COVID-19, governments globally (including within the markets in which we operate) have implemented strict social distancing measures, including varied approaches to lockdowns and closures of non-essential businesses, including ours. COVID-19 presents an unprecedented disruption to our business, and the wide variations in potential outcomes present a material challenge to our business and our industry. We are taking appropriate actions in response to COVID-19 in line with relevant government guidance and we continue to take every step that we believe is prudent to protect and manage our business, control our cost base and protect our operating cash flows. See “Summary—Recent Developments—Impact of COVID-19”. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, it is not possible to accurately predict the short-, medium- or long-term impacts of COVID-19 on our business and our industry. Our strategic mission continues to be providing affordable and flexible memberships to high-quality fitness facilities balanced against the pressures of the macroeconomic environment in which we operate. Upon our acquisition of Fitness World, we were the market-leading operator in the Danish market, with a growing presence in Switzerland and amongst value operators in Europe, were number two by number of sites value operator in Europe and number three by revenue and member numbers. We believe that the strategic rationale for the acquisition of Fitness World remains intact for the long-term despite the significant immediate challenges faced in a COVID-19 world. For the year ended December 31, 2019, we derived 57% of our revenue from our operations in the UK, 36% from our operations in Denmark, 6% from operations in Switzerland and 1% from our operations in Poland. Our key geographic markets are the UK and Denmark and as such, Pure Gym and Fitness World will continue operating under their existing brand names in these key markets. As of December 31, 2019, the Combined Group operated 504 gyms in cities and towns across the four countries, with Pure Gym accounting for 52% of clubs and Fitness World accounting for 48% of clubs, and had approximately 1.7 million members in total. The table below displays the key European gym operators by number of members: 1 ----- (‘000 Members) (1) Source: Company information and Deloitte/EuropeActive Report. (2) Pure Gym excludes pre-opening members and includes members at Pure Gym branded gyms only. (3) Pure Gym, Fitness World and The Gym Group data is as of December 2019; Basic-Fit data is as of Q3 2019. Members of other operators are as per latest estimates included in the Deloitte/EuropeActive Report. Fitness World is a good strategic fit for Pure Gym due to its aligned low-cost operating model. The Combined Group is the third largest operator in Europe by membership and the second largest by number of gyms. With leading market positions in the UK and Denmark and as the second largest player in Switzerland, the Combined Group is a market-leading European value gym operator with diversification and scale benefits. Our disruptive customer value proposition, differentiated business model and well-managed growth strategy has allowed us to grow rapidly. For the year ended December 2019, the Combined Group generated revenue of £447.5 million and a Combined Group Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of £161.2 million after giving pro forma effect to the Acquisition. In the same timeframe, Pure Gym’s UK operations generated revenue of £255 million and Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of £105 million, representing growth of 12.1% and 41.0%, respectively, as compared to the previous year end.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Attractive and resilient fitness market driven by established trends towards the value segment
Subsubsection Text: Pure Gym and Fitness World operate in an attractive and growing market within which the value segment is growing. The European health and fitness club market had a market value of £21.9 billion as of December 2019 (Source: OC&C Report) and fitness club memberships continue to increase across most of the European geographies. Over the four years from December 2015 to December 2019, members of the European fitness market increased from 54 million to 65 million, which reflects a compound annual growth rate of 4.5% (Source: OC&C Report). In the UK, the health and fitness club market continues to benefit from the UK population becoming more health-conscious and from various government initiatives designed to promote healthy living and active lifestyles. The UK health market has also benefitted from the increasing prevalence of value gyms, which have increased the availability of fitness facilities to a larger proportion of the population. The value gym market share increased from 7% to 13% over the past four years between December 2015 and December 2019, as a percentage of total market value (Source: LDC Report, OC&C Report). 3 ----- Historically, the UK health and fitness market has been served by mid-market and premium private gym operators and by public gym operators. While the value gym segment has grown quickly over the past several years, we believe there remains significant opportunity for further growth due to value gyms’ broad consumer appeal. Currently, 16% of the United Kingdom population is a member of a gym, which is below equivalent penetration rates in Sweden (22%), Norway (21%) and the U.S. (20%) (Source: OC&C Report). There remains room for growth in gym market penetration in Denmark and Switzerland, with only 19% of the Danish population and 14% of the Swiss population having a gym membership. In Denmark, market share of the value segment increased from 45% to 56% over the past four years between 2015 and 2019, as a percentage of total market value. The high market share of value gyms is mainly driven by the clear leadership position of Fitness World in Denmark. The value gym market has demonstrated resilience during periods of economic decline and can also support growth in these conditions as consumers consider cost-conscious alternatives. Consumer spending on gyms has shown resilience during periods of decreased overall economic activity, as demonstrated by a 2.1% CAGR in total gym spend in the UK health and fitness club market between 2006 and 2012, during which period total gym spend did not fall during any individual year. From 2008 to 2012, value gyms grew significantly, with membership increasing by a CAGR of 12.1% (Source: LDC Report, OC&C Report). Throughout 2020, the COVID-19 pandemic caused unprecedented disruption to our everyday way of life and to our industry. Only those operators with the strong liquidity positions have been able to withstand a period of extended closure and therefore we anticipate some supply will exit the market as weaker operators fail. We believe demand will continue to be strong given the increased focus on health and well-being post COVID-19. We continue to believe we have the right business model, operating in the right market segment to be highly successful in a postCOVID-19 environment in the medium to long term.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Clear market leader in the value segment
Subsubsection Text: We are one of the pioneering operators of value gyms in Europe and have been a leading contributor towards the growth of the value gym market over the past decade. Our scale and market leading position provide us with significant competitive advantages, including: _Commercial Offer—Our leading footprint of 263 gyms in the UK and 185 gyms in Denmark as of December_ 31, 2019 enables us to offer our members multi-site access in many locations. In addition, our scale enables us to pursue partnerships and other commercial arrangements that further differentiate our product offering and value proposition. _Property Acquisition—We have historically had a strong landlord covenant rating and have benefitted from_ “tenant of choice” status given our scale, strong brand and high quality product. As a result, we are generally able to secure our selected sites on attractive lease terms throughout the UK and Denmark. _Technology—We have invested heavily in building out our digital presence and software engineering teams_ and third-party technology relationships. As a result, we have a high and increasing degree of control over, and the ability to improve, our web, mobile and application-based offerings. We believe this will help reduce costs and increase revenues over time, particularly following the integration of technological systems between Pure Gym and Fitness World. Key features of our technology include: - Website and dedicated apps that, among other things, provide members the ability to enrol and upgrade into the various membership packages, utilize nutrition and exercise guides, view workout videos, find and book classes, see how busy their gym is, track their gym activity, follow workout plans and track body composition metrics. - Superior technology-enabled systems within individual gyms, including automatic PIN-based gym entry systems at all Pure Gyms, access card gym entry at all Fitness World clubs and “intelligent cycling” at certain Fitness World sites. 4 ----- _Brand—The Combined Group has national brands that benefit from higher levels of brand awareness than_ any other value gym operator in the UK and Denmark. The scale and nationwide footprint allow the business to effectively pursue national marketing campaigns such as TV advertisements. In the UK, the Pure Gym brand is also supplemented by a workout video YouTube channel with over 16,000 subscribers and an Instagram account with over 110,000 followers as of February 2020. In Denmark, Fitness World’s presence is supplemented by 32,300 followers on its Instagram account as of February 2020. Fitness World also uses its dedicated app to advertise services and products such as personal training and sports nutrition drinks from its Functional Nutrition line, which grows the brand and drives value added sales. _Ability to invest—Our scale and resources allow us to rapidly develop new sites and invest in other areas of_ our business, such as technology, that enable us to operate more efficiently and deliver a better customer experience. Our reinvestment and refurbishment capability further differentiates us from smaller cashconstrained competitors.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Diversified operator with scale that is difficult to replicate
Subsubsection Text: We have become a market-leading value gym operator in the UK and Danish markets, with a growing presence in Switzerland. As a result, we are uniquely positioned to benefit from the outperformance in the countries in which we operate, including for the following reasons: - _Increasing scale and a healthy degree of geographic diversification—Upon its acquisition of Fitness World, the newly Combined Group was number two in Europe by number of gyms with over 500 sites (517 sites as of November 9, 2020, consisting of 253 open sites, 236 closed sites in England, six closed sites in Denmark, three closed sites in Switzerland and 19 closed sites in Poland due to COVID-19 restrictions) and had a Combined Group Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of £161.2 million as of December 31, 2019 (on a _pro forma basis). We are geographically diversified with 43% of Combined Group revenue generated from operations outside of the UK. In the year ended December 31, 2019, we generated £255 million in UK revenue, £160 million in Danish revenue, £27 million in Swiss revenue and £5 million in Polish revenue. We have the largest gym estate and membership base in the UK market with 11% of total UK gym members and we are a leader in Danish fitness industry with an estimated 43% market share. We believe our expansive presence allows us to procure services and products on favourable terms due to the larger volume of our operations, which gives us superior purchasing power compared to smaller gym operators or new entrants into the market. - _High barriers to scale—We believe that new fitness brands would experience extreme difficulty in attempting to disrupt our strong presence and overall member loyalty, particularly in the UK and in Denmark. We are present in some of the most attractive locations, making it difficult for new entrants to open competing clubs given our accumulated expertise for identifying gym sites. We also have a diversified network of gyms which allows us to offer multi-site membership more effectively. Key features of our business that new entrants would have difficulty in scaling include: - _Expertise in property management—Given our established operating track record and position as the value gym industry leader in the UK and Denmark with national scale, we have acquired significant expertise in property acquisition and management. We are skilled at identifying site locations that will be successful and provide strong ROCE. In order to maintain our market-leading position, we have a strong site selection and property development team with industry expertise supported by an external team of professionals, such as lawyers, architects and planning consultants, as well as the technological tools at our disposal. In particular, we utilize a quantitative whitespace tool to identify attractive new locations in all geographies. The whitespace tool takes into account population statistics, drive time, local demographics, commercial space in catchment area, office locations data, competitor locations and infrastructure (for example, proximity to train stations) when analysing potential new sites. The whitespace tool both identifies attractive cities as well as optimal locations for rollout within a city. 5 ----- - _Industry leading technology platform—We continue to invest in our technology platform, consisting of both websites and mobile applications, where our members can book classes, pay for their memberships and other ancillary services. As the fitness industry increasingly converges with the digital sector, we believe that our technology platform allows our members to more easily access and purchase our services, which helps us attract and retain members. Additionally, our technology-enabled platform allows us to analyse user-specific data which in turn, supports our operational performance. This allows our management to better control all aspects of our pricing strategy, product development and promotional activities. Pure Gym and Fitness World have independently invested in their technological platforms and the Combined Group will benefit from the combination of IT capabilities across its operations as these systems converge. - _Leading marketing expertise driving strong brand awareness—We have an increasingly sophisticated, multi-channel digital-led marketing strategy which is not overly reliant on any single channel. We employ a range of marketing techniques through various media channels in order to promote a contemporary and differentiated brand, which would be difficult for new entrants to replicate given our resources and prior marketing experience. - _Superior convenience as a result of network scale—We have the largest gym network in the UK and Denmark, which allows us to capitalize on potential members’ desire for proximity. We believe this to be a competitive advantage, given that research indicates that proximity is among the top two most important factors for members when choosing a gym. - _Greater access to capital allowing for rapid growth—Based on our strong operating cash flow conversion, which is driven by our highly efficient and high-margin operating model, comparatively low maintenance capital expenditure requirements and positive working capital inflows, we are able to continue investing in new and existing sites. This allows us to protect and grow our market share, while we observe that some mid-market gym operators are often choosing not to reinvest in their existing sites or in expansion. - _Pricing sophistication—We have the ability to employ dynamic pricing at certain gyms in order to tailor our price points to the local market. This allows us to adapt to local markets by managing member enrolment and thus optimize revenues. - _Purchasing Scale—We believe we are the largest purchaser of gym equipment in our key geographies from leading suppliers including Matrix, Precor and Technogym, thereby reducing the costs of constructing and operating our gyms. - _Highly experienced team with significant industry know-how—Our team has exceptional local knowledge, which is based on strong relationships that they have developed over time. We have made, and continue to make, significant investments in our management team comprised of experienced professionals with established track records.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Powerful and highly disruptive customer value proposition
Subsubsection Text: We believe that our customer value proposition, which is focused on providing affordable and flexible memberships to high-quality fitness facilities, is powerful and highly disruptive to the traditional gym and fitness industry. The strength of our customer value proposition has enabled us to grow rapidly by gaining significant market share from traditional mid-market and premium operators, as well as attracting consumers to our gyms who have never previously been a member of a fitness club. The key characteristics of Pure Gym’s customer proposition are as follows: _High-quality facilities and inclusive philosophy—Our gyms are equipped with a large number of pieces of_ high-specification gym equipment, including a broad selection of cardio machines, fixed resistance machines, free weights and functional and other exercise equipment, such as TRX bands and kettlebells. Our gyms are clean, well-maintained and are fitted out with high-quality changing rooms and shower facilities and audio/visual systems. We have welcoming environments and we seek to support all members in the pursuit of their fitness goals, regardless of their current abilities, as demonstrated by our 6 ----- “everybody welcome” philosophy in Pure Gyms and “create healthy habits for all” philosophy in Fitness World clubs. _Affordable pricing—Our flexible and low-cost membership structure provides excellent value for money for_ our members, with student discounts and day passes at Pure Gym locations and off-peak membership options. These options further minimize costs at Pure Gyms and Fitness World clubs, often enabling access to affordable fitness where there previously was none. _Flexibility—We offer a great range of flexibility through our enrolment offers, free classes, extended opening_ hours, premium membership options, and online membership management. - _Enrolment—Members can sign up with no fixed term contract in the UK, Denmark and Switzerland. Accordingly, members have the freedom and the flexibility to leave at their convenience without incurring cancellation fees and have the ability to freeze their memberships for months at a time. - _Access—We generally offer 24x7x365 access in the UK and extended opening hours in Denmark. This contrasts with the opening hours of mid-market and premium operators, which tend to be more restricted. Clubs in Switzerland are open for 14 to 17 hours a day during weekdays with more limited weekend hours depending on each club. - _Free classes—We have dedicated group exercise studios, including purpose-built stationary cycling studios in many locations. Most Pure Gym clubs offer over 50 free classes per week taught by professional personal trainers. Fitness World incorporates a wide range of class offerings in their membership model. Other operators in the value market do not typically offer such an extensive range of classes. - _Premium Memberships—For an additional monthly premium, our members can choose to upgrade their enrolment options, which provides them with a number of additional benefits. For example, they may have the ability to book classes earlier than standard members, guest passes and larger discounts on sports and fitness brands or receive a set number of personal training sessions a year. - _Online Membership Management—Our online website and app platforms allow members to manage their membership online, freeze or cancel their membership, book classes, locate gym facilities, track fitness data and engage in fitness challenges.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: High cash flow generative profile underpinned by exceptional profitability and positive working capital cash inflows
Subsubsection Text: We believe that we have a low cost, capital efficient and technology-enabled gym operating model that provides a competitive advantage over mid-market and premium gym operators. The operating model allows us to offer a compelling customer proposition, support high levels of membership and require low levels of operating and Initial Capital Investment costs. Collectively, these factors drive strong unit economics and ROCEs. The key characteristics of the model are as follows: _Highly capital efficient—Greenfield gyms require a known level of maintenance and refurbishment capital_ expenditure post initial pre-opening investments relating to leasehold costs and fit-out. Landlords will often contribute to the initial fit-out of clubs and in Denmark, these landlord contributions are often significant. Gyms generate stable and predictable EBITDA at maturity (24-36 months post opening), driving attractive ROCE. _Low personnel costs—We are able to operate our gyms with low levels of employed personnel primarily_ through the use of technology. For example, Pure Gym uses an online joining process and Fitness World offers in-app enrolment, both of which eliminate the need for a dedicated in-gym sales forces which are commonly used by mid-market and premium operators. Members at Pure Gym and Fitness World locations also use fully-automated PIN-controlled entry portals or member cards to facilitate secure 7 ----- access to gyms, which eliminates the need for additional staff. We believe that we can build upon existing commonalities between Pure Gym and Fitness World and further increase personnel cost efficiency by applying some UK best practices to Fitness World gyms through measures such as unmanned hours covered by video surveillance with tailored alert systems. _Highly effective utilization of space—Unlike most mid-market and premium operators, we do not install_ pools, spas, saunas, steam room, extensive cafes or other high-end amenities in our gyms. These amenities are generally expensive to construct, operate and maintain and take up a significant amount of leased space. We believe that these amenities are generally less utilized by members and that by eliminating them we are able to install a greater number of pieces of high utilization fitness equipment, such as treadmills, free weights and stationary bikes. As a result, our gyms in the UK, Denmark and Switzerland can support high levels of membership while operating on low operating and Initial Capital Investment costs. In addition to consistent and predictable growth, we have strong overall gym performance in the countries in which we operate. For our UK operations, revenue increased from £159.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 to £254.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, representing a CAGR of 16.8%. Similarly, Pure Gym Run-Rate Adjusted increased from £69.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 to £104.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, representing a CAGR of 14.5%. For the acquired Fitness World, revenue increased from £121.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 to £192.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, representing a CAGR of 16.6%. Fitness World Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA increased from £28.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 to £51.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, representing a CAGR of 22.3%. The Combined Group benefits from a highly cash generative business model, which is driven by manageable maintenance capital expenditure requirements and positive working capital inflows. The working capital dynamics are underpinned by rent free periods for new leases, favourable terms with our primary gym equipment providers, and payments from members being received in advance, while major suppliers are paid in arrears. Following the historical period of investment, there is limited further expenditure required in central functions (for example, a head office), which helps to ensure that we are a fully scalable platform going forward.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: Our senior management has an established track record of delivering growth and operational excellence in their current roles at the company and in their prior roles at a range of other businesses. Senior management is supported by an experienced management team in key areas, including property acquisition, property development, operations, IT, marketing, human resources and finance. The experienced management team from Fitness World has proven capabilities to drive growth across multiple geographies. The individuals that form part of our property acquisition and development teams are highly experienced in the markets in which we operate. They have strong relationships with landlords, agents, developers and contractors and a proven ability to identify and develop a large number of successful sites while promoting consistent growth as evidenced by our estate growth. We believe that the strength and experience of the property acquisition and development teams ensures that we are well placed to secure attractive new gym sites. Under the current CEO, Pure Gym has grown from an operator of 84 gyms with £37 million of Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA to an operator of over 500 gyms with £161.2 million of Combined Group Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA as of December 31, 2019 (on a pro forma basis). In addition to a strong track record of operational excellence and property acquisition expertise, our leadership team also adheres to a balanced fiscal policy of deleveraging. Pure Gym has consistently reduced its leverage over the past three years. In November 2017, Pure Gym had a leverage ratio of 4.6x (calculated as senior secured net debt divided by Adjusted EBITDA). As of December 2018, this reduced to 3.9x and as of December 2019, the leverage ratio was further reduced to 3.6x, demonstrating a consistent organic deleveraging profile. Further, we have a clear deleveraging strategy for the future as we intend to: - deploy new equity capital in a considered and measured way to open new sites, improve existing sites and deliver technology assets; - reduce leverage by growing EBITDA through new site openings and deployment of technology assets in our core business and through capital-light franchising growth; and 8 ----- - balance capital deployment with cashflow generation and progressive deleveraging. Pure Gym has made substantial investments in management over the past two years and important business functions are now generally managed internally, which we believe provides us with a competitive advantage. For example, important IT functions were brought in-house in 2015 and the IT team was strengthened with a number of new hires. The senior management team is comprised of high calibre individuals with broad experience from various sectors and previous businesses. This ensures that our senior management and other important management teams are well invested and are capable of executing both our focus on performance delivery and our growth strategy. We have a strong and differentiated culture centred on collaboration, innovation and entrepreneurship and we believe that this culture has been a key driver of our ability to deliver strong historical growth and widen the gap between us and other operators in the value gym market. This culture has also helped us to attract and retain high quality personnel and create a highly motivated work force that is dedicated to delivering the best product possible. Pure Gym is recognized as an “employer of choice” after being placed in the Sunday Times 100 Best Companies to Work For in 2018 (the results of which are based on employee feedback).

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: We believe that our key strengths are as follows:

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: A rigorous focus on operational excellence to drive the growth and profitability of our existing estate
Subsubsection Text: We remain focused on maintaining the high-quality performance of all our gyms and delivering profitable growth across our existing estate. Management drives revenue performance in a number of ways, including: _Maintaining high standards through targeted investments—We are focused on carefully investing in our_ existing estate in order to maintain the high-quality of our gyms and we seek to continuously optimize the product offer and member experience. This in turn supports our ability to drive membership volumes and tenures, word of mouth recommendations and provide value for money for our members. _Driving Average Revenue Per Member (“ARPM”)—We take a multi-layered approach to increasing ARPM_ by: - _Developing new commercial products—We have implemented and continue to develop new membership options to attract certain types of new members to our gyms and increase our fee yields while consistently offering excellent value for money. For example, Pure Gym has continued to see an increase in penetration of its premium membership products across its gyms. These products take advantage of our technology platform to offer members the option to pre-book classes on a priority basis, take a friend to the gym, obtain multi-site access and freeze their memberships. Similarly, Fitness World offers premium membership options for members who are interested in sports nutritional products or a set number of personal training sessions per year. - _Increasing ancillary sales per visit—Ancillary sales are an integral part of the initiative to increase ARPM. For example, Fitness World has successfully grown ancillary sales through its personal training programs and through developing its own successful brand of nutritional supplements by: - educating over 300 new personal trainers and over 400 new instructors through their Fitness Institute and Fitness World Academy; and - offering nutritional products ranging from sports and energy drinks, protein bars and protein powder for purchase through its on-site vending machines, at reception, or through 9 ----- membership options, such as Fitness World’s “All In” membership in its Denmark clubs, which entitles members to one nutritional product per day. - _Bringing the UK’s variable pricing expertise to Fitness World markets—Fitness World does not currently offer dynamic pricing in the same way that Pure Gym can in the UK. It is believed that there are potential upsides to bringing Pure Gym’s pricing expertise for setting membership fees specific to local markets Denmark and Switzerland. Our operational experts tailor pricing to specific local markets and monitor and change the specific prices over time as the market and our competition evolve. In turn, this allows us to monitor member enrolment, manage capacity and maximize revenue and returns. - _Optimizing site capacity—We seek to optimize the capacity of our existing gyms where this is possible and viable. Capacity optimization can involve the physical extension of gyms, or the redesign of certain aspects of gyms to eliminate site-specific utilization bottlenecks, such as the substitution of low utilization equipment, or the installation of additional automated entry portals or access gates to increase capacity. - _Marketing and CRM—We have strengthened our marketing approaches and we are taking a more sophisticated and data-driven approach to membership acquisition and retention. Pure Gym’s brand awareness is strong but has further room for significant growth in the context of our large estate of gyms. We utilize channels, such as television advertising and social media, to increase brand awareness and drive membership growth. Fitness World’s brand awareness is high in Denmark and we are continuing to build on this awareness by marketing services and products through the Fitness World designated app, social media, and through our association with brand ambassadors. - _Development of new sales channels and cross marketing—We are leveraging our nationwide scale in the UK and in Denmark to identify opportunities to partner and enter into commercial arrangements with large corporations that have the potential to deliver incremental membership volumes. - _Leveraging our technology infrastructure—We have made significant investments in our IT team and infrastructure and believe this helps us provide a value-added member experience and the opportunity for additional member sales. _Maintaining a rigorous focus on cost containment—Our ability to offer low membership fees and generate_ strong unit economics and ROCEs is underpinned by our low-cost operating model. As a result, we are focused on optimizing and controlling gym-level operating costs, as well as Initial Capital Investment Costs. These costs are controlled centrally and we intend to continue to leverage our growing scale in order to achieve more favourable purchasing terms with third-party suppliers, service providers and contractors. In addition, we are pursuing a number of ongoing operational efficiency projects, such as energy saving initiatives, to minimize future gym-level cost increases and improve returns. Following several years of investment into central functions such as IT, marketing and finance, we believe that our central functions are well invested and that we will not require significant incremental central cost expansion in the medium term.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Increasing the number of high quality New Gyms and preserving the consistency and predictability of ROCE
Subsubsection Text: Pure Gym and Fitness World have significantly increased their number of gyms in recent years as a result of organic roll-out and selective acquisitions. We continue to focus on driving the operational and financial performance of New Gyms as they mature, with key areas of focus including: - Using our experience to select attractive gym locations where the demand and demographics result in predictable financial performance - Consistency of delivery and high standards - Leveraging our experience to adapt to local markets 10 ----- - Optimization of volume and ARPM in each gym - Driving scale benefits - Successfully increasing margins and member enrolment for newly-acquired businesses We plan to leverage our experience to continue the organic roll out of new gyms with strong ROCE. Future growth in the value segment will be driven by the development of new value gyms, continued market share gains from mid-market and premium operators, as well as public gyms operated by local authorities, and overall growth in gym participation rates due in part to the increasing awareness and availability of value gyms in each of our markets. The significant opportunity for further growth in the value gym market is evidenced by: - The significant success of the value gym concept to date and its broad consumer appeal. - The current overall penetration rates of gym membership in existing markets as of December 2019; only 16% of the British population, 19% of Danish population, 14% of the Swiss population, and 8% of the Polish population have gym memberships (Source: OC&C Report). We believe that we are ideally positioned to capitalize on this substantial market penetration opportunity as market leaders in the United Kingdom and Denmark with a long, successful track record of opening new gyms and rapidly growing membership, revenue and profitability. The Combined Group has a structured and disciplined approach to site identification, acquisition and development. Our property acquisition teams are highly experienced and have a strong network of property agents, landlords and developers that provide us with a substantial number of new site opportunities. Our gyms have been proven to work across the United Kingdom and Denmark in a wide variety of property types and, accordingly, management considers a broad number of locations for new gyms. We have also proven our ability to innovate through initially testing and now proving the small box format (“SBF”) concept in the UK, which features gyms that are 6,000 to 9,000 square feet in size and enable us to adapt the Pure Gym model to smaller local markets. The UK and Denmark have similar levels of ROCE though different cost structures. Gyms in Denmark generate lower margins and require lower initial capital expenditure compared to UK gyms, due to sizeable landlord contributions and that are partly offset by higher rents. Landlords in Denmark frequently pay for a substantial part of the initial club fit-out costs, thus reducing the payback periods and increasing ROCE. We seek to grow our organic gym estate by both opening new Pure Gyms at sites that were not previously operated as gyms (“Organic Greenfields”) as well as sites that were previously operated as gyms (“Organic

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: Our strategy is to continue to be a market-leading value gym operator by providing affordable, flexible and value-for-money memberships to high-quality gyms to anyone who wants to increase their level of fitness, while simultaneously delivering profitable growth. Our acquisition of Fitness World is a continuation of this strategy, strengthening our position as a market leader in Europe and in geographies outside of the UK. The key elements of our strategy include:

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: On January 14, 2020, the Issuer indirectly acquired Forward TopCo A/S (together with its subsidiaries, “Fitness World”) for consideration of DKK 2,037.1 million (£232.9 million) plus repayment of Fitness World indebtedness of DKK 1,033.1 million (£118.1 million), converted to pounds sterling using the year end specific rate of DKK 8.74687 to £1.00000 as at December 31, 2019. The Acquisition, the refinancing of Fitness World’s existing indebtedness and the payment of related fees and expenses was financed through drawings under the Bridge Facility. We expect to use the proceeds from the Offering to fully repay the amounts drawn under the Bridge Facility in connection with the Acquisition and to pay transaction fees and expenses. See “Use of Proceeds”. On November 28, 2017, the Issuer, the facility agent and security agent under the Original Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, and the Issuer’s parent company (“Holdco”) entered into an intercreditor agreement in connection with the financing of the 2017 Acquisition (the “Intercreditor Agreement”), and the Trustee and the Fitness World Guarantors are expected to accede to the Intercreditor Agreement on or about the Issue Date. 11 ----- While the Group's performance during the six months ended June 30, 2020 was significantly impacted by COVID-19 closures, swift management action protected liquidity and cashflow during lockdown when, for a period, the whole estate was closed. Reopening the Group's gym estate has been successful, as evidenced by positive member feedback, which has translated to encouraging member trends in like-for-like member volumes as well as gym visits. As a result, our principal shareholder, certain affiliated funds of Leonard Green & Partners, L.P. (collectively, “LGP”), remains highly supportive of our business and they remain optimistic about its long-term prospects, as evidenced by the Equity Injection provided by LGP on September 18, 2020. The £100.0 million Equity Injection received by the Group on September 18, 2020, together with increased commitments under the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility described below, are intended to bolster the Group's balance sheet, facilitate its return to a growth strategy focused on developing and opening new gym sites when the right opportunities arise and provide a cash buffer in the event local or national lockdown measures are reimposed in connection with government COVID-management strategies. In connection with the financing of the Acquisition and the Offering, the Issuer entered into the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, increasing the total available borrowings under the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility from £95.0 million to £145.0 million (the “RCF upsize”) and, in aggregate, increasing our total liquidity to £296.6 million as at June 30, 2020, on a pro forma basis for the Equity Injection and the RCF upsize (exclusive of fees). For the duration of the Waiver Period, the Issuer is required to ensure that on each Liquidity Test Date, the Available Liquidity (as defined in the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) (calculated as at the relevant Liquidity Test Date and as set out in a liquidity compliance certificate to be delivered by the Issuer to the RCF Agent within five business days after the Liquidity Test Date) is not less than £30,000,000. In accordance with the terms of the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, the financial covenant does not apply during the Waiver Period and shall only begin to apply from either (i) the quarter ending on 31 December 2022 (if the Waiver Period ends on September 30, 2022) or (ii) the first quarter date to occur after the date on which the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility is reduced to no more than £95,000,000 (if the Waiver Period expires prior to September 30, 2022). For the duration of the Wavier Period, the making of restricted payments pursuant to the certain baskets is restricted and the incurrence of indebtedness and the making of permitted investment pursuant to certain baskets is limited to £40 million in aggregate principal amount, respectively. The terms of the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility are described further under “Description of Certain _Financing Arrangements—Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility Agreement”._ In order to enable the business to borrow up to the full amount of the total commitments available under the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility on an as needed basis, the Issuer launched a consent solicitation on September 10, 2020 with respect to the Existing Notes (the “Consent Solicitation”), which was made solely on the terms and subject to the conditions set forth in the consent solicitation statement in respect of the Existing Notes dated as of September 10, 2020. The requisite consents were received and the Consent Solicitation was completed on September 17, 2020. The supplemental indenture to the Existing Indenture in regards to the Consent Solicitation was executed, and the amendments became effective and operative, on September 17, 2020. The consummation of the Acquisition, refinancing of Fitness World’s existing indebtedness, incurrence of indebtedness under the Bridge Facility, entry into the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, the Offering and the application of the use of proceeds as set out in the section “Use of Proceeds” are collectively herein referred to as the “Transactions”.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: As of the Issue Date, LGP, together with minority co-investors, holds approximately 79% of the issued ordinary shares of Pinnacle Topco Limited, our ultimate parent. Management holds approximately 21% of the ordinary issued shares of Pinnacle Topco Limited, with certain of such management shareholders able to vote up to 20% of the ordinary shares. The Equity Injection brings LGP's total cash equity investment in our business to £381 million. Leonard Green & Partners, L.P. is a leading private equity firm, which since its inception has invested in over 90 companies with an aggregate value of over $165 billion. Founded in 1989 and based in Los Angeles, U.S.A., Leonard Green & Partners, L.P. invests in market leading companies across a range of industries. Leonard Green & Partners, L.P. seeks to back companies that are leaders in their respective industries, have robust growth potential and are led by exceptional management teams. 12 ----- Since its inception, Leonard Green & Partners, L.P. has raised more than $40 billion of committed capital across its eight funds, with consistently strong returns over its 30-year history. Other current and prior Leonard Green & Partners, L.P. investments include Equinox, SoulCycle, Life Time Fitness, Shake Shack, Whole Foods, BJ’s Wholesale Club, Troon Golf, Mister Car Wash and Activision Blizzard.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: The Combined Group has over 500 sites across the UK, Denmark, Switzerland and Poland, (517 sites as of November 9, 2020, consisting of 253 open sites, 236 closed sites in England, six closed sites in Denmark, three closed sites in Switzerland and 19 closed sites in Poland due to COVID-19 restrictions). Overall, as of November 9, 2020, 253 (49%) of our sites were open: - **UK: All 236 of our sites in England are currently shut down as a result of the national lockdown that went into effect on November 5, 2020. Our 38 sites across Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland remain open, with the sites in Wales having been closed for two weeks until November 9, 2020, due to the Welsh “firebreak” lockdown. More broadly, PureGym continues to collate and share evidence with national, regional and local authorities that indicates that gyms are relatively low-risk environments and make a strong positive contribution to public health. - **Denmark: 179 out of 185 Fitness World gyms remain open. On October 23, 2020, the Danish government announced new COVID-19 restrictions which have an impact on the operation of gyms such as Fitness World, including for example restrictions on group exercise classes of more than 10 people and requirement to wear a face mask when entering, exiting or staying in a gyms lounge, although not while exercising). These changes may have an impact on member satisfaction and member numbers. In addition, on November 5, 13 ----- 2020, the Danish government announced a number of COVID-19 related restrictions and measures in the area of Northern Jutland following the discovery of a mutated coronavirus referred to as “Cluster 5”, which is believed to spread from minks to humans. Consequently, the Northern Jutland region has been placed on partial lockdown and Fitness World has closed six gyms in the area as a result of the restrictions. The partial lockdown is currently in effect until December 3, 2020, however, there is a risk that it could be extended or that further regional lockdowns, closures or restrictions could be imposed. The Danish government continues to focus on local and sector specific containment measures. The management team continue to monitor the situation carefully and are ready to react to regulatory changes. - **Switzerland: 36 out of 39 of our gyms in Switzerland remain open; viral infection rates are on par with the UK and we were informed on October 23, 2020 that one canton (Bern) would be instituting a local lockdown which required closure of three gyms. Management will continue to monitor the situation carefully across Switzerland. - **Poland: our 19 gyms in Poland were closed on October 17, 2020 as part of a range of measures instituted by the national government to stem rising virus rates.
