Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Initial lockdown start date** **Initial lockdown end date UK ............................................
Subsubsection Text: Despite an extended closure period due to the initial mandated government lockdown measures in the countries in which we operate, our business returned to profitability in the initial reopening that took place in August and September 2020 following the reopening of our UK estate, with gyms in both Switzerland and Denmark returning to profitability in the month of their reopening following the initial lockdown period. The charts below show the resilience of our business model as evidenced by our rapid return to profitability in August and September following initial lockdown period in the countries in which we operate. While the trend observed in August and September 2020 demonstrated our resilience at that point in time, there can be no assurance that our recovery following subsequent lockdowns would be comparably robust. Member feedback on our first reopening was positive and translated to positive member trends in like-forlike member volumes as well as gym visits, particularly among the younger member demographic which displayed a greater propensity to return to the gym. This initial membership trend continued in the UK, where our median member age is below that of our gyms in Denmark and Switzerland: the UK business has the youngest demographic mix in the group (median member age is 28 in the UK, 30 in Denmark and 31 in Switzerland). As at October 18, 2020, we had approximately 1.6 million closing members across the Combined Group, which represents like-for-like members versus membership levels at the same point in 2019 of 80% in the UK, 90% in Denmark and 93% in Switzerland and there have been no confirmed reports of COVID-19 transmission in our gyms reported after more than 26 million visits since reopening. Member visits in the UK increased to 86% in late October, as compared to the same point in 2019. In August 2020, like-for-like average revenue per member was higher than August 2019, with an increase of 3% in the UK and 7% in Denmark. Our gyms across the UK were closed for a longer period than our gyms in Europe and therefore experienced more leavers during the initial lockdown period. However, as at October 26, 2020, substantially all of our 236 gyms in England had been open for approximately 13 weeks and our 25 gyms in Scotland had open for approximately seven weeks. Membership levels in the UK reached 80% as of late October 2020 as compared to the same point in 2019. Our cleaning protocols were a major factor driving increasing membership levels during the initial reopening phase. The Combined Group’s operating protocols have been centred on enhanced safety measures in adherence with government health and safety guidelines. These safety protocols include extensive training for employees and members, which is comprised of greater visibility of the new rules through our website, social media, mobile app, and on the gym floor at point-of-sale and video screens. For example, in the UK, we have developed an extensive, multistage approach to ensuring sufficient club capacity in line with social distancing measures, including a two-meter distance rule across the gym floor and locker room, implementing 15 minute access windows for slot booking, allowing “over booking” to optimize capacity usage, disabling every other cardio machine in order to maintain separation, 50% maximum capacity for our group exercise classes, reducing free weight equipment and clearly delineating floor spacers to create two-meter workout stations. For example, during the week of September 7 to 17 ----- September 13, 2020, 12.9% of our UK gyms reached 90% of capacity for at least one hour. We use our advanced technology platform to provide “live” feeds of current attendance to enable members to choose when to visit the gym and to ensure controlled entry: for example, between August 31, 2020 and September 6, 2020, 38% of entrants entered using a QR code. Our cleaning protocols have also been upgraded to allow for three levels of cleaning, including the cleaning of high touch points every three hours, an overnight deep clean of all facilities by our contract partners, and encouragement for members to clean kit before and after their gym session. We also provide anti-viral wipe stations around the gym and personal protective equipment for all of our staff. Our safety protocols are backed by enforcement policies in order to ensure that members are complying with the measures we have implemented. If members repeatedly fail to comply with the new policies, their membership will be terminated. Across Denmark, Switzerland and Poland, similar COVID-responsive protocols have been adopted to ensure that our facilities are in line with or ahead of the minimum requirements within each of those geographies. In addition to our safety protocols, the geographic diversity of our gym estate and our dynamic pricing model were distinctive features that set us apart from our competitors during the initial reopening phase. In the UK, although we operate gyms in centrally-located, worker-centric locations throughout major cities in the countries in which we operate, we are not heavily reliant on these locations in isolation in order to earn a significant percentage of our revenue with only 16% of our gyms constituting worker-centric gyms and on average 26% to 37% of the members of these worker-centric gym members having multi-club access to our other gym locations as at February 2020, giving us extensive reach in residential areas outside of city limits and helping to counteract the effects of individuals working from home. Of the 274 total gyms we operated in the UK as at November 8, 2020, 209 are not located in the city centre. Of these 274 gyms, 65 are in city centre locations, 45 are in worker-centric locations, and 20 are in residential areas in London and thus removed from worker-centric locations. Members with gym memberships to our workercentric locations also enjoy multi-club access, with an average of 37% of our members who work in London opting for a premium membership option that allows them the benefit of also accessing a residential gym location if desired. The chart below shows the breakdown of multi-gym access memberships for our UK members as of February 2020. In addition to geographic diversity, in the UK, our “live” feed technology allows members to monitor how busy each gym is and has the added benefit of allowing us to manage capacity in accordance with government guidelines while also encouraging gym attendance throughout the day and outside peak periods. Gym capacity during the initial reopening phase was less restricted than previously by traditional working day constraints and was instead characterized by steady attendance throughout the day rather than in peak periods in the morning and in the evening. In the UK in particular, we also have the ability to drive members to our other gym locations by offering more competitive price points if one of our gyms is particularly busy. In the event of an outbreak in any of our open gyms across Europe, we are equipped to provide contact details through our controlled membership entry in order to enable test and trace procedures to be properly implemented and will increase our cleaning capacities in proportion to what 18 ----- is deemed necessary to prevent future outbreaks. We remain committed to acting in accordance with the guidance provided by the relevant authorities in the countries in which we operate.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Initial lockdown start date** **Initial lockdown end date UK ............................................
Subsubsection Title: Subsequent lockdown period and additional coronavirus restrictions
Subsubsection Text: On October 31, 2020, the UK Prime Minister announced a second national lockdown across England, which came into effect on November 5, 2020, and required the temporary re-closure of all of our gyms until at least December 2, 2020, subject to government review (the “second lockdown period”). Consistent with our approach during the initial lockdown period, we have placed members on “free freeze” and as a result all our revenues from our sites in England have ceased. On November 5, 2020, the Danish government announced a number of COVID-19 related restrictions and measures in the area of Northern Jutland, (comprising the seven Danish municipalities of Hjørring, Frederikshavn, Brønderslev, Jammerbugt, Thisted, Vesthimmerland and Læsø) following the discovery of a mutated coronavirus referred to as “Cluster 5”, which is believed to spread from minks to humans. The restrictions were enacted following the detection of the virus traced to the region’s mink farms. Consequently, the Northern Jutland region has been placed on a partial lockdown and Fitness World has closed six gyms in the area as a result of the restrictions. The partial lockdown is currently in effect until December 3, 2020, subject to government review. On October 29, 2020, the Swiss government enacted a number of heightened coronavirus restrictions as a result of increasing daily number of coronavirus cases across Switzerland. The new restrictions include a duty to wear masks in all enclosed public spaces and in other busy public spaces, a ban on public events with more than 50 attendees as well as a ban on sports and cultural activities involving more than 15 people, partial lockdowns in specific areas of the country, reduced travel, and the suspension of night bus and train routes. As a result of the new restrictions, we have closed three of our sites in Switzerland. In order to mitigate against the effects of the coronavirus restrictions in the countries in which we operate, we have again acted swiftly to implement a cash preservation strategy, significantly reducing cash outflows from the business to maximize our liquidity position. We estimate that our UK weekly operational cash burn will be £1.9 million per week during the four week closure of our sites in England based on £1.0 million per week in government support through the rates holiday and the furlough scheme, £0.7 million per week in revenue from our gyms that are currently still open in Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, and £0.4 million per week in operational cost savings. We estimate that our total UK cash burn due to the four week closure in England will be £6.0 million to £9.0 million before factoring in rent negotiations with landlords or any deferment activity. As a result, we estimate the net impact on Group cash and liquidity of the England lockdown in November and December 2020 will be £5.0 million to £10.0 million, after taking into account cash flows from our operations in Denmark and Switzerland.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Initial lockdown start date** **Initial lockdown end date UK ............................................
Subsubsection Text: While we are cognizant that the risks presented to our business by COVID-19 may continue beyond the second lockdown period, our management team has proven that it can guide the business through an unprecedented set of circumstances in which the business generates zero revenue by quickly implementing a cash preservation strategy. We believe we are ready to act in accordance with a cash preservation strategy by (i) pausing growth, maintenance and refurbishment capital expenditures, (ii) reducing operational costs, (iii) deferring payments to landlords and suppliers to the extent permissible and (iv) utilizing the government support that is available to our business. Following the Equity Injection and the RCF upsize, we believe that our business has ample financial reserves to absorb the impact of the second lockdown period. We believe that our budget model is well-positioned to weather further waves of COVID-19 and future mandated government lockdown measures through the end of this year and to mid-2021, as well as the consequent downturn in economic conditions due to our management team’s ability to effectively implement a cash preservation strategy in conjunction with our liquidity reserves following the Equity Injection and RCF upsize. When our gym estate in England is permitted to reopen, we also believe that we are well-positioned to contend with consumer dynamics in a possible economic downturn given our value gym pricing proposition. Pure Gym was founded in a recessionary environment and grew rapidly during difficult economic times because consumers turned to value 19 ----- offerings rather than premium gym brands (see “Industry Overview”). According to OC&C, client trends have indicated that gym membership is a form of “low-cost entertainment” and is habitual in terms of usage patterns, which enables clients to not only _seek value gym offerings but also_ _retain them during a recessionary environment, particularly as a form of stress management. Based on the experience we have in managing our business in prior economic downturns, we anticipate that in the event of an economic downturn, traditional operators will abstain from investing in their gym sites and default to raising prices, both of which are factors we believe will drive clients to our gyms. In the period between the initial reopening and the commencement of the second lockdown period, we managed multiple local lockdowns that impacted our gym estate. For ten weeks between June 29, 2020 and September 8, 2020, Leicester (a two-gym city cluster) was put into local lockdown. The actual cost to us for this lockdown period was approximately £398,000 (an average of £83,000 per club per month). Beginning on October 14, 2020, Liverpool (a seven-gym city cluster) was put into local lockdown and gyms closed for the ten days between October 14, 2020 and October 24, 2020. The actual cost to us for this lockdown period was approximately £190,000 (an average of £84,000 per club per month). We have a strategy to deal with the second lockdown period by leveraging our experience with the initial lockdowns. This strategy consists of pausing our capital expenditure, implementing operational cost reductions, deferring payments to landlords and suppliers where possible and effectively utilizing support from the relevant governments to the extent available (noting that the UK business rates holiday is ongoing through the 2020/2021 tax year and the UK furlough scheme has been extended through to March 2021). However, we can provide no assurance that government support will be offered at equivalent levels to those during the initial lockdowns or at all in the event of further lockdowns. Were government support to not be available, or to be available on a more limited basis, we would only be able to rely on our ability to pause capital expenditures, implement cost reductions and defer payments, which could significantly reduce our overall ability to mitigate cash burn. In addition to comprehensive contingency planning and financial modelling for further waves of COVID-19 and future mandated government lockdown measures through the end of this year and to mid-2021, we are continuing to build on our strong technological platform by investing in at-home and digital fitness given the surge in home workout demand during COVID-19. The Fitness World app is already a staple of our business (see “Business— _Marketing—Fitness World”) and we are continuing to optimize the Pure Gym app in order to provide our customers_ with at-home workout options. For example, as of September 11, 2020, there were 1.15 million total “on phone” downloads by 420,000 non-members and 730,000 members, demonstrating that 70% of the Pure Gym membership base used the Pure Gym app. Demand for the app has remained healthy, with approximately 150,000 at-home workouts being conducted on the app from July 20, 2020 to August 16, 2020, for example. “At-home workouts” correlate to each time a user starts playback on a workout video. We have also experienced an increase in app downloads, with approximately 140,000 new users during the same period. We expect that at home and digital fitness will continue to be a complementary opportunity for us and we plan to continue investing accordingly. _Future expansion opportunities_ Prior to the initial and second lockdown periods in the countries in which we operate, we had a robust growth strategy in place with respect to both organic site development in the UK and opportunities abroad. We continue to have a range of expansion opportunities, including at our test sites in the U.S. and across Switzerland, as well as further opportunities to expand our gym estate in our key markets and enter into international franchise agreements. Our expansion pipeline remains strong, with 151 sites in the organic site development pipeline for our gyms in the UK. Of these 151 sites, 61 sites have been approved by the Board and 90 are in the first stage of capital expenditure committee approval. For four of our recently opened UK gyms, member levels tracked our average target member feasibility levels within weeks of reopening, indicating a positive upward trend. However, before pursuing further expansion or franchising opportunities, we plan to monitor the property market and expect to manage our commitments prudently to ensure we maintain adequate operational liquidity with respect to our current and future expansion projects.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Initial lockdown start date** **Initial lockdown end date UK ............................................
Subsubsection Text: England .................................** March 21, 2020 July 25, 2020 Scotland ................................** March 21, 2020 August 31, 2020 Wales .....................................** March 21, 2020 August 10, 2020 Northern Ireland..................** March 21, 2020 July 10, 2020 Denmark ..................................** March 12, 2020 June 11, 2020 Switzerland ..............................** March 16, 2020 May 11, 2020 Poland .......................................** March 16, 2020 June 6, 2020 At the time that initial lockdowns went into effect in each country in which we operate, our overall approach was to place members on “free freeze” and as a result almost all our revenues ceased. Some revenues were received during closure periods in Fitness World Denmark as a result of offers made to members and, in the UK, a small amount of revenue was secured from the PureGym Together product. However, in aggregate, almost all of our revenue effectively ceased until the phased initial reopening of our gyms began on May 11, 2020 in Switzerland, June 6, 2020 in Poland, June 11, 2020 in Denmark, and from July 10, 2020 in the UK. The duration of the initial lockdowns are described above. At the foundation of all business decisions we made in response to COVID-19 was our concern for, and attention to, the health, safety and well-being of our employees and members. In addition, we took every step that we believed was prudent to protect and manage the business, reduce our cost base and protect our liquidity. The Group had a strong year in 2019 and a robust start to 2020, both of which enabled us to enter the COVID-19 crisis from a position of financial strength; however, the spread of COVID-19 and the prolonged shutdown of our gym estate during the initial lockdown period had a material negative impact on our business. In order to mitigate against these negative effects, we acted swiftly to implement a cash preservation strategy, significantly reducing cash outflows from the business to maximize our liquidity position. Specifically, we adopted the following measures during the initial lockdown period in each of the countries in which we operate: - actively engaged with our landlords to seek deferrals and/or rent-free periods across the Combined Group while certain of our gyms remain closed; 14 ----- - cut marketing and advertisement spend to nearly zero in the initial lockdown period; - furloughed almost our entire workforce with members of senior management foregoing their salary for a period of three months and many other staff members taking significant voluntarily salary reductions; and - significantly reduced our planned capital expenditure program, which resulted in a reduced scope of work that was focused on concluding current projects, essential maintenance and infrastructure work in our current gym estate. We were also able to utilize government support effectively in order to significantly mitigate our average weekly cash burn rate. The government initiatives we utilized as mitigation measures across the Combined Group included: - the UK Job Retention Scheme, a salary compensation scheme in relation to the costs of furloughed staff, which is in effect until the end of March 2021; - UK tax deferrals in which VAT payments for the first quarter are deferred until March 2021 and PAYE and NIC payments for the second quarter were deferred to July 2020; - the UK business rates holiday for the 2020/2021 tax year; - the Danish salary compensation scheme relating to furloughed employees; - the Danish fixed cost compensation scheme; - Danish extensions of the payment deadlines for Danish “A-tax” and labour market contributions, as well as extensions of VAT payment deadlines; Fitness World's Danish entities have automatically benefitted from these extended payment deadlines; - Danish VAT loan scheme for small- and medium-sized businesses; and - the Swiss salary compensation scheme relating to furloughed employees. Prior to the initial lockdown period, net average cash outflow for the Combined Group was £9 million per week on an unmitigated basis, consisting of £8 million in operating cash cost and £1 million in interest cash cost per week. As a result of the cost-cutting strategies, cash-saving measures, revenue initiatives and access to government initiatives we took, the Combined Group’s liquidity declined by only £18 million throughout the 14-week initial lockdown closure period (£1.3 million per week on average) from March 23, 2020 to June 26, 2020. This primarily consisted of £11 million of payments in relation to capital expenditures (being projects completed prior to the initial lockdown period) and £7 million of interest payments that fell due during the period. The Combined Group therefore effectively reduced, deferred or offset all of its unmitigated £8 million weekly operating cash cost burden during this 14-week initial lockdown period. Of the £8 million unmitigated weekly operating cash cost, £4 million was saved through a combination of reducing operating costs, landlord forbearance and assistance received from governments (furlough monies, fixed overhead compensation and rates relief), £2.0 million (comprising £2.5 million of deferred payments net of £0.5 million of receipts) has been deferred into the second half of 2020 and £2 million has been offset through various revenue and other cash collection activities. An additional £15 million of deferrals are due to be settled in 2021. Additionally, we believe that we have ample liquidity to manage the second wave of coronavirus restrictions that are currently in force and expect payment deferrals to remain manageable through the end of 2020. Under our current modelling and in light of the current lockdowns in place in the countries in which we operate, we estimate that 15 ----- we will have £215 to £220 million of available liquidity as at December 31, 2020. In the event of further simultaneous national lockdowns across the UK, Denmark and Switzerland, assuming the business were able to mitigate 50% of its weekly cash burn rate of £9.0 million, then management estimates that the business could be sustained for approximately 12 months. For more information about the risks associated with the impact of subsequent waves of COVID-19 and lockdowns on our ability to minimize cash burn, see “Risk Factors—The negative impact of COVID_19 on our business is significant and its effects will continue to materially negatively impact our business, financial _condition and results of operations due to many factors, some of which are beyond our control”. The chart below_ compares our pro forma liquidity as of June 30, 2020 and August 28, 2020 and our actual liquidity as of October 31, 2020 with our projected liquidity post-deferred payments as of December 31, 2020. The projections included below are based on estimates and assumptions made as of early November 2020, which assume that the second lockdown period in England will last four weeks and assumes that growth capex, exceptional items and settlement of deferred payments will amount to the figures presented below, which are based on management estimates. 16 -----

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: As at June 30, 2020 on a pro forma basis for the Equity Injection and the RCF upsize (exclusive of fees), we had available liquidity of £296.6 million, consisting of £188.6 million in cash and cash equivalents on a pro forma 20 ----- basis for the Equity Injection and the RCF upsize (exclusive of fees), which includes £37.0 million in drawings under the Revolving Credit Facility, and had £98.0 million in undrawn Revolving Credit Facility commitments available for drawing by way of certain ancillary facilities, as well as £10.0 million in undrawn overdraft facilities and letters of credit that are typically utilized from time to time in the ordinary course of business. As of October 31, 2020, we had available liquidity of approximately £266 million, consisting of approximately £121 million in cash and approximately £145 million in undrawn Revolving Credit Facility commitments available for drawing by way of certain ancillary facilities as well as undrawn overdraft facilities and letters of credit that are typically utilized from time to time in the ordinary course of business. We are currently complying with and expect to be able to continue to comply with the covenants contained within our debt facilities and are monitoring these on a regular basis. We are in regular contact with the governments in our key markets to keep abreast of the availability of and our eligibility for government support. Our shareholders remain highly supportive of our business and optimistic about its long-term prospects, as shown by the Equity Injection. Between the end of the initial lockdown period and the commencement of the second lockdown period, we were recovering well. For example, during the initial lockdown period, our gyms across the UK were closed for a longer period than our gyms in Europe and therefore experienced more leavers during the lockdown period. However, as of the end of October 2020, when substantially all of our 236 gyms in England had been open for approximately 13 weeks and our 25 gyms in Scotland had been open for approximately seven weeks, membership levels in the UK reached 80% as compared to the same point in 2019. In October 2020, we had estimated that, based on then-applicable conversion rates of frozen members into paying members, another 3% of members would convert, for an estimated 83% membership level in the UK. It is too soon to make any estimate of the magnitude of the impact of the second lockdown period on our business and we can provide no assurance that following the current lockdown or subsequent lockdowns our recovery would be comparably robust, but we believe our recovery in October 2020 demonstrates the resilience of our business model and reflects on our response to the virus being well-received by our members.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: In light of the government-mandated closure of our Polish gyms, we have taken the strategic view that we will not be investing additional Group resources in our Polish business at this time. Consequently, we have decided to cease operating in Poland. Our Polish subsidiary has applied to the Polish courts to open an insolvency proceeding under Polish bankruptcy laws with the goal of appointing a trustee to oversee the orderly distribution of our Polish assets. For the year ended December 31, 2019, Fitness World generated revenue of DKK 46.9 million (£5.5 million) and Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of DKK 6.2 million (£0.7 million) from its operations in Poland, representing 1% of Fitness World's Total Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA. 21 -----

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: _This summary highlights certain information about us and the Offering described elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. This summary is not complete and does not contain all the information you should consider before investing in the Notes. The summary should be read in conjunction with, and is qualified in its entirety by, the more detailed information included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, including the Financial Information and related notes contained elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. You should read carefully the entire Offering Memorandum to understand our business, the nature and terms of the Notes and the tax and other considerations which are important to your decision to invest in the Notes, including, without limitation, the risks discussed under the caption “Risk Factors”. In response to COVID-19, governments globally (including within the markets in which we operate) have implemented strict social distancing measures with varying degrees of lockdowns and closures of non-essential businesses such as ours. The COVID-19 pandemic presents an unprecedented disruption to our business, and the wide variations in potential outcomes present a material challenge to our business and our industry. We took action early in response to the COVID-19 crisis and we continue to take every step that we believe is prudent to protect and manage the business, reduce our cost base and protect our operating cash flows. See “—Recent Developments—Impact of COVID-19”. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, it is not possible to accurately predict the medium- or long- term impact of COVID-19 on our business and our industry._

(2) We define total number of members as the total number of active members, including the total number of members who have suspended (to “freeze” or have “frozen”) their memberships, but excluding “pay-as-you-go” customers, the total number of members who have cancelled their memberships and the total number of pre-opening members of organic gyms that have yet to open, as of the specified date or the end date of the relevant period. (4) We define Combined Group average revenue per member per month as the Combined Group Revenue for the period divided by the number of months in that period, further divided by the average number of members for the Combined Group in that period. The average number of members is calculated as of the beginning of the first month and the end of every month in that period. (5) This measure is not defined under IFRS. These financial measures should not be considered as alternatives to operating profit or profit for the financial period as indicators of our performance, or as alternatives to operating cash flows as a measure of our liquidity. Our management uses these measures to assess our operating performance. In addition, we believe that similar measures are commonly used by investors. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Data”. (6) We define “Combined Group EBITDA” as EBITDA of Pure Gym plus EBITDA of Fitness World. (7) We define “Combined Group Adjusted EBITDA” as Adjusted EBITDA of Pure Gym plus Adjusted EBITDA of Fitness World. Adjusted EBITDA is the profit or loss for a certain period before income tax expense, net finance cost, depreciation of property, plant and equipment and right of use assets, amortization of intangible fixed assets, impairment of property, plant and equipment, profit/loss on disposal of property, plant and equipment, profit/loss on lease modifications, exceptional administrative expenses, and other extraordinary items, after adding back Pre-Opening Costs, share based payment charges and the Cash Rent Adjustment. Subsubsection Text: 25 ----- (a) In the year ended December 31, 2019, exceptional administrative expenses were £6.2 million relating to exploration of acquisition and expansion opportunities, restructuring of certain operations in the existing business and post-acquisition integration costs of acquired businesses. In the six months ended June 30, 2020, exceptional administrative expenses consisted of £1.1 million of costs related to the transition and integration of Fitness World into the group, £0.9 million of costs related to restructuring of the existing business, and £0.7 million of costs related to the exploration of acquisition and expansion opportunities. (b) Refers to the net impact of various one-off items not included in “exceptional administrative expenses”. (c) Pre-Opening Costs represents the total of all gym site operating costs incurred during the pre-opening periods of gyms in that period. Pre-Opening Costs primarily consist of staff and marketing expenses. (d) Represents the deduction of the cash rent payable during the period which otherwise was not reflected in EBITDA (as reported on a post-IFRS 16 basis). Management believes that adjusting EBITDA to reflect cash rent is a better reflection of our actual earnings. (e) Head Office Costs for a given period are defined as all non-gym specific costs, other than depreciation and amortization, related to the operation of head office functions in that period. (f) Run-Rate Adjustment is an adjustment made to those gyms which are less than three years old at the end of the reporting period. These adjustments replace the Adjusted EBITDA earned by these sites in the last twelve month period with the projected Adjusted EBITDA for their third year of operation. Combined Group Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA therefore seeks to reflect the anticipated mature Adjusted EBITDA potential of those gyms which were trading at the end of the relevant period. Management forecasts EBITDA on a gym-specific basis and updates forecasts quarterly based on current and anticipated performance, taking into account seasonality and location-specific factors. See “Business—Key Strengths—High cash flow generative profile underpinned by exceptional profitability and positive working _capital cash inflows”._ We believe that our gyms generate Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA at a substantially mature rate at month 24, therefore months 25 to 36 represent the first full year of mature EBITDA performance. We believe these run-rate adjustments are appropriate because, based on our experience and the actual performance of gyms open fewer than two years, the first two years of operation are unrepresentative of run-rate trading. Management has confidence in these gyms achieving their estimated run-rate profitability, given the consistent and predictable ramp-up delivered by the gym cohorts in previous years. These adjustments to EBITDA are presented for informational purposes only and do not purport to present what EBITDA would have been had newly opened gyms been open for the entire period nor does it purport to project EBITDA for any future period. The assumptions underlying the adjustments are based on our current estimates and they involve risks, uncertainties and other factors that may cause actual results or performance to be materially different from anticipated future results or performance expressed or implied by such adjustments. See “Risk Factors—Risks relating to our _business—Certain non-IFRS measures such as Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA incorporate forward-looking estimates that may differ from actual results”._ (g) Synergy adjustments for the year ended December 31, 2019 of £4.5 million (DKK 39.7 million converted to pounds sterling at the spot rate of DKK 8.7469 to £1.000 as of December 31, 2019) (composed of £1.9 million of overheads and procurement synergies, £0.8 million in IT cost optimization synergies and £1.8 million in estate optimization synergies) and for the six months ended June 30, 2020 of £4.9 million (DKK 39.7 million, as converted to GBP at the spot rate of DKK 8.1635 to £1.000 as of June 30, 2020) reflect specific identified cost savings for the Combined Group. (9) We define “Combined Group Adjusted EBITDA margin” as Combined Group Adjusted EBITDA divided by Combined Group Revenue for that period. (10) We define “Combined Group Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA” as Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA of Pure Gym plus Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA of Fitness World. Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA is Adjusted EBITDA for that period excluding Head Office Costs. (11) We define “Combined Group Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA margin” as Combined Group Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA divided by the Combined Group Revenue for that period. (12) We define “Combined Group Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA” as Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of Pure Gym plus Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of Fitness World plus synergy adjustments for the year ended December 31, 2019 of £4.5 million (DKK 39.7 million converted to pounds sterling at the spot rate of DKK 8.7469 to £1.000 as of December 31, 2019) and for the six months ended June 30, 2020 of £4.9 million (DKK 39.7 million, as converted to GBP at the spot rate of DKK 8.1635 to £1.000 as of June 30, 2020) to reflect specific identified cost savings for the Combined Group. Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA is Adjusted EBITDA including Run-Rate Adjustments. (13) We define “Combined Group Operating Cash Flow” as Operating Cash Flow of Pure Gym plus Operating Cash Flow of Fitness World. Operating Cash Flow is Adjusted EBITDA plus Working Capital Cash Flow and less Maintenance and Refurbishment Capital Expenditures for that period. Section Title: SUMMARY CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION FOR PURE GYM
Subsection Title: Gym”) for the year ended December 31, 2019, and are derived from the audited consolidated financial statements of
Subsubsection Text: the Topco Group and the Pure Gym as of and for each of the years ended December 31, 2017, 2018, and 2019, as applicable, included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. The unaudited historical financial information for the Issuer and its consolidated subsidiaries for the six months ended June 30, 2019 and June 30, 2020, has been derived from the Unaudited Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements. The results of operations for interim periods are not necessarily indicative of the results to be expected for the full year or any future period. The Issuer is a public limited company incorporated on October 30, 2017, for the purpose of consummating the 2017 Acquisition (as defined below) and the related financing thereof. The Issuer conducts no business operations of its own and as of the Issue Date its only material assets will be its holding of the entire issued share capital of the Combined Group as well as rights and claims under intercompany financings. The Issuer’s only material liabilities will be its outstanding indebtedness under the Existing Notes, the Notes and certain subordinated shareholder debt. For further information, please see “Summary—Corporate and Financing Structure”, “Business” and “Description of _Certain Financing Arrangements”._ The Issuer acquired Topco on November 30, 2017 (the “2017 Acquisition Date”) and the 2018 Pure Gym 14-Month Financial Statements (as defined below) encompass the 14-month period of trading from the 2017 Acquisition Date to December 31, 2018. As a result, the 2018 Pure Gym 14-Month Financial Statements are not directly comparable to the 2017 Topco Financial Statements or the 2019 Pure Gym Financial Statements (each as defined below), both of which were prepared on a 12-month basis. As a result, for the year ended December 31, 2018, this Offering Memorandum provides the 2018 Topco Financial Statements (as defined below) for comparative purposes rather than the 2018 Pure Gym 14-Month Financial Statements. The 2018 Pure Gym 14-Month Financial Statements have been included in the index to this Offering Memorandum for reference purposes only. With respect to the 2019 Pure Gym Financial Statements, Pure Gym applied the new IFRS 16 (Leases) accounting standard, effective from January 1, 2019 using the modified retrospective method, for transition and measuring right of use assets using the retrospective calculation, both as defined by the IFRS 16 accounting standard. Cumulative effects of applying this new accounting standard were therefore recognized as an adjustment to retained earnings as of January 1, 2019 (the date of initial application), while comparative figures were not restated. The 2017 Topco Financial Statements and the 2018 Topco Financial Statements have not been restated for the adoption of IFRS 16. IFRS 16 eliminates the classification of leases as either operating leases or finance leases and introduces a single lessee accounting model with some exemptions for short-term and low-value leases. The lessee recognizes a right-ofuse asset representing its right to use the underlying asset and a lease liability representing its obligation to make lease payments. The effect of applying IFRS 16 is to align the presentation of leases more closely to that of owned assets, rent expense is no longer deducted in arriving at operating profit or Pure Gym EBITDA and instead profit before tax includes an interest charge on the unwinding of the finance lease liability and a depreciation charge on the right of use asset. See Note 27 “Change in Accounting Policies” of the 2019 Pure Gym Financial Statements. Results of operations for prior periods or years are not necessarily indicative of the result to be expected for any future period. Prospective investors should bear in mind that the performance indicators and ratios that we report herein, such as Pure Gym Adjusted EBITDA, Pure Gym Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA, and Pure Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA and certain other measures (each as defined in this Offering Memorandum), are not financial measures defined in accordance with IFRS and, as such, may be calculated by other companies using different methodologies and having different results. Therefore, these performance indicators and ratios are not directly comparable to similar figures and ratios reported by other companies. The following summary financial information should be read together with the sections “Presentation of _Financial and Other Data”, “Selected Consolidated Financial and Other Information of Pure Gym”, “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations of Pure Gym”, “Capitalization”, the_ Financial Statements and related notes, and the additional financial information contained elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. 28 -----

Subsubsection Text: Total number of gyms ......................................... 192 222 263 238 505 Total number of Mature Gyms[(1)] ......................... 132 170 192 n/a n/a Total number of members[(2) ](‘000s) ................... 927 1,012 1,135 1,128 1,697 Average number of members per gym[(3)] ............ 5,070 4,994 4,710 4,816 3,528 Average Revenue per Member per Month[(4)](£) ................................................... 18.00 18.51 18.90 18.79 11.20 EBITDA[(5)(6)](£ millions) .................................... 64.4 75.6 125.2 62.7 36.5 Adjusted EBITDA[(5)(7)(8)] (£ millions) ................. 71.5 81.5 89.1 44.9 (0.3) Adjusted EBITDA margin[(5)(9)] ........................... 36.1% 35.7% 34.9% 35.7% (0.3%) Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA[(5)(8)(10)] (£ millions) ......................................................... 88.4 102.4 113.0 56.4 17.3 Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA margin[(5)(11)] ........... 44.6% 44.8% 44.3% 44.8% 15.5% LTM Combined Group Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA[(5)(8)(12)] (£ millions) ......................................................... 84.8 95.2 104.5 97.8 101.4 Operating Cash Flow[(5)(13)(14) ](£ millions) ........... 67.4 83.7 77.8 35.9 6.6 Operating Cash Flow Conversion[(5)(14)] ............... 94% 103% 87% 80% n/a (1) We define “Mature gyms” as the gyms that have been open for 24 months or more as of the end of the relevant reporting period. (2) We define total number of members as the total number of active members, including the total number of members who have suspended (to “freeze” or have “frozen”) their memberships, but excluding “pay-as-you-go” customers, the total number of members who have cancelled their memberships and the total number of pre-opening members of organic gyms that have yet to open, as of the specified date or the end date of the relevant period. (3) We define average number of members per gym as the average of the number of members for each gym as of the beginning of the first month and the end of every month in that period. (4) We define average revenue per member per month as revenue for that period divided by the number of months in that period and further divided by the average number of members during that period. The average number of members during that period is calculated as the average of the number of members as of the beginning of the first month and the end of every month in that period. 30 ----- 31 ----- (c) Pre-Opening Costs represents the total of all gym site operating costs incurred during the pre-opening periods of gyms in that period. Pre-Opening Costs primarily consist of staff, marketing and also rent expenses when reporting under IAS17. (d) From January 1, 2019, as the deduction of the cash rent payable during the period which otherwise was not reflected in EBITDA (as reported on a post-IFRS 16 basis). Pre January 1, 2019, under IAS17, the total rent payable over the life of the lease is spread over the lease term and charged to the income statement on a straight line basis in arriving at EBITDA. As we typically receive a rent free period of a year or more as an incentive from developers or landlords to lease space in their buildings this results in rent charged to EBITDA being greater than the cash outlay in the early years of the lease term and less than the cash outlay in the later years of the lease term. The Cash Rent Adjustment adds back any non-cash element of the rent expensed in the period during these early years (less any amounts already added back as a Pre-Opening Cost) and deducts any shortfall in rent expense in the later years to reflect the actual cash outlay due for that period under our lease arrangements. Management believes that adjusting EBITDA to reflect cash rent is a better reflection of our actual earnings. (e) Head Office Costs for a given period are defined as all non-gym specific costs, other than depreciation and amortization, related to the operation of head office functions in that period. (f) Run-Rate Adjustment is an adjustment made to those gyms which are less than three years old at the end of the reporting period. These adjustments replace the Adjusted EBITDA earned by these sites in the last twelve month period with the projected Adjusted EBITDA for their third year of operation. Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA therefore seeks to reflect the anticipated mature Adjusted EBITDA potential of those gyms which were trading at the end of the relevant period. Management forecasts EBITDA on a gym-specific basis and updates forecasts quarterly based on current and anticipated performance, taking into account seasonality and location-specific factors. See “Business—Key Strengths—High cash flow generative profile underpinned by exceptional profitability and positive working _capital cash inflows”._ We believe that our gyms generate Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA at a mature rate at month 24, therefore months 25 to 36 represent the first full year of mature EBITDA performance. We believe these run-rate adjustments are appropriate because, based on our experience and the actual performance of gyms open fewer than two years, the first two years of operation are unrepresentative of run-rate trading. Management has confidence in these gyms achieving their estimated run-rate profitability, given the consistent and predictable rampup delivered by the gym cohorts in previous years. These adjustments to EBITDA are presented for informational purposes only and do not purport to present what EBITDA would have been had newly opened gyms been open for the entire period nor does it purport to project EBITDA for any future period. The assumptions underlying the adjustments are based on our current estimates and they involve risks, uncertainties and other factors that may cause actual results or performance to be materially different from anticipated future results or performance expressed or implied by such adjustments. See “Risk Factors—Risks relating to our business—Certain non-IFRS _measures such as Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA incorporate forward-looking estimates that may differ from actual results”._ (g) Synergy adjustments for the six months ended June 30, 2020 of £4.9 million (DKK 39.7 million, as converted to GBP at the spot rate of DKK 8.1635 to £1.000 as of June 30, 2020) reflect specific identified cost savings for the Combined Group. (h) Financial information for the years ended December 31, 2017 and December 31, 2018 has not been re-stated for the adoption of IFRS 16, which came into effect on January 1, 2019. (11) We define “Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA margin” as Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA divided by revenue for that period. Management holds approximately 21% of the ordinary issued shares of Pinnacle Topco Limited, and certain management shareholders are able to vote up to 20% of the ordinary shares. See “Principal Shareholders”. (2) In connection with the 2017 Acquisition, the Issuer incurred £281.0 million in subordinated shareholder indebtedness in the form of loan notes and an intercompany loan from Pinnacle Midco 2 Limited, each of which are subordinated to the interests of the holders of the Notes under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement and on September 18, 2020, Pinnacle Midco 2 Limited granted a subordinated shareholder loan to Pinnacle Bidco plc in connection with the £100.0 million Equity Injection. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements— _Intercreditor Agreement” and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Subordinated Shareholder Funding”._ (3) The entities in the Restricted Group will be subject to the covenants in the Indenture. See “Description of the Notes”. (4) In connection with the financing of the Acquisition and the Offering, the Issuer amended and restated its Original Revolving Credit Facility Agreement providing for the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility. The terms of the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility are described further under “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility _Agreement”. On November 28, 2017, the Issuer, the facility agent and security agent under the Original Revolving Credit Facility Agreement,_ and the Issuer’s parent company (“Holdco”) entered into the Intercreditor Agreement, and the Trustee and the Fitness World Guarantors are expected to accede to the Intercreditor Agreement on or about the Issue Date. (5) The Notes will be the Issuer’s senior obligations and will rank _pari passu_ in right of payment with all the Issuer’s existing and future obligations that are not expressly subordinated to the Notes. The Notes will be guaranteed on a senior basis (collectively, the “Guarantees”) by the Guarantors on the Issue Date. Each of the Guarantors will, on or about the Issue Date, guarantee on a senior basis any borrowings under the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, the Notes and the Existing Notes. The Guarantees will be subject to certain contractual and legal limitations under applicable laws, which may substantially limit the value of the Guarantees, and may be further subject to certain defences that may limit their validity and enforceability. Further, the Guarantees may be released under certain circumstances. See “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Security Interests and Certain Insolvency Law _Considerations” and “Description of the Notes—Guarantees—Release of Guarantee”. On or about the Issue Date, the Notes and the_ Guarantees will be secured by first-priority security interests in the collateral described under “Description of the Notes—Security”. The Existing Notes and the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility will be secured by the same Collateral as the Notes. Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, in the event of an enforcement action and certain distressed disposals, any liabilities in respect of obligations under the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility will receive priority over the Notes in relation to any proceeds received from the Collateral. 40 -----

Section Title: SUMMARY CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION FOR FITNESS WORLD
Subsubsection Text: The following financial information is the historical consolidated financial information of Forward TopCo A/S, a public limited liability company (Aktieselskab) incorporated under the laws of Denmark (together with its subsidiaries, “Fitness World”). Forward TopCo A/S was established on March 30, 2015. The financial information contained in the following tables comprising summary of consolidated information is derived from the audited consolidated financial statements of Fitness World as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019 with comparative figures as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018, included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. Other financial and operational data for Fitness World is derived from Fitness World’s internal reporting systems. Fitness World consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019 with comparative figures as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018 have been prepared in accordance with IFRS as adopted by the European Union. The consolidated financial statements have been audited by EY Godkendt Revisionspartnerselskab. See “Independent Auditors” and “Risk Factors—Risks relating to the Notes, the Guarantees _and the Collateral—Investors in the Notes may have limited or no recourse against the independent auditors” for a_ description of the independent auditors’ reports of EY Godkendt Revisionspartnerselskab. With respect to the 2019 Fitness World Financial Statements, Fitness World applied the new IFRS 16 (Leases) accounting standard, effective from January 1, 2019 using the “modified retrospective method”. Therefore, cumulative effects of applying this new accounting standard were recognized as an adjustment to retained earnings as of January 1, 2019 (the date of initial application), while comparative figures were not restated. IFRS 16 eliminates the classification of leases as either operating leases or finance leases and introduces a single lessee accounting model with some exemptions for short-term and low-value leases. The lessee recognizes a right-of-use asset representing its right to use the underlying asset and a lease liability representing its obligation to make lease payments. The effect of applying IFRS 16 was to align the presentation of leases more closely to that of owned assets, rent expense is no longer deducted in arriving at operating profit or Fitness World EBITDA and instead profit before tax includes an interest charge on the unwinding of the finance lease liability and a depreciation charge on the right of use asset. See Note 29 “Changes in accounting policies and disclosures” of the 2019 Fitness World Financial Statements. Results of operations for prior periods or years are not necessarily indicative of the result to be expected for any future period. Prospective investors should bear in mind that the performance indicators and ratios that we report herein, such as Adjusted EBITDA, Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA, and Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA and certain other measures (each as defined in this Offering Memorandum), are not financial measures defined in accordance with IFRS and, as such, may be calculated by other companies using different methodologies and having different results. Therefore, these performance indicators and ratios are not directly comparable to similar figures and ratios reported by other companies. The following summary financial information should be read together with the sections “Presentation of _Financial and Other Data”, “Selected Consolidated Financial Information of Fitness World”, “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations of Fitness World”, “Capitalization”, the_ Financial Statements and related notes, and the additional financial information contained elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. 33 -----

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsubsection Text: The following is a brief summary of certain terms of the Offering. It may not contain all the information that is important to you. For additional information regarding the Notes and the Guarantees, see “Description of the Notes”, and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement”. Issuer:** Pinnacle Bidco plc, a public limited company organized under the laws of England and Wales. Notes Offered:** €445.0 million aggregate principal amount of % Senior Secured Notes due 2025. Issue Date:** On or about, 2020. Issue Price:** % plus accrued interest, if any, from the Issue Date. Maturity Date:**, 2025. Interest Payment Dates:** Semi-annually in arrears on each and commencing on, 2021. Interest will accrue from the Issue Date. Interest:** % per annum. Denomination:** Each Note will have a minimum denomination of €100,000 and integral multiples of €1,000 in excess thereof, respectively. Ranking of the Notes:** The Notes will: - be general, senior obligations of the Issuer, secured as set forth below under “Description of the Notes—Security”; - rank _pari passu_ in right of payment with all existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that is not subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, including the Issuer’s obligations in respect of the Existing Notes, the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility and certain hedging obligations; - be effectively senior to all of the Issuer’s existing and future indebtedness that is unsecured, or secured on a basis junior to the security granted by the Issuer in respect of the Notes, in each case to the extent of the value of the Issuer’s property or assets securing the Notes; - rank senior in right of payment to all existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that is subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, including the Subordinated Shareholder Funding; - be effectively subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Notes, to the extent of the value of the property or assets securing such indebtedness; - be effectively junior to any existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that will receive proceeds from any enforcement action over and certain distressed disposal of the property and assets securing the Notes on a priority basis, including indebtedness under the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility and certain other future indebtedness; and - be structurally subordinated to any future and existing indebtedness of subsidiaries of the Issuer that are not Guarantors. Guarantees:** On or about the Issue Date, the Issuer’s obligations under the Notes will be guaranteed (collectively, the “Guarantees”) on a senior basis by Gym Topco Limited, Gym Midco Limited, Gym Midco 2 Limited, Gym Bidco Limited, Pure 41 ----- Gym Limited, Fitness World Group A/S, Fitness World A/S and Basefit.ch AG (the “Guarantors” and each a “Guarantor”). The Guarantees will be subject to certain contractual and legal limitations under applicable laws, which may substantially limit the value of the Guarantees, and may be further subject to certain defences that may limit their validity and enforceability. Further, the Guarantees may be released in certain circumstances. See “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the _Security Interests and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations”, “Description of the Notes—Guarantees” and “Risk Factors—Risks relating to the Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral”._ The Guarantors accounted for 99.2% of the Combined Group Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2019 and substantially all of the Combined Group consolidated total assets as of December 31, 2019. Ranking of the Guarantees:** Each Guarantee will: - be a general, senior obligation of the relevant Guarantor, secured on a first-priority basis as set forth below under “Description of the _Notes—Security”;_ - rank _pari passu_ in right of payment with all existing and future indebtedness of that Guarantor that is not subordinated in right of payment to such Guarantee, including obligations in respect of the Existing Notes, the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility and certain hedging obligations; - rank senior in right of payment to all existing and future indebtedness of that Guarantor that is subordinated in right of payment to such Guarantee; - be effectively senior to all of that Guarantor’s existing and future indebtedness that is unsecured, or secured on a basis junior to the security granted by such Guarantor in respect of its Guarantee, in each case to the extent of the value of such Guarantor’s property or assets securing its Guarantee; - be effectively subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness of that Guarantor that is secured by property or assets that do not secure such Guarantee on an equal basis, to the extent of the value of the property or assets securing such indebtedness; - be effectively junior to any existing and future indebtedness of such Guarantor that will receive proceeds from any enforcement action over and certain distressed disposal of the property and assets securing the Guarantee of such Guarantor on a priority basis, including indebtedness under the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility and certain other future indebtedness; and - be structurally subordinated to all existing or future Indebtedness of the Subsidiaries of such Guarantor that do not guarantee the Notes. The Guarantees will be subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement”. Security:** The Notes, the Existing Notes and the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility will be secured by a first-priority security interest in certain assets of the Issuer and the Guarantors as of the Issue Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, certain perfection requirements and any Permitted Collateral Liens (the “Collateral”). See “Description of the Notes—Security”. 42 ----- The Intercreditor Agreement provides that lenders under the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility and certain other indebtedness permitted to be secured by the Collateral will receive the proceeds from the enforcement of security over, and certain distressed disposals of, the Collateral in priority to holders of the Notes. See “Description of the Notes—Security” and “Description _of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement”._ The security interests securing the Notes and the Guarantees may be subject to certain contractual and legal limitations under applicable laws, which may substantially limit the value of the security interests, and may be further subject to certain defences that may limit their validity and enforceability. See “Risk _Factors—Risks relating to the Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral”._ The security interests securing the Notes and the Guarantees may be released under certain circumstances. See “Risk Factors—Risks relating to the Notes, the _Guarantees and the Collateral—There are circumstances other than repayment or discharge of the Notes under which the Collateral securing the Notes and the Guarantees will be released automatically without your consent or the consent of the Trustee”, “Description of the Notes—Security—Release of Liens” and_ “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement”. Additional Amounts:** Any payments made by or on behalf of the Issuer or any Guarantor with respect to the Notes will be made without withholding or deduction for or on account of Taxes in any Relevant Taxing Jurisdiction (as defined in the “Description of the _Notes”) unless required by law. If withholding or deduction for such Taxes is_ required to be made with respect to such a payment under the Notes, subject to certain exceptions, the Issuer or the relevant Guarantor will pay the additional amounts necessary so that the net amount received by the holders of the relevant Notes after the withholding or deduction is not less than the amount that they would have received in the absence of the withholding or deduction. See “Description of the Notes—Withholding Taxes”. Optional Redemption:** At any time prior to, 2022, the Issuer will be entitled at its option, on one or more occasions, to redeem all or a portion of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 100.0% of the principal amount of the Notes, plus a “make-whole” premium as of, and accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the redemption date, as described under “Description of the Notes—Optional _Redemption”._ At any time on or after, 2022, the Issuer will be entitled at its option, on one or more occasions, to redeem all or a portion of the Notes at the redemption prices set forth under the caption “Description of the Notes—Optional _Redemption”._ At any time prior to, 2022, the Issuer will be entitled at its option, on one or more occasions, to redeem the Notes in an aggregate principal amount not to exceed 40% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Notes (including any Additional Notes (as defined in “Description of the Notes”)) with the net cash proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price equal to        % of the principal amount of such Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption, so long as of least 50% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Notes (including any Additional Notes) remains outstanding immediately after each such redemption and each such redemption occurs no later than 180 days after the date of closing of the relevant equity offering. Prior to, 2022, the Issuer may, during each twelve-month period commencing with the Issue Date, redeem up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount 43 ----- of such Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the redemption date. See “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption”. Optional Redemption for Tax** In the event of certain changes affecting taxation in the law of any Relevant Reasons:** Taxing Jurisdiction that become effective after the issuance of the Notes, the Issuer may redeem the Notes in whole, but not in part, at any time, at a redemption price of 100.0% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption. See “Description of the _Notes—Redemption for Taxation Reasons”._ Change of Control:** Upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a “change of control,” the Issuer may be required to offer to repurchase the Notes at a purchase price in cash equal to 101% of the principal amount of such Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of purchase. See “Description _of the Notes—Repurchase at the Option of Holders—Change of Control”._ However, a change of control will not be deemed to have occurred if a specified consolidated net leverage ratio is not exceeded in connection with such event. Certain Covenants:** The Indenture will limit, among other things, our ability to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock of our restricted subsidiaries; - pay dividends or make other distributions or purchase or redeem our stock; - make investments or other restricted payments; - transfer or sell assets; - engage in certain transactions with affiliates; - create liens on assets to secure indebtedness; - impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders of the relevant series of Notes; and - merge or consolidate with other entities. Each of these covenants is subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants”. Transfer Restrictions:** The Notes and the Guarantees have not been, and will not be, registered under the U.S. Securities Act or the securities laws of any other jurisdiction. The Notes are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale and may only be offered or sold in transactions that are exempt from, or not subject to, the registration requirements of the U.S. Securities Act. We have not agreed to, or otherwise undertaken to, register the Notes (including by way of an exchange offer) under the U.S. Securities Act. See “Transfer Restrictions” and “Plan of Distribution”. Use of Proceeds:** We will use the net proceeds from the Offering to repay amounts drawn under the Bridge Facility in connection with the Acquisition and to pay transaction fees and expenses. See “Use of Proceeds” and “Certain Relationships and Related _Party Transactions—Certain Financing Arrangements”._ No Prior Market Listing:** The Notes will be new securities for which there is currently no established trading market. Although each of the relevant Initial Purchasers have advised us that they intend to make a market in the Notes, they are not obligated to do so and they may discontinue market-making at any time without notice. Accordingly, there is no assurance that an active trading market will develop for the Notes. Listing:** Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority Limited for the listing of and permission to deal in the Notes on the Official List of The 44 ----- International Stock Exchange in accordance with the rules and regulations of such exchange. Original Issue Discount:** The Notes may be issued with original issue discount (“OID”) for U.S. federal income tax purposes. The Notes will be considered to be issued with OID if the stated principal amount of the Notes exceeds the issue price of the Notes (as determined for U.S. federal income tax purposes) by an amount equal to or more than a statutorily defined de minimis amount. In such event, investors in the Notes subject to U.S. federal income taxation generally will be required to include OID in their gross income for U.S. federal income tax purposes as it accrues, in advance of the receipt of cash payments attributable to such income, using the constant yield method. See “Tax Considerations—Certain United States federal _income tax considerations”._

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: The negative impact of COVID-19 on our business is significant and its effects will continue to materially negatively impact our business, financial condition and results of operations due to many factors, some of which are beyond our control.
Subsubsection Text: In late 2019, a new strain of coronavirus was detected in Wuhan, China. In March 2020, the World Health Organization declared COVID-19 a global pandemic and governmental authorities around the world implemented measures to reduce the spread of COVID-19. These measures have adversely affected workforces, consumer sentiment, economies and financial markets, and, along with decreased consumer spending and widespread uncertainty following months of lockdowns, have led to an economic downturn in our markets and have had a direct impact on our business across all of the countries in which we operate. In March 2020, the governments of all of the countries in which we operate imposed significant lockdown measures in order to control the spread of COVID-19 and, in doing so, required the temporary closure of all of our gyms. When lockdowns occurred, our overall approach was to place members on “free freeze” and as a result almost all our revenues ceased. Some revenues were received during the initial lockdown period in Fitness World Denmark as a result of offers made to members and, in the UK, a small amount of revenue was secured from the PureGym Together product. However, in aggregate, almost all of our revenue effectively ceased until the phased reopening of our gyms following the initial lockdown period began on May 11, 2020 in Switzerland, June 6, 2020 in Poland, June 11, 2020 in Denmark and July 10, 2020 in the UK. Further, following the second wave that is currently underway in Europe, we cannot predict when or where these waves will occur, how far into the future such waves will continue to occur nor can we predict with any certainty the impacts of such subsequent waves, including the impacts of future national or local lockdowns or other measures implemented by the governments and/or local or regional authorities of the countries in which we operate. We also cannot guarantee that the markets in which we operate will ever return to the norms, lifestyle and gym attendance patterns that existed before the emergence of COVID-19, which would have a material adverse effect on our business. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, a second wave of COVID-19 is underway in Europe, with cases rising markedly in all of the geographies in which we operate. On October 12, 2020, the UK Prime Minister announced a three-tiered system of restrictions across England which came into effect on October 14, 2020. On October 14, 2020, Liverpool and a number of other cities in the Merseyside area (including Knowsley, Wirral, St. Helens, Sefton and Halton) (where we operated seven gyms as of October 26, 2020) were placed in Tier 3. Under the baseline for Tier 3 restrictions, gyms were not automatically closed in affected areas, but gyms could be closed in areas subject to Tier 3 restrictions under “additional measures” imposed by national or local government, which was the case in the Merseyside area. However, after ten days of closure and a media/lobbying campaign spearheaded by PureGym, seven gyms in the 46 ----- Merseyside area were reopened after gyms were removed from "additional measures" to Tier 3 restrictions. While gyms may remain open where Tier 1 and Tier 2 restrictions apply, there can be no guarantee that, in the event the tier system is re-implemented in the future, this would continue to be the case or that more stringent rules and restrictions would not be applied in the future in a manner that could materially adversely impact our business. Additionally, local authorities had the power to impose stricter rules and restrictions in addition to those imposed by the national three-tiered system, which may have further material adverse impacts on our business and industry. During the period in which the tier system was in place, many of our gyms were in areas that were in Tier 2 or Tier 3. Under the tier system, Tier 2 areas could rapidly become Tier 3 areas; likewise, Tier 1 areas could rapidly become Tier 2 (and even Tier 3) areas. The placement of areas into the tiers was outside of our control and was dynamic and unpredictable. The three-tiered alert system applied only to England: the devolved administrations in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland have the power to design and implement their own coronavirus restrictions, which may be as or more stringent than the English three-tiered system. We also cannot exclude the possibility of the addition of additional tiers or more stringent tier-based restrictions being imposed should the government deem the tiers insufficient to certain rising virus levels. The tier system was subsequently replaced by the second national lockdown that is described below. However, the tier system, or another set of comparable or more severe restrictions could be put in place in the future. On October 31, 2020, the UK Prime Minister announced a second national lockdown across England, which came into effect on November 5, 2020, and required the temporary re-closure of all of our English gyms until at least December 2, 2020, subject to government review. Consistent with our approach during the initial lockdown period, we have placed members on “free freeze” and, as a result, all our revenues have ceased from our sites in England. The imposition of future local and national lockdowns in response to the level of coronavirus case levels across Europe is outside of our control and is expected to be dynamic and unpredictable. Furthermore, the devolved administrations in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland are in charge of designing and implementing their own coronavirus restrictions, which may be as or more stringent than the lockdown measures imposed in England. In Denmark, the Northern Jutland region has been placed on partial lockdown and we have closed six of our gyms as a result of the lockdown. In Switzerland, we have closed three of our gyms as a result of local lockdown measures. In light of rising case levels across Europe, future national and local lockdowns are foreseeable in all of the countries in which we operate. Even when our gyms are allowed to safely open, social distancing and other policies implemented to slow the further spread of the disease may impact the operation and member appeal of our gyms. For example, members unaccustomed to waiting significant periods of time before using certain exercise equipment or to increased cleaning periods may cancel their memberships. In some locations, for example, in Switzerland, members may be required to wear masks or other protective equipment, which may deter members from attending our gyms and may cause them to cancel or suspend their memberships. Even when social distancing policies are lifted, interest in visiting our gyms may remain weak due to health concerns or changes in exercise preferences in favour of online or on-demand platforms. We cannot predict if and when each of our gyms will return to pre-outbreak membership levels or if they will be able to maintain pre-outbreak membership levels and pricing terms over the mid- to long-term. We also cannot predict whether member cancellation rates will increase in subsequent lockdown periods as compared to the initial lockdown period. Additionally, policies implemented to slow the further spread of the disease have impacted and will continue to impact our cost of doing business due to, among other things, the increased cost associated with hygiene measures and track and trace programs. Our business is sensitive to reductions in discretionary spending by consumers, public health events and other factors described in this “Risk Factors” section. To date, this outbreak has caused, and is continuing to cause, significant disruption in economic activity globally, which could lead to a decline in discretionary spending by our members. Our revenue may be negatively impacted by the adverse changes in the perceived or actual economic climate, including higher unemployment rates, declines in income levels and loss of personal wealth resulting from the impact of COVID-19. Our revenue may not increase in proportion to our fixed costs and deferred costs and our revenue may not be sufficient to offset the full impact of the shutdown of our gyms during the initial and second lockdown periods. If our cost base is higher than our revenue, our cash management policies may fail due to factors beyond our control.
