Section Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA COMBINED FINANCIAL INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: On January 14, 2020, Pinnacle Europe Holdings Limited, an indirect wholly owned subsidiary of the Issuer, acquired the entire issued share capital of Forward TopCo A/S for cash consideration of DKK 2,037.1 million (£232.9 million) plus repayment of Fitness World indebtedness of DKK 1,033.1 million (£118.1 million), (the “Fitness World Acquisition”). The unaudited pro forma combined financial information has been prepared to give effect to the Transactions. The unaudited pro forma combined financial information listed above is referred to as the “Unaudited

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsubsection Text: Pure Gym has a powerful and highly disruptive customer proposition that is differentiated from traditional gym operators and appeals to a broad range of consumers. The key elements of the proposition include affordable membership fees, no fixed term contracts and 24x7x365 access to high-quality gyms. The proposition is underpinned by the differentiated, capital efficient and technology-enabled gym operating model, which enables Pure Gyms to support high levels of membership, operate on low costs and generate strong unit economics, cash 94 ----- flow conversion and ROCE. As of December 31, 2019, Pure Gym operated 263 gyms in cities and towns across the UK, including 68 gyms within greater London, and had 1,134,683 members overall.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsubsection Text: Since it was founded in 2005, Fitness World has disrupted the Danish fitness market with its convenient, value-for-money, flexible offer. Fitness World has a market-leading position in Denmark with an estimated 43% market share measured by members as of December 2019 (Source: Deloitte/EuropeActive Report). With a clear focus on property and ecosystem management, Fitness World created a smart footprint across cities with a complementary offering across clubs, creating local barriers to entry and satisfying the number one key purchasing criteria, which is proximity (Source: Fitness World Acquisition Report). Fitness World is a household name with membership including close to 10% of the population over the age of 14 in Denmark (as of December 31, 2019) and is proud of the contribution it has made to public health. Fitness World’s inclusive vision is to promote “healthy habits for all” and thereby enable people from all walks of life to live a healthier lifestyle through fitness training. As of December, 31, 2019, Fitness World had 185 gyms and 485,690 members overall in Denmark. For the year ended December 31, 2019, Fitness World generated revenue of DKK 1,362.1 million (£159.8 million) and Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of DKK 365.8 (£42.9 million) from its operations in Denmark, representing 83% of Fitness World’s total Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsubsection Text: Fitness World entered the Swiss market in 2018 by acquiring Basefit, the second largest gym operator and the leading value operator in Switzerland. In 2019, Basefit was the first player in the Swiss market to offer a flexible monthly membership option, BaseFree, which has been well received by the market as 45% of joiners have opted for BaseFree since its launch in December 2019. As of December 31, 2019, Basefit was the largest Swiss value operator with 39 gyms and 78,677 members and a member churn rate of 46%. Prior to its acquisition by Fitness World, Basefit generated revenue of £11 million and had a Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of £4 million for the year ended December 31, 2016. This increased to revenue of £16 million and a Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of £6 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. Following its acquisition by Fitness World, Basefit’s revenue increased to £21 million and its Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA was £6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. Fitness World has continued to invest in the Basefit brand and its operations in Switzerland. For the year ended December 31, 2019, Basefit generated revenue of DKK 232.7 million (£27.3 million) and Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of DKK 69.0 (£8.1 million) from its operations in Switzerland, representing 16% of Fitness World’s total Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsubsection Text: In 2015, Fitness World entered Poland by acquiring Condizione and its three fitness clubs and has since grown organically through bolt-on acquisitions. In light of the government mandated closure of our Polish gyms, we have taken the strategic view that we will not be investing additional Group resources in our Polish business at this time. Consequently, we have decided to cease operating in Poland. Our Polish subsidiary has applied to the Polish courts to open an insolvency proceeding under Polish bankruptcy laws with the goal of appointing a trustee to oversee the orderly distribution of our Polish assets. For the year ended December 31, 2019, Fitness World generated revenue of DKK 46.9 million (£5.5 million) and Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of DKK 6.2 million (£0.7 million) from its operations in Poland, representing 1% of Fitness World's Total Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsubsection Text: On January 14, 2020, our business combined Pure Gym, a value gym operator that has rapidly become the largest operator of gyms in the United Kingdom both by number of gyms and members, and Fitness World, a leading European gym and value fitness operator with sites across Denmark and Switzerland. We believe that the Combined Group has strong growth prospects and common core competencies, including shared market leadership positions in the UK and Denmark, an inclusive philosophy, a modern technology-enabled customer offer based on high-quality, affordable gyms that can be accessed on a flexible basis, and a strong platform for expansion. Our vision is to provide affordable, flexible, and “value-for-money” memberships to high-quality gyms to all people who want to increase their level of fitness, as demonstrated by our inclusive “everybody welcome” philosophy. In response to COVID-19, governments globally (including within the markets in which we operate) have implemented strict social distancing measures, including varied approaches to lockdowns and closures of non-essential businesses, including ours. COVID-19 presents an unprecedented disruption to our business, and the wide variations in potential outcomes present a material challenge to our business and our industry. We believe that we have taken and are taking appropriate actions in response to COVID-19 in line with relevant government guidance and we continue to take every step that we believe is prudent to protect and manage our business, control our cost base and protect our operating cash flows. See “Summary—Recent Developments—Impact of _COVID-19”. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, it is not possible to accurately predict the short-,_ medium- or long-term impacts of COVID-19 on our business and our industry. 93 ----- Our strategic mission continues to be providing affordable and flexible memberships to high-quality fitness facilities balanced against the pressures of the macroeconomic environment in which we operate. Upon our acquisition of Fitness World, we were the market-leading operator in the Danish market, with a growing presence in Switzerland and amongst value operators in Europe, were number two by number of sites value operator in Europe and number three by revenue and member numbers. We believe that the strategic rationale for the acquisition of Fitness World remains intact for the long-term despite the significant immediate challenges faced in a COVID-19 world. For the year ended December 31, 2019, we derived 57% of our revenue from our operations in the UK, 36% from our operations in Denmark, 6% from operations in Switzerland and 1% from our operations in Poland. Our key geographic markets are the UK and Denmark and as such, Pure Gym and Fitness World will continue operating under their existing brand names in these key markets. As of December 31, 2019, the Combined Group operated 504 gyms in cities and towns across the four countries, with Pure Gym accounting for 52% of clubs and Fitness World accounting for 48% of clubs, and had approximately 1.7 million members in total. The table below displays the key European gym operators by number of members: (‘000 Members) (1) Source: Company information and Deloitte/EuropeActive Report. (2) Pure Gym excludes pre-opening members and includes members at Pure Gym branded gyms only. (3) Pure Gym, Fitness World and The Gym Group data is as of December 2019; Basic-Fit data is as of Q3 2019. Members of other operators are as per latest estimates included in the Deloitte/EuropeActive Report. Fitness World is a good strategic fit for Pure Gym due to its aligned low-cost operating model. The Combined Group is the third largest operator in Europe by membership and the second largest by number of gyms. With leading market positions in the UK and Denmark and as the second largest player in Switzerland, the Combined Group is a market-leading European value gym operator with diversification and scale benefits. Our disruptive customer value proposition, differentiated business model and well-managed growth strategy has allowed us to grow rapidly. For the year ended December 2019, the Combined Group generated revenue of £447.5 million and a Combined Group Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of £161.2 million after giving pro _forma effect to the Acquisition. In the same timeframe, Pure Gym’s UK operations generated revenue of £255_ million and Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of £105 million, representing growth of 12.1% and 41.0%, respectively, as compared to the previous year end.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsection Title: Significant factors affecting our results of operations
Subsubsection Text: This section discusses key factors that we believe have had a material effect on Pure Gym’s results of operations and financial condition during the periods under review, as well as those that are reasonably likely to have a material effect on its results of operations and financial condition in the future. _Impact of COVID-19 The discussion below incorporates data for the months of July 2020 and August 2020 that are derived from preliminary results and estimates contained in our management accounts, which have not been and will not be audited or reviewed in accordance with any generally accepted auditing standards and are subject to change._ 95 ----- _The data for the months of July 2020 and August 2020 presented below is not intended to be a comprehensive statement of the Combined Group’s financial or operational results for the nine month period ended September 30, 2020 and is based on a number of assumptions that are subject to inherent uncertainties and risks. As such, you should not place reliance on them when making an investment decision. See “Information Regarding Forward-Looking Statements” and “Risk Factors” for a more complete discussion of certain of the factors that could affect our future performance and results of operation. In addition to the inherent risks and uncertainties associated with using data derived from management accounts, the impact of COVID-19 during the current quarter has created heightened and unprecedented risks and uncertainties and has resulted in atypical, non- routine transactions and activities, which increase the likelihood that the management accounts for the period, including the data for the months of July 2020 and August 2020 presented below, may not be in line with the financial data we report in our September 2020 interim financial information or at year-end. For more information about the risks associated with the use of data derived from management accounts and the heightened risks in the context of the ongoing COVID-19 situation, see “Risk Factors—The unaudited financial data and projections included herein need to be carefully considered and incorporate forward-looking estimates that may differ from actual results”. The discussion below also incorporates data that is derived from management's projections. By their nature, projections are forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties because they relate to events, depend on circumstances that may or may not occur in the future and are based on a number of assumptions that are themselves subject to inherent uncertainties and risks. We caution you that forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance and that our actual results of operations, financial condition and liquidity, and the development of the industry in which we operate may differ materially from those made in or suggested by the forward-looking statements contained in this Offering Memorandum. In addition, even if our results of operations, financial condition and liquidity, and the development of the industry in which we operate are consistent with the forward-looking statements contained in this Offering Memorandum, those results or developments may not be indicative of results or developments in subsequent periods. As such, you should not place reliance on forward-looking statements when making an investment decision. See “Information Regarding Forward-Looking Statements”._ We had a strong start to the 2020 financial year. In addition to the acquisition of Fitness World, we had a strong trading performance in January and February and combined group membership numbers peaked at 1.9 million as of February 29, 2020. However, in March 2020, the governments of the countries in which we operate imposed significant lockdown measures in order to control the spread of COVID-19 and, in doing so, necessitated the temporary closure of all of our gyms (the “lockdown period”) until restrictions could be lifted. When lockdowns occurred, our overall approach was to place members on “free freeze” and as a result almost all our revenues ceased. Some revenues were received during closure periods in Fitness World Denmark as a result of offers made to members and, in the UK, a small amount of revenue was secured from the PureGym Together product. However, in aggregate, almost all of our revenue effectively ceased until the phased reopening of our gyms began. The Group had a strong year in 2019 and a robust start to 2020, both of which enabled us to enter the COVID-19 crisis from a position of financial strength; however, the spread of COVID-19 and the prolonged shutdown of our gym estate has had a material negative impact on our business. During the initial lockdown period, we acted swiftly to minimize our cash burn. The business entered lockdown from a position of real strength, which gives us confidence that our core product and proposition was performing well and resonating strongly with members. As expected, our trading performance was severely impacted in the last two weeks of the first quarter and throughout the second quarter of 2020. Prior to the initial lockdown period, net average cash outflow for the Combined Group was £9 million per week on an unmitigated basis, consisting of £8 million in operating cash cost and £1 million in interest cash cost per week. As a result of our cost-cutting strategies, cash-saving measures, revenue initiatives and access to government initiatives, the Combined Group’s liquidity declined by only £18 million throughout the 14-week closure period from March 23, 2020 to June 26, 2020. This primarily consisted of £11 million of payments in relation to capital expenditures (being projects completed prior to the lockdown period) and £7 million of interest payments that fell due during the period. The Combined Group therefore effectively reduced, deferred or offset all of its unmitigated £8 million weekly operating cash cost burden during this 14-week lockdown period. Of the £8 million unmitigated weekly operating cash cost, £4 million was saved through a combination of reducing operating costs, landlord forbearance and assistance received from governments (furlough monies, fixed overhead compensation and rates relief), £2.0 million (comprising £2.5 million of deferred payments net of £0.5 million of receipts) has been deferred into the second half of 2020 and £2 million has been offset through various revenue and other cash collection activities. The second half of 2020 and 2021 will inevitably see increased cash outflows 96 ----- as deferred payments are settled and interest payments are made as they fall due and management’s plan takes this into account. For more information about the risks associated with the impact of the current and subsequent waves of COVID-19 and current and future lockdowns on our ability to minimize cash burn, see “Risk Factors— _The negative impact of COVID-19 on our business is significant and its effects will continue to materially negatively impact our business, financial condition and results of operations due to many factors, some of which are beyond our control”._ We also benefited from our geographic diversification during the initial reopening following the initial lockdown period, with a range of reopening dates: Switzerland (11 May), Poland (6 June), Denmark (11 June), Northern Ireland (10 July), England (25 July) and Wales (10 August). The health and wellbeing of our members and staff remains of paramount importance and we are fully engaged to ensure that our gyms, when open, are a safe place to work and a safe place to work out. We have implemented new standards and protocols which are being put in place across the industry. These measures, including personal sanitization, capacity limits, social distancing and abundant cleaning facilities, reduce the risk of transmission for members attending a gym and for our colleagues who work in them. We believe that our approach to variable pricing and capacity management – which is currently best developed in the UK estate – places us well to optimize our value proposition. For example, during the initial reopening, across 274 gyms in the UK, capacity limits ranged from 37 members to 197 members. We track gym capacity, which is set by gym and which can be changed in real-time. We use a data-led approach to manage capacity, leveraging our understanding of usage trends by gym and space allocation and work out station volumes, as well as member feedback. There are a number of levers in addition to club capacity limit that are available to us to help us manage capacity, including number of stations available, hours, classes offered, off-peak product and our booking system. Decisions relating to capacity management in the UK, where COVID-19 related restrictions are currently tightest, are based on daily performance reviews at the gym level. Additionally, we employ a COVID-19 risk monitoring tool as the basis for twice-weekly risk assessments in the UK and weekly risk assessments in Denmark. This risk monitoring tool is based on daily public testing data provided by government sources in the UK and Denmark, uses risk parameters and methodologies set out by the German Public Health Institute (The Koch Institute) and assesses each individual site for risk based on the local area and the specific location of each individual member. This allows management to target additional safety measures (for members and for our team members) and we believe it gives us early warnings of where local lockdowns may come into force. This tool is coupled with industry-wide (UK and European) data covering member visits, EHO visits, infected member/staff incidence and transmission incidence, which provides a coherent data set for discussions with local and national governments to explain why gyms should remain open in the event of further lockdowns. Member feedback on our first reopening was positive and translated to positive member trends in likefor-like member volumes as well as gym visits, particularly among the younger member demographic which displayed a greater propensity to return to the gym. This initial membership trend continued in the UK, where our median member age is below that of our gyms in Denmark and Switzerland: the UK business has the youngest demographic mix in the group (median member age is 28 in the UK, 30 in Denmark and 31 in Switzerland). As at October 18, 2020, we had approximately 1.6 million closing members across the Combined Group, which represents like-for-like members versus membership levels at the same point in 2019 of 80% in the UK, 90% in Denmark and 93% in Switzerland and there have been no confirmed reports of COVID-19 transmission in our gyms reported after more than 26 million visits since reopening. Member visits in the UK increased to 86% in late October, as compared to the same point in 2019. In August 2020, like-for-like average revenue per member was higher than August 2019, with an increase of 3% in the UK and 7% in Denmark. Despite the extended closure period due to mandated government lockdown measures in the countries in which we operate, our business returned to profitability in August and September 2020 following the reopening of the UK estate, with gyms in both Switzerland and Denmark returning to profitability in the month of their reopening. The charts below show the resilience of our business model as evidenced by our rapid return to profitability in August and September following initial lockdown period in the countries in which we operate. 97 ----- While the trend observed in August and September 2020 demonstrated our resilience at that point in time, there can be no assurance that our recovery following subsequent lockdowns would be comparably robust. Overall, as of November 9, 2020 253 (49%) of our sites were open: - **UK: All 236 of our sites in England are currently shut down as a result of the national lockdown that went into effect on November 5, 2020. Our 38 sites across Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland remain open, with the sites in Wales having been closed for two weeks until November 9, 2020, due to the Welsh “fire-break” lockdown. More broadly, PureGym continues to collate and share evidence with national, regional and local authorities that indicates that gyms are relatively low-risk environments and make a strong positive contribution to public health. - **Denmark: 179 out of 185 Fitness World gyms remain open. On October 23, 2020, the Danish government announced new COVID-19 restrictions which have an impact on the operation of gyms such as Fitness World, including for example restrictions on group exercise classes of more than 10 people and requirement to wear a face mask when entering, exiting or staying in a gyms lounge, although not while exercising). These changes may have an impact on member satisfaction and member numbers. In addition, on November 5, 2020, the Danish government announced a number of COVID-19 related restrictions and measures in the area of Northern Jutland following the discovery of a mutated coronavirus referred to as “Cluster 5”, which is believed to spread from minks to humans. Consequently, the Northern Jutland region has been placed on partial lockdown and Fitness World has closed six gyms in the area as a result of the restrictions. The partial lockdown is currently in effect until December 3, 2020, however, there is a risk that it could be extended or that further regional lockdowns, closures or restrictions could be imposed. The Danish government continues to focus on local and sector specific containment measures The management team continue to monitor the situation carefully and are ready to react to regulatory changes. - **Switzerland: 36 out of 39 of our gyms in Switzerland remain open; viral infection rates are on par with the UK and we were informed on October 23, 2020 that one canton (Bern) would be instituting a local lockdown which required closure of three gyms. Management will continue to monitor the situation carefully across Switzerland. - **Poland: our 19 gyms in Poland were closed on October 17, 2020 as part of a range of measures instituted by the national government to stem rising virus rates. The effect of COVID-19 on our business and the wider fitness industry will ultimately depend on a number of factors, including, but not limited to, the duration and severity of the outbreak and the length of time it takes for demand and pricing to return and for normal economic and operating conditions to resume. In this Offering Memorandum, we present financial and other operating data as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019. In addition to its usefulness as regards our historical performance, this data represents the ordinary course operations of our business before the Acquisition and before the impact of COVID-19. We have 98 ----- also presented financial and other operating data as of and for the six months ended June 30, 2020, which include the results of the Fitness World Group from January 14, 2020 and which represent the impact on our business of the Acquisition and COVID-19. Accordingly, our financial condition and results of operations will differ in respect of the current year and for future periods, when compared to the historical financial condition and results of operations presented in this discussion. For additional detail, see “Summary—Recent Developments—Impact _of COVID-19”. IFRS 16 (Leases)_ With respect to the 2019 Pure Gym Financial Statements, Pure Gym applied the new IFRS 16 (Leases) accounting standard, effective from January 1, 2019 using the modified retrospective method, for transition and measuring right of use assets using the retrospective calculation, both as defined by the IFRS 16 accounting standard. Cumulative effects of applying this new accounting standard was therefore recognized as an adjustment to retained earnings as of January 1, 2019 (the date of initial application), while comparative figures were not restated. The 2017 Topco Financial Statements and the 2018 Topco Financial Statements have not been restated for the adoption of IFRS 16. IFRS 16 eliminates the classification of leases as either operating leases or finance leases and introduces a single lessee accounting model with some exemptions for short-term and low-value leases. The lessee recognizes a right-of-use asset representing its right to use the underlying asset and a lease liability representing its obligation to make lease payments. The effect of applying IFRS 16 is to align the presentation of leases more closely to that of owned assets, rent expense is no longer deducted in arriving at operating profit or Pure Gym EBITDA and instead profit before tax includes an interest charge on the unwinding of the lease liability and a depreciation charge on the right of use asset. See Note 27 “Change in Accounting Policies” of the 2019 Pure Gym Financial Statements. _Roll out of Pure Gyms_ New gym openings have been a significant driver of our growth during the periods under review and our roll out strategy has had, and is expected to continue to have, a significant effect on our results of operations. We opened 22 gyms in 2017, 30 gyms in 2018 and 41 gyms in 2019. During the six months ended June 30, 2020, the estate increased by 241 gyms as a result of the Fitness World acquisition in January 2020 and by six gyms as a result of organic openings (four in the UK and two in Switzerland). Prior to lockdown, a further eight organic Pure Gym sites were developed in the UK and were ready for opening, all of which have now opened post-period end. We have not closed or relocated any organic gyms in the UK during the period, however as part of an estate optimization plan in Denmark, three Fitness World gyms were closed, with members successfully migrated – in the main – to alternative nearby gyms within our estate. The chart below shows the member levels of seven recently opened UK gyms as compared to our targeted average. 99 ----- Source: Management data; OC&C analysis. 1. Bank has been excluded as it is a London city centre gym. _Pre-opening period_ Prior to opening, each new Pure Gym typically undergoes a two to three-month long pre-opening period following commencement of the lease. During this period, construction of the gym is completed, a significant amount of marketing is conducted and discounted membership offers are typically made to attract new members. Pre-Opening Costs during the pre-opening period averaged £85,000 per New Gym opened in the year ended December 31, 2019 (on a post-IFRS 16 basis) and largely consisted of staff costs and marketing expenses. The impact of IFRS 16 was to reduce average pre-opening costs during the period by £37,000 being rent expense that would otherwise have been charged to the income statement on an IAS 17 basis. _Maturity profile_ Once a new Pure Gym opens, its membership base generally increases rapidly in the first three to six months eventually reaching mature levels after approximately 24 months. Revenue per member also increases as members who join following opening typically pay higher monthly membership fees than those on pre-opening offers. Growth in revenue per member is also supported by the expiration of pre-opening offers, which generally terminate between three and 12 months after opening, when members who remain on these offers receive an automatic price uplift. Together, these factors typically drive increases in revenue and result in growth in Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA as a significant proportion of gym operating and property costs are fixed. We categorize a gym as a Mature Gym at the end of its second year of operation, as a gym’s EBITDA tends to be substantially mature after 24 months, whereas during the first 24 months we usually see an increase in EBITDA. Typically, a gym’s third year is the first full year during which it delivers an annual Mature Gym EBITDA. For example, we consider a gym that opened in August 2017 a Mature Gym for the year ended December 31, 2019, although its EBITDA tends to stabilize after August 2019. Accordingly, the period from January 1, 2020 to December 31, 2020 would be the first full financial year during which that gym delivers an annual Mature Gym EBITDA. 100 ----- The following table shows selected financial information for the UK Mature Gym portfolio for year ended December 31, 2019. For information regarding the calculation of these items, see “Presentation of _Financial and Other Data—Non-IFRS Measures”._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsubsection Text: Pure Gym derives substantially all of its revenue from monthly membership fees and joining fees paid by its members. For the year ended December 31, 2019, 92% of Pure Gym revenue was attributable to membership fees. For the six months ended June 30, 2020, 92% and 91% of Pure Gym revenue was attributable to membership fees, respectively. Accordingly, our revenue is significantly dependent on membership volumes. Membership volumes are affected by numerous factors, including the total number of Pure Gyms in operation, the prices our gyms charge, the sizes and locations of our gyms, competitive dynamics in the value gym market and seasonality, amongst others. Pure Gym membership has grown substantially from approximately 927,000 as of December 31, 2017 to approximately 1,135,000 as of December 31, 2019. This growth has been driven primarily by the opening of new gyms, the maturation of recent openings, and the acquisition of Ovalhouse Limited (trading as Soho Gyms) in 2018. As at June 30, 2020, membership for the Combined Group was 1,697,000, of which 1,128,000 is attributable to Pure Gyms and 560,000 to the gyms in the Fitness World group. The following table shows certain membership information for different categories of our gym portfolios for the periods indicated. New Gyms have lower membership levels than Mature Gyms as they have not reached maturity. This is of particular note in 2019, as 19 gyms were opened in the fourth quarter. 101 ----- The table below presents the breakdown of our members by gym type for the periods presented.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsubsection Text: Our revenue is also dependent on the prices we charge. Pure Gym operates a dynamic pricing model with the objective of maximizing each site’s revenue. To this end, membership fee and joining fee rates are set on an individual gym basis and take into account a number of factors such as a gym’s membership level, its utilization profile, its capacity, the demographic profile of its local catchment and the degree of local competition, amongst others. See “Business—Members—Membership Pricing—Pure Gym”. The following table sets forth the Average Revenue per Member per Month for the periods indicated. The figures exclude VAT and combine membership and ancillary revenues.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsection Title: For the year** **For the six months ended December 31,** **ended June 30, £** **2017** **2018** **2019** **2019** **2020
Subsubsection Text: _Low-cost gym operating model_ Pure Gym employs a low-cost, technology-enabled gym operating model, which enables our Pure Gyms to offer a compelling customer value proposition while simultaneously delivering strong operating margins and profitability. See “Business—Key Strengths—High cash flow generative profile underpinned by exceptional _profitability and positive working capital cash inflows”. The majority of site operating costs are controlled_ centrally and senior management is focused on leveraging scale and implementing other initiatives to control costs and improve efficiencies. Site operating costs, other than property costs, are generally consistent across all Pure Gyms and do not typically vary significantly between gyms. Accordingly, site operating costs as a percentage of revenue for a Mature Gym are substantially lower than for a New Gym. For the year ended December 31, 2019, site operating costs, including depreciation, as a percentage of revenue for our 192 Mature Gyms was 58.5% as compared to 61.8% for all of our gyms. 102 ----- The following table sets out our gym site operating costs for the UK Mature Gym portfolio for the year ended December 31, 2019 on a post-IFRS 16 basis.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsection Title: For the year** **For the six months ended December 31,** **ended June 30, £** **2017** **2018** **2019** **2019** **2020
Subsubsection Text: Average Revenue per Member per Month[(1)] 18.00 18.51 18.90 18.79 11.20 (1) We define average revenue per member per month as revenue for that period divided by the number of months in that period and further divided by the average number of members during that period. Average Revenue per Member per Month increased from £18.00 for the year ended December 31, 2017 to £18.90 for the year ended December 31, 2019, largely as a result of both increased membership fees and additional charges for value-added options that we offer such as premium memberships (See _Business— _Members—Membership Offerings—Pure Gym). In the six months ended June 30, 2020, Average Revenue per_ Member per Month decreased to £11.20 for the Combined Group due to the COVID-19 closure impact. For an increased monthly fee, Pure Gym’s members can choose to upgrade to a premium membership option. This allows access to additional gyms and provides members with a number of additional benefits, for example, the ability to book classes earlier than standard members and four guest passes a month. We started offering these premium membership options in late 2016, and as of December 31, 2019, 23% of our members are on a premium product. Due to the effect of pre-opening offers, Average New Gym Revenue per Member per Month is initially lower than Average Mature Gym Revenue per Member per Month. However, this metric is influenced by the profile of openings in any year, the length of pre-sale offer, the location and the format of the new sites. For example, a bias towards earlier openings in a London location will provide a higher Average Revenue per Member per Month metric.

The impact of IFRS 16 was to reduce operating costs for UK Mature Gyms during the period by £18.7 million, being a reduction in property lease costs that would otherwise have been charged under IAS 17 of £33.7 million offset by increased deprecation charge associated with right of use assets of £15.2 million. _Head Office Costs_ We have made substantial investments in Head Office Costs over recent years to facilitate continued innovation and differentiation, to gain more control over certain key business functions, such as IT, and deliver the management and technology infrastructure to support our enlarged estate and future growth plans. These investments have included hiring additional staff as well as making investments in our management processes and IT systems to build and maintain an industry-leading technology platform. Although we expect to continue investing in our key business functions, we believe our infrastructure is now scalable and will deliver a reducing ratio to revenue as our growth continues. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsection Title: For the year ended December 31, 2019 As a percentage of revenue** **(£ millions)** **(%)
Subsubsection Text: Organic growth remains the bedrock of our growth strategy, supplemented by carefully selected strategic acquisitions. M&A activity has had a positive effect on our results of operations. In 2015, the acquisition of LA Fitness bolstered our property portfolio in London and the South East. In 2018, we acquired Soho Gyms consisting of ten fitness clubs based in prime locations throughout London. In January 2020, we also acquired Fitness World’s 241 gym estate spanning across Denmark, Poland and Switzerland, for a consideration of DKK 2,037.1 million (£232.9 million), and the repayment of DKK 1,033.1 million (£118.1 million) of outstanding Fitness World indebtedness. We acquired Fitness World because it is a strong business with very similar characteristics to Pure Gym. It provides scale and diversification and represents a stable cash generating business with opportunities for further expansion. 103 ----- The financial data of the Issuer and its consolidated subsidiaries as of and for the six months ended June 30, 2020 presented herein include Fitness World from the Acquisition Date.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsection Title: For the year ended December 31, 2019 As a percentage of revenue** **(£ millions)** **(%)
Subsubsection Text: Pure Gym recognized expected liabilities for tax based on an estimation of the likely taxes due, which requires significant judgment as to the ultimate tax treatment of certain items. We recorded income tax expenses of £3.6 million, £3.0 million and £3.4 million during the years ended December 31, 2017, 2018 and 2019, respectively. We believe that we will have effective UK tax rates of approximately 19% for 2020, 19% for 2021 and 19% for 2022.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsection Title: For the year ended December 31, 2019 As a percentage of revenue** **(£ millions)** **(%)
Subsubsection Text: Pure Gym experiences a small degree of seasonality. The majority of our membership growth takes place in January, February, September and October. Seasonality is generally positively driven by consumers’ desire to improve their fitness at the start of the year and the start of new university/school terms, and negatively driven by Christmas and summer holidays. We generally focus our marketing spend around peak joining periods, particularly the January/February period.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsection Title: Description of key income statement items
Subsubsection Text: Revenue in the UK primarily comprises monthly membership fees paid by members, including fees paid by members who freeze their memberships, additional fees for value add options, such as our premium membership options and non-refundable joining fees paid by new members in the period. Membership fees and joining fees represented 92% of our total revenue for the year ended December 31, 2019. Monthly membership fees are recognized evenly over the month on a daily basis with deferred revenue recorded at the month end for any revenue that is to be recognized in the following month. Joining fees are recognized in the month of receipt, with the exception of joining fees received from members who sign up during the pre-opening period of a new gym, which are recognized as revenue in the month the relevant gym opens. We also generate revenue from daypass sales, vending sales, marketing contributions from suppliers, direct debit bounce fees, rent from personal trainers and other ancillary activities, which together represented 8% of our total revenue for the year ended December 31, 2019. Revenue is stated excluding value added tax and other sales-related taxes. Our revenue was £198.0 million, £228.4 million and £254.9 million for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2018 and 2019, respectively, £61.6 million and £125.9 million and £111.1 million for the six months ended June 30, 2019 and 2020, respectively.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsection Title: Description of key income statement items
Subsubsection Text: Other administrative expenses comprise the costs incurred in administering our operations, including employee costs, property lease rental costs (on an IAS 17 basis for 2017 and 2018), marketing costs, other fixed property costs, other operating costs, head office costs, depreciation of property, plant and equipment and amortization of intangible assets. Gains and losses on disposals of property, plant and equipment are also included in other administrative expenses. Employee costs consist of wages and salaries, social security and pension costs. Property lease rental costs in 2017 and 2018 consist of property rental charges on an IAS 17 basis. Marketing costs comprise expenditure relating to attracting new members and retaining existing members. Other fixed property costs include rates, services charges, and other costs related to property. Other operating costs comprise repairs, maintenance, cleaning, insurance, security, and utilities expenses, and other costs. Head office costs comprise costs that are not allocated to our gyms and are generally incurred in administrating our estate and our business, including central and regional support staff costs and their associated administration costs, technology and website maintenance costs, professional fees and other costs. The largest component of head office costs is employee costs. Depreciation of property, plant and equipment relates to depreciation of fixtures and fittings, leasehold improvements and fitness equipment for years 2017 and 2018 and also depreciation of right of use assets (on a post-IFRS 16 basis) for 2019 and 2020. Capital costs are depreciated over six years for fixtures, fittings and fitness equipment, three to 15 years for leasehold improvements and the life of the lease for leasehold costs and right of use assets. Initial Capital Investment is generally depreciated over a blended average useful life of nine years 104 ----- while refurbishment capital spend is generally depreciated over a blended average useful life of six years. Amortization includes amortization of intangible assets.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsection Title: Description of key income statement items
Subsubsection Text: Exceptional administrative expenses include items that are material in size and unusual or infrequent in nature. The separate reporting of exceptional administrative expenses helps provide an indication of our underlying performance. In 2017, exceptional administrative expenses totalled £13.8 million and primarily related to the sale of Pure Gym to Leonard Green and Partners, LP. In 2018, exceptional administrative expenses totalled £1.8 million and primarily related to the acquisition of Soho Gyms and the subsequent integration and transition of these sites to the Pure Gym brand. In the year ended December 31, 2019, exceptional administrative expenses totalled £8.3 million, being costs associated with the acquisition of Fitness World, exploration of other acquisition and expansion opportunities, further integration and transition expenses of Soho Gyms and the restructuring of certain operations in the existing business. Exceptional administrative expenses increased to £3.0 million for the six months ended June 30, 2020, which primarily related to transition and integration costs relating to the Fitness World acquisition, as compared to £1.0 million for the six months ended June 30, 2019, which were primarily associated with exploration of potential future acquisitions and restructuring of the existing business.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsection Title: Description of key income statement items
Subsubsection Text: Net finance costs are finance costs net of finance income. Finance costs represent the charges (accrued or paid) associated with shareholder loans, vendor loan notes, bank loans and overdrafts, preference shares, finance leases, interest rate derivatives and for 2019 and 2020, finance costs associated with the unwinding of property lease liabilities on a post-IFRS 16 basis. Finance costs also include interest on the Notes and any borrowings under the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility. Additionally, finance costs include the amortization of any fees associated with the raising of finance that have been capitalized. Finance costs are recognized using the effective interest method. Finance income consists of interest (accrued or paid) on cash held at the bank and income from the Finance Lease Receivable.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsection Title: Description of key income statement items
Subsubsection Text: Income tax (charge)/credit comprises current and deferred tax. Current tax is the expected tax payable or receivable on the taxable income or loss for the year, using tax rates enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting date, and any adjustment to tax payable or receivable in respect of previous years. Deferred tax is recognized in respect of temporary differences between the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities for financial reporting purposes and the amounts used for taxation purposes. Deferred tax assets are recognized for unused tax losses, unused tax credits and deductible temporary differences to the extent that it is probable that future taxable profits will be available against which they can be used. 105 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsubsection Text: Other administrative expenses increased by 56.7% to £141.5 million for the six months ended June 30, 2020 as compared to £90.3 million for the six months ended June 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the acquisition of Fitness World, offset by cost reductions achieved during the closure period due to a combination of government mitigation schemes and swift management actions. _Exceptional administrative expenses_ Exceptional administrative expenses increased to £3.0 million for the six months ended June 30, 2020, which primarily related to transition and integration costs relating to the Fitness World acquisition, as compared to £1.0 million for the six months ended June 30, 2019, which were primarily associated with exploration of potential future acquisitions and restructuring of the existing business. _Net finance costs_ Net finance costs increased to £81.0 million for the six months ended June 30, 2020, an increase of £37.9 million, or 87.9%, as compared to £43.1 million for the six months ended June 30, 2019. This increase is primarily due to the acquisition of Fitness World and consists of bridge loan interest, amortization of associated capitalized finance costs, additional finance leasing acquired with Fitness World and foreign exchange losses. _Income tax credit/(charge)_ Our income tax was a credit of £8.6 million for the six months ended June 30, 2020, an increase of £8.9 million as compared with a charge of £0.3 million for the six months ended June 30, 2019. The tax credits arose due to the significant losses incurred due to the COVID-19 closures. We do not expect to be tax paying in 2020 as a result of losses incurred from the COVID-19 closures.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsubsection Text: Other administrative expenses for the year ended December 31, 2019 were £186.8 million, an increase of £2.8 million, or 1.5%, compared to £184.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was principally as a result of growth in number of gyms and the full year effect of gyms opened in the prior year, offset by the impact of IFRS 16 implemented on 1 January 2019, which reduced other administrative expenses for the period by £26.4 million, being a reduction in property lease costs that would otherwise have been charged under IAS 17 of £45.7 million offset by an increased deprecation charge associated with right of use assets and profit on lease modifications of £19.3 million. _Exceptional administrative expenses_ Exceptional administrative expenses for the year ended December 31, 2019 were £8.3 million, an increase of £6.5 million compared to £1.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2018. Exceptional administrative expenses in the year ended December 31, 2019 primarily related to the acquisition of Fitness World, further integration and transition costs of Soho Gyms, restructuring certain operations of the existing business and exploration of other acquisition and expansion opportunities, while exceptional administrative expenses in the year ended December 31, 2018 primarily related to the acquisition of Soho Gyms and integration and transition of these sites to the Pure Gym brand. _Net finance costs_ Our net finance costs for the year ended December 31, 2019 were £83.4 million, an increase of £55.2 million, or 196%, compared to £28.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was a combination of the full year effect of borrowings drawn down in 2018 related to the Soho Gyms acquisition, the cost of additional borrowings drawn in 2019 and the impact of IFRS 16 implemented on January 1, 2019, which increased net finance cost by £28.8 million. _Income tax charge_ Our income tax charge for the year ended December 31, 2019 was £3.4 million compared to £3.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2018.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsubsection Text: The Group's liquidity requirements arise primarily from the need to fund its roll out strategy, make interest payments on its indebtedness, fund its working capital requirements and invest in the upkeep of its existing gyms and central systems and capabilities. The Group's principal sources of liquidity have been its cash flow from operating activities, its banking facilities, and its finance leases. Following the Offering, we expect to fund our working capital and capital expenditure requirements with future cash flow from operating activities and cash holdings and, if necessary, additional borrowings under the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility. As of June 30, 2020, after giving effect to the Transaction, the Combined Group would have had £180.6 million cash and cash equivalents, £98.0 million in undrawn Revolving Credit Facility commitments available for drawing by way of certain ancillary facilities and £10 million available overdraft facility under the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility. For an update on the Group’s liquidity, see “Summary—Recent _Developments—Impact of COVID-19—Liquidity Update”. Historically, our liquidity needs were also met through_ drawings under the Original Revolving Credit Facility as amended by the amendment and restatement deed.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsection Title: For the year** **For the six months ended December 31,** **ended June 30, 2017** **2018** **2019** **2019** **2020 (£ millions)
Subsubsection Text: Net cash generated from/(used in) operating activities ................................. (9.9) 88.0 69.5 27.0 1.2 Net cash used in investing activities .......... (38.4) (61.5) (69.4) (21.7) (254.0) Net cash generated from financing activities ................................................. 28.9 1.7 28.2 37.0 288.8 Expansionary Capital Expenditures .... 32.0 32.5 50.6 18.9 18.6 Maintenance and Refurbishment Capital Expenditures ...................... 7.1 11.3 16.5 3.0 9.2 Total capital expenditures ................** 39.1 43.8 67.1 22.0 27.8 Our capital expenditures increased from £39.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2017 to £67.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2019 primarily as a result of an increase in the number of new sites (and therefore total Initial Capital Investment) year on year and ongoing investments in our management systems and IT systems. Maintenance and Refurbishment Capital Expenditures also increased over the same period due to the growing portfolio of gyms. We maintain a comprehensive maintenance and refurbishment program for our gyms, with initial and ongoing capital expenditures consisting of expenses in relation to equipment, fixtures and fittings, IT and leasehold costs. We estimate that a Pure Gym will generally be fully refurbished within six to eight years of opening at a cost of approximately £0.6 million per gym, and this cost will typically be phased in over the sixth to eighth years following opening. During the six months ended June 30, 2020, the estate increased by 241 gyms as a result of the Fitness World acquisition in January 2020 and by six gyms as a result of organic openings (four in the UK and two in Switzerland). Prior to lockdown, a further eight organic Pure Gym sites were developed in the UK and were ready for opening, all of which have now opened post-period end. We have not closed or relocated any organic gyms in the UK during the period. As part of an estate optimization plan in Denmark, three Fitness World gyms were closed, with members successfully migrated – in the main – to alternative nearby gyms within our estate. As a part of our cash preservation measures taken in response to COVID-19, all capital expenditure on scheduled refurbishment was paused and only essential maintenance works were carried out. Each of our Pure Gyms generally require approximately £25,000 to £30,000 of capital investment on an annual basis for maintenance, incorporating some minor enhancements. This maintenance expenditure, in addition to the scheduled site refurbishments, is expected to resume in 2021. In 2020, we have so far opened 19 new gyms (12 in the UK, of which two were SBF gyms, five in Denmark and two in Poland). We do not plan to open any further new gyms before 2021. The Initial Capital Investment for each Pure Gym is estimated to be on average £1.2 million for a large box gym and on average £0.7 million for a SBF gym. See “Business—Gym size and format—Pure Gym”. 112 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsection Title: Cash and cash equivalents at end of period** **(4.8)** **23.3** **51.6** **65.6** **88.6
Subsubsection Text: _Net cash flows from operating activities_ Pure Gym’s net cash flows from operating activities comprise our operating profit before interest, tax, profit/(loss) on disposals, depreciation, amortization and impairment charges, net of the movement in net working capital and less tax, exceptional costs paid, net interest and debt issuance costs paid. Pure Gym’s net cash flows from operating activities for the six months ended June 30, 2020 were £1.2 million, a decline of £25.8 million as compared to the six months ended June 30, 2019. Operating cash flows of the group were significantly reduced by COVID-19. Membership subscriptions were frozen during the closure period, but this lost revenue was offset in part by government mitigation schemes combined with swift management action to reduce costs and preserve cash. Pure Gym’s net cash flows from operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 were £69.5 million, a decrease of £18.5 million, or 21.0%, compared to £88.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was principally as a result of increased interest payments. Pure Gym’s net cash flows from operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2018 were £88.0 million, an increase of £97.8 million compared to £(9.9) million in the year December 31, 2017. This increase was principally the result of payment of cumulative loan note interest and exceptional costs associated with the sale of Pure Gym to LGP in 2017 and the associated refinancing of Pure Gym. Working Capital Cash Flow for the six months ended June 30, 2020 of £16.1 million benefited from deferment of supplier payments at the period end, a measure taken in response to mitigate the cashflow impact of COVID-19. Working Capital Cash Flow for the six months ended June 30, 2019 was negative £6.0 million and this was primarily due to the unwind of year end accruals. Pure Gym benefited from Working Capital Cash Flow of £3.1 million, £13.5 million and £3.6 million, for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2018 and 2019, respectively. Our Working Capital Cash Flow is generally positive, largely because membership fees are paid by members one month in advance, we benefit from favourable payment terms with our suppliers, and for years 2017 and 2018 on an IAS 17 basis, the cash property lease rental costs are lower than our property lease rental costs accrued in the income statement due to rent free periods on new gyms and the accounting requirement that future minimum or expected increases in rents are amortized equally over the life of each lease. In the year ended December 31, 2019, our total cash outflow on property lease rental was £40.5 million, or 15.9% of revenue. On a post-IFRS 16 basis, the presentation of this cash outflow on property leases is split across net cash generated from operating activities (being interest of £28.8 million) and net cash generated from financing activities (being capital of £11.7 million). 110 ----- _Net cash flows used in investing activities_ Net cash flows used in investing activities consist of expenditure on property, plant and equipment and intangible assets and amounts paid for acquisitions, less proceeds from disposals and the portion of any capital expenditure funded through finance leases. Net cash outflow from investing activities was £254.0 million in the six months ended June 30, 2020, as compared to £21.7 million in the six months ended June 30, 2019 and related to the acquisition of Fitness World, net of cash acquired. Net cash flows used in investing activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 were £69.4 million, which was primarily the result of purchasing property, plant and equipment for 41 new sites. Net cash flows used in investing activities for the year ended December 31, 2018 were £61.5 million, which was primarily a result of purchasing property, plant and equipment for 30 new organic sites along with acquiring Soho Gyms. Net cash flows used in investing activities for the year ended December 31, 2017 were £38.4 million, which was primarily a result of purchasing property, plant and equipment for 22 new gyms. _Net cash flows used in financing activities_ Pure Gym’s net cash flows from financing activities consists of the drawdown and repayment of bank loans, finance leases and shareholder debt. Net cash used in financing activities in the six months ended June 30, 2020 was £288.8 million and consisted of £380.9 million of proceeds from the Bridge Facility obtained to acquire Fitness World, net of the repayment of £118 million debt acquired, in addition to the net drawings on the revolving credit facility of £37.0 million and finance lease capital payments of £13.2 million. Net cash generated from financing activities in prior periods primarily related to the issuances of Existing Notes. Net cash flows generated from financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 were £28.2 million, which was a result of the issue of additional Existing Notes, net of the capital element of property leases on a post-IFRS 16 basis. Net cash flows generated from financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2018 were £1.7 million, which was primarily a result of proceeds of amounts borrowed from other group companies, net of repayment of borrowings. 111 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsection Title: Qualitative and quantitative disclosures concerning market risk
Subsubsection Text: Market risk is the risk that future cash flows of a financial instrument will fluctuate because of changes in market prices. Pure Gym’s exposure to the risk of changes in market interest rates relates primarily to our longterm debt obligations with floating interest rates and interest rate derivatives. After giving effect to the Transactions, our only floating rate debt obligation will be any drawings under the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsection Title: Qualitative and quantitative disclosures concerning market risk
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity risk is the risk that Pure Gym will not be able to meet its financial obligations as they fall due. Ultimate responsibility for liquidity risk management rests with the Board. We manage liquidity risk by continuously monitoring forecast and actual cash flows, matching the maturity profiles of financial assets and operational liabilities and by maintaining adequate cash reserves. For additional detail, see “Summary—Recent _Developments—Impact of COVID-19” and “Summary—Recent Developments—Liquidity Update”._ Pure Gym’s exposures to liquidity risk are discussed in note 19 of our consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019, included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsection Title: Qualitative and quantitative disclosures concerning market risk
Subsubsection Text: Credit risk is the risk of financial loss to Pure Gym if a member or counterparty to a financial instrument fails to meet its contractual obligations. 113 ----- Pure Gym’s principal financial assets are bank balances and cash, trade and other receivables and investments. Pure Gym’s credit risk is limited primarily to trade receivables. The credit risk on liquid funds and derivative financial instruments is limited because the counterparties are banks with high credit ratings assigned by international credit-rating agencies. There is no significant concentration of credit risk, with exposure spread over a large number of counterparties and customers. Exposures to credit risk are discussed in note 19 of our consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019, included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsection Title: Qualitative and quantitative disclosures concerning market risk
Subsubsection Text: In the ordinary course of business, we are exposed to a variety of market risks including credit risk, liquidity risk and interest rate risk. We monitor and manage these risks as part of our overall risk management and seeks to minimize potential adverse effects on its financial position and performance. Pure Gym’s exposures to market risk are discussed in more detail in note 19 of our consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019, included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. This discussion does not address other risks to which we are exposed in the ordinary course of business, such as operational risks. See “Risk _Factors”._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsection Title: Critical accounting policies and estimates and forthcoming changes
Subsubsection Text: In the application of its accounting policies, Pure Gym is required to make judgements, estimates and assumptions that affect the application of our accounting policies and the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, income and expenses. The estimates and associated assumptions are based on historical experience and other factors that are considered to be relevant. Actual results may differ from these estimates. Significant accounting policies are set out in note 2 of our consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019, and significant accounting judgements, estimates and assumptions are set out in note 3 of our consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019, included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. 114 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PURE GYM
Subsubsection Text: _Financial information in this Offering Memorandum has been derived from the historical consolidated financial information of the Issuer and its consolidated subsidiaries and Topco and its consolidated subsidiaries as applicable. The Issuer is a public limited company incorporated on October 30, 2017, for the purpose of consummating the 2017 Acquisition and the related financing thereof. The Issuer conducts no business operations of its own and as of the Issue Date its only material assets will be its holding of the entire issued share capital of Topco and its consolidated subsidiaries, as well as rights and claims under intercompany financings. The following discussion and analysis of the financial condition and results of operations are based on the Pure Gym Financial Statements as of and for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2018 and 2019 and the Unaudited Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements for the six-month period ended June 30, 2020, all of which are reproduced elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. Accordingly, the discussion and analysis of historical periods does not reflect the significant impact that the Transactions will have on us. The Pure Gym Financial Statements as of and for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2018 and 2019 exclude the results of the Fitness World Group have been prepared in accordance with IFRS and have been audited by PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP. The Unaudited Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements, which were prepared in accordance with IAS 34 Interim Financial Reporting as adopted by the European Union, include the results of the Fitness World Group from January 14, 2020 and have not been audited and are not necessarily indicative of the results to be expected for the full year. The following discussion of our results of operations and financial conditions contains forward-looking statements. Our actual results could differ materially from those discussed in these forward-looking statements. Factors that could cause or contribute to such differences include those discussed below and elsewhere in this document, particularly under the sections headed “Risk Factors”, “Presentation of Financial and Other Data” and “Information Regarding Forward-Looking Statements”. In addition, certain industry issues also affect our results of operations and are described in “Industry Overview”. Prospective investors should read this section in conjunction with “Presentation of Financial and Other Data”, “Industry Overview”, “Business”, “Selected Consolidated Financial Information of Pure Gym” and “Capitalization”. Prospective investors should read the entire document. The financial information considered in this section is extracted from the financial information set out in “Selected Consolidated Financial Information of Pure Gym”._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF FITNESS WORLD
Subsection Title: Significant factors affecting our results of operations
Subsubsection Text: _Impact of COVID-19_ Similar to Pure Gym, we have experienced a material negative impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations as a result of COVID-19. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of _Financial Condition and Results of Operations of Pure Gym—Overview—Significant factors affecting our results of operations—Impact of COVID-19”. IFRS 16_ With respect to the 2019 Fitness World Financial Statements, Fitness World applied the new IFRS 16 (Leases) accounting standard, effective from January 1, 2019 using the “modified retrospective method”. Therefore, cumulative effects of applying this new accounting standard was recognized as an adjustment to retained earnings as of January 1, 2019 (the date of initial application), while comparative figures were not restated. IFRS 16 eliminates the classification of leases as either operating leases or finance leases and introduces a single lessee accounting model with some exemptions for short-term and low-value leases. The lessee recognizes a right-of-use asset representing its right to use the underlying asset and a lease liability representing its obligation to make lease payments. The effect of applying IFRS 16 was to align the presentation of leases more closely to that of owned assets, rent expense is no longer deducted in arriving at operating profit or Fitness World EBITDA and instead profit before tax includes an interest charge on the unwinding of the lease liability and a depreciation charge on the right of use asset. See Note 29 “Changes in accounting policies and disclosures” of the 2019 Fitness World Financial Statements. _Roll out of Fitness World clubs_ New gym openings have been a significant driver of our growth during the periods under review and our roll out strategy has had, and is expected to continue to have, a significant effect on our results of operations. We opened 15 gyms in 2018 and 15 gyms in 2019. _Maturity profile_ The following table shows gym cohort analysis for the period since 2016, as well as LTM Return on Capital Employed (“ROCE”) as of December 31, 2019. Inconsistencies in allocation of cost and cohorts means 115 ----- that 2016 was the first representative year for cohort analysis. For information regarding the calculation of EBITDA and ROCE, see “Presentation of Financial and Other Data—Non-IFRS Measures”.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF FITNESS WORLD
Subsubsection Text: Fitness World derives substantially all of its revenue from monthly membership fees and joining fees (90% of Fitness World revenue in the year ended December 31, 2019) paid by its members. Accordingly, our revenue is significantly dependent on membership volumes. Membership volumes are affected by numerous factors, including the total number of Fitness Worlds in operation, the prices of our membership offerings, the sizes and locations of our gyms, competitive dynamics in the value gym market and seasonality, amongst others. Our membership has grown from approximately 457,000 as of December 31, 2016 to approximately 589,000 as of December 31, 2019, representing a CAGR of 8.8%. This growth has been driven primarily by the opening of new gyms, the maturation of recent openings, and the acquisition of local independent gyms in both Denmark and Switzerland in 2018. The following table shows certain membership information for different categories of our gym portfolios for the periods indicated. New Gyms have lower membership levels than Mature Gyms as they have not reached maturity. 116 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF FITNESS WORLD
Subsubsection Text: (1) We define Mature Gym Adjusted EBITDA as profit for a certain period before income tax expense, net finance cost, depreciation of property, plant and equipment and right of use assets, amortization of intangible fixed assets, impairment of property, plant and equipment profit/loss on disposal of property, plant and equipment, profit/loss on lease modifications and exceptional administrative expenses for mature sites, after adding back the Cash Rent Adjustment and Pre-Opening Costs for mature sites and after adding back Head Office Costs. (2) We define Average Mature Gym Adjusted EBITDA as Mature Gym Adjusted EBITDA for a certain period divided by the number of Mature Gyms in that period. (3) We define Average Mature Gym Adjusted EBITDA Margin as Mature Gym Adjusted EBITDA for a certain period divided by the revenue attributable to Mature Gyms for that period. (4) We define Average Mature Gym ROCE as Mature Gym Adjusted EBITDA for a certain portfolio of gyms for a certain period divided by the Initial Capital Investment attributable to that portfolio of gyms. _Initial Capital Investment_ We incur capital costs to construct and fit out new gyms. The Average Initial Capital Investment for Mature Gyms for the year ended December 31, 2019 was DKK 5.0 million (£0.6 million). The Average Initial Capital Investment for New Gyms in the year ended December 31, 2019 was DKK 5.4 million (£0.6 million).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF FITNESS WORLD
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF FITNESS WORLD
Subsubsection Text: Our revenue is also dependent on the prices we charge on our offerings. Fitness World operates a semidynamic pricing model with the objective of maximizing each site’s revenue. To this end, membership fees are set on an individual gym basis and take into account a number of factors such as a gym’s membership level, its utilization profile, its capacity, the demographic profile of its local catchment and the degree of local competition, amongst others. See “Business—Members—Membership Pricing—Fitness World”. The following table sets forth the Average Revenue per Member per Month for the periods indicated. The figures exclude VAT and combine membership and ancillary revenues.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF FITNESS WORLD
Subsubsection Text: _Low-cost gym operating model_ Fitness World employs a low-cost, technology-enabled gym operating model, which enables Fitness World clubs to offer a compelling customer value proposition while simultaneously delivering strong operating margins and profitability. See “Business—Key Strengths—High cash flow generative profile underpinned by _exceptional profitability and positive working capital cash inflows”. The majority of site operating costs are_ controlled centrally and senior management is focused on leveraging our scale and implementing other initiatives to control costs and improve efficiencies. Site operating costs, other than property costs, are generally consistent across all Fitness Worlds and do not typically vary significantly between gyms. 117 ----- The following table sets out our gym site operating costs for the Mature Gym portfolio for the year ended December 31, 2019 on a post-IFRS 16 basis.

Going forward, we believe site level operating costs other than rent and depreciation will generally increase with inflation. _Head Office Costs_ We have made substantial investments in Head Office Costs over recent years to facilitate continued innovation and differentiation, to gain more control over certain key business functions, such as IT, and deliver the management and technology infrastructure to support our enlarged estate and future growth plans. These investments have included hiring additional staff as well as making investments in our management processes and IT systems to build and maintain an industry-leading technology platform. Although we expect to continue investing in our key business functions, we believe our infrastructure is now scalable and will deliver a reducing ratio to revenue as our growth continues.
