Subsubsection Text: Our income tax credit for the year ended December 31, 2019 was DKK 4.1 million compared to an expense of DKK 16.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was principally a result of an adjustment of DKK 7.9 million in the prior year related to the tax impact from a closed VAT audit in 2019 and was further impacted by changes in permanent differences, deductibles for interests and changes in taxable income. 118 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF FITNESS WORLD
Subsubsection Text: Fitness World experiences a small degree of seasonality. The majority of our membership growth takes place in January, February, September and October. Seasonality is generally positively driven by consumers’ desire to improve their fitness at the start of the year and the start of new university/school terms, and negatively driven by Christmas and summer holidays. We generally focus our marketing spend around peak joining periods, particularly the January/February period.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF FITNESS WORLD
Subsubsection Text: We believe that our central functions are now well invested and that Fitness World will be able to grow with more limited levels of incremental Head Office Cost investment in the medium term.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF FITNESS WORLD
Subsubsection Text: Revenue primarily comprises fitness club memberships, including joining fees and live group lessons. Membership fees and joining fees represented 90% of our total revenue for the year ended December 31, 2019. Monthly membership fees are recognized evenly over the month on a daily basis with deferred revenue recorded at the month end for any revenue that is to be recognized in the following month. Joining fees are recognized in the month of receipt, with the exception of joining fees received from members who sign up during the preopening period of a new gym, which are recognized as revenue in the month the relevant gym opens. We also generate revenue from sports nutrition drinks, vending sales, personal training sales, marketing contributions from suppliers and other ancillary activities, which together represented 10% of our total revenue for the year ended December 31, 2019. Revenue is stated excluding value added tax and other sales-related taxes. Our revenue was DKK 1,362.6 million and DKK 1,642.7 million for the years ended December 31, 2018 and 2019, respectively.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF FITNESS WORLD
Subsubsection Text: Other administrative expenses comprise the costs incurred in administering our operations, including employee costs, property lease rental costs (in 2018 only), marketing costs, other fixed property costs, other operating costs, head office costs, depreciation of property, plant and equipment and amortization of intangible assets. Gains and losses on disposals of property, plant and equipment are also included in other administrative expenses. Employee costs consist of wages and salaries, social security and pension costs. Property lease rental costs consist of property rental charges. Marketing costs comprise expenditure relating to attracting new members and retaining existing members. Other fixed property costs include rates, services charges, and other costs related to property. Other operating costs comprise repairs, maintenance, cleaning, insurance, security, and utilities expenses, and other costs. Depreciation of property, plant and equipment relates to depreciation of fixtures and fittings, leasehold improvements and fitness equipment for years 2017 and 2018 and also depreciation of right of use assets (on a post-IFRS 16 basis) for 2019. Capital costs are depreciated over six to eight years for fixtures, fittings and fitness equipment, three to 15 years for leasehold improvements and the life of the lease for leasehold costs and right of use assets. Initial Capital Investment is generally depreciated over a blended average useful life of nine years while refurbishment capital spend is generally depreciated over a blended average useful life of six years. Amortization includes amortization of intangible assets.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF FITNESS WORLD
Subsubsection Text: Special items include items that are material in size and unusual or infrequent in nature. The separate reporting of special items helps provide an indication of our underlying performance. In 2018, special items totalled DKK 36.3 million and primarily related to the merger and acquisition costs in connection with the acquisition of Basefit.ch AG as well as reorganization and implementation costs in connection with the European General Data Protection Regulation. In the year ended December 31, 2019, special items (net) totalled DKK 28.5 million principally including post-merger integration costs related to the acquisition of Basefit.ch AG, other M&A costs, internal restructuring costs and costs related to ongoing legal proceedings (including related provisions), which were partially offset by a gain related to the settlement of VAT claims.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF FITNESS WORLD
Subsubsection Text: Net finance costs are finance costs net of finance income. Finance costs represent the charges (accrued or paid) associated with bank loans and overdrafts, finance leases, interest rate derivatives and for 2019, finance costs associated with the unwinding of property lease liabilities on a post-IFRS 16 basis. Additionally, finance costs include the amortization of any fees associated with the raising of finance that have been capitalized. Finance 119 ----- costs are recognized using the effective interest method. Finance income consists of interest (accrued or paid) on cash held at the bank.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF FITNESS WORLD
Subsubsection Text: Income tax (charge)/credit comprises current and deferred tax. Current tax is the expected tax payable or receivable on the taxable income or loss for the year, using tax rates enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting date, and any adjustment to tax payable or receivable in respect of previous years. Deferred tax is recognized in respect of temporary differences between the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities for financial reporting purposes and the amounts used for taxation purposes. Deferred tax assets are recognized for unused tax losses, unused tax credits and deductible temporary differences to the extent that it is probable that future taxable profits will be available against which they can be used. For a description of the key elements of the line items of Fitness World’s income statement please refer to Notes of the 2019 Fitness World Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

Fitness World’s principal sources of liquidity have historically been its cash flow from operating activities and its banking facilities. Going forward, it will be intercompany loans from Pure Gym and its finance leases. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF FITNESS WORLD
Subsubsection Text: _Net cash flow from operating activities_ Fitness World’s net cash flows from operating activities comprise of its operating profit before interest, tax, profit/(loss) on disposals, depreciation, amortization and impairment charges, net of the movement in net working capital and less tax, exceptional costs paid, and net interest paid. Fitness World’s net cash flows from operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 were DKK 534.1 million, an increase of DKK 395.1 million, or 284%, compared to DKK 139 million in the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was principally a result of IFRS 16, which re-classified the capital element of lease payments as financing activities. Excluding the effect from IFRS 16, cash flows from operating activities would have been DKK 240 million, an increase of DKK 101 million, or 73%, which was primarily a result of increased earnings following the maturation of gym sites opened during the period and the full period effect from the acquisition of Basefit.ch AG. Fitness World’s net working capital of DKK (13.6) million and DKK (16.5) million for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2018 was primarily a result of increased inventories and payout of merger and acquisition costs accrued at the end of December 31, 2018. _Net cash flow from investing activities_ Net cash flows from investing activities consist of expenditure on property, plant and equipment and intangibles and amounts paid for acquisitions, less proceeds from disposals and the portion of any capital expenditure funded through finance leases. Net cash flows from investing activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 were DKK 164.0 million, which was a decline of DKK 319.2 million compared to DKK 483.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2018. This was mainly due to the acquisition of Basefit.ch AG and other smaller acquisitions made in 2018. Excluding the cash flow used for business acquisitions, cash flow from investing activities increased with DKK 52 million. The increased cash flow for investing activities excluding business acquisitions was primarily driven by investments in digital platform solutions. _Net cash flow from financing activities_ Fitness World’s net cash flows from financing activities consists of the drawdown and repayment of bank loans and finance leases. 122 ----- Net cash flows from financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 were DKK 385.6 million, which was primarily a result of IFRS 16 implementation, which re-classifies Fitness World’s rental payments as financing activities in the amount of DKK 326.0 million. Fitness World’s net payment on long-term debt facilities increased in 2019 compared to 2018 by DKK 59.3 million as a consequence of new loans in 2018 in connection with the acquisition of Basefit.ch AG. Net cash flows from financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2018 were DKK 333.6 million, which was primarily a result of new loans as part of the acquisition of Baseft.ch AG.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF FITNESS WORLD
Subsubsection Text: Our capital expenditures increased from DKK 155.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2018 to DKK 226.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2019 primarily as a result of new club openings in Denmark and Switzerland, refurbishment of existing clubs, and upgrading equipment and technology in clubs. Maintenance and Refurbishment Capital Expenditures also increased over the same period due to the growing portfolio of gyms. Fitness World maintains a comprehensive maintenance and refurbishment program for its gyms. Fitness World believes that the breakdown of the initial and ongoing capital expenditures consists of expenses in relation to furniture, fixtures and IT, equipment and leasehold costs.

Section Title: INDUSTRY OVERVIEW
Subsection Title: Overview of the UK health and fitness club market
Subsubsection Text: The UK health and fitness club market (including secondary income) has grown over the past four years from a total value of £3.9 billion as of December 2015 to £4.7 billion as of December 2019, reflecting a CAGR of 4.4% (Source: LDC Report). Over this same period, the number of health and fitness clubs grew from 6,312 to 7,239, reflecting a CAGR of 3.5%, while the number of health and fitness club members grew from 8.8 million to 10.4 million, reflecting a CAGR of 4.3% (Source: LDC Report). As of December 2019, 16% of the UK population was a member of a health and fitness club (Source: LDC Report). The 4.3% CAGR in health and fitness club members from December 2015 to December 2019 can be primarily attributed to the growth of value clubs and the increasing focus of UK consumers on health and wellbeing. This increasing focus on wellbeing is partially driven by consumers’ growing awareness of the significant benefits of a healthy lifestyle, as well as government initiatives such as “Change4Life”, a public health program that began in 2009 to tackle unhealthy lifestyles by encouraging exercise and healthy eating, and “This Girl Can”, an award-winning campaign launched in January 2015 to encourage more women in England to take part in sports and physical activity. Operators are also diversifying gym locations into less populated areas targeting smaller population catchment areas, supporting growth in penetration rates. Other factors have also contributed to the growth of the market over the past five years, including modest population growth, increases in consumers’ disposable incomes and innovation and new technology in fitness. The UK health and fitness club market is split into two main segments: public clubs and private clubs. The private clubs segment can be further split into: (i) premium clubs; (ii) mid-market clubs and (iii) value clubs. The below table shows the total number of clubs and total number of members within the UK health and fitness club market split by these segments. _Number of clubs and members in the UK health and fitness club market and market value as of December, 2019 (Source: LDC Report)_

Section Title: INDUSTRY OVERVIEW
Subsubsection Text: Public clubs are those funded and operated by local authorities or county councils. They are typically larger in size compared to private clubs and offer a wide variety of facilities such as sports halls, studios and swimming pools. Some public clubs are managed or operated by private companies on behalf of local authorities and county councils. Public clubs are generally open to members of the public on a pay-and-play or membership basis. As of December 2019, there were 2,729 public clubs with a total of 3.4 million members, equivalent to an average of 1,239 members per club. On average, public clubs charged monthly membership fees of £29 as of December 2019 (Source: LDC Report). The number of public clubs decreased marginally over December 2015 to December 2019 from 2,762 to 2,729, while the number of public club members increased from 3.3 million to 3.4 million, reflecting a CAGR of 0.4%, and the revenue earned by the public club market increased from £1.2 billion to £1.3 billion, reflecting a CAGR of 1.5%. The three largest public club operators in the United Kingdom (by number of clubs) are Greenwich Leisure Limited, Sports and Leisure Management Ltd. (trading as Everyone Active) and Places for People Leisure (Source: LDC Report). The public club market in Denmark is mainly operated in smaller cities in connection with a local sports club. Public clubs are those funded and operated by local authorities. They are typically smaller in size compared to private clubs and offer a wide variety of facilities such as sports halls, studios and swimming pools. Some public clubs are managed or operated by private companies on behalf of local authorities and county councils. As 132 ----- of December 2019, there were 537 public clubs with a total of 150 thousand members, equivalent to an average of 280 members per club. On average, public clubs charged monthly membership fees of £20 in 2019 (Source: _OC&C Report) The number of public clubs remained largely constant over December 2015 to December 2019,_ while the number of public club members decreased from 247 thousand to 150 thousand, and the market value of the public club market decreased from £59 million to £37 million.

Section Title: INDUSTRY OVERVIEW
Subsubsection Text: Private clubs are those funded and operated by commercial enterprises. The private club market is significantly larger than the public club market, with approximately 4,510 clubs and 7.0 million members (Source: _LDC Report), equivalent to an average of approximately 1,554 members per club as of December 2019. On_ average, private clubs charged monthly membership fees of £37 as of December 2019 (Source: LDC Report). The number of private clubs increased from 3,550 as of December 2015 to 4,510 as of December 2019, reflecting a CAGR of 6.2% (Source: LDC Report). Over this same period, the number of private club members grew from 5.5 million to 7.0 million, reflecting a CAGR of 6.5%, while private club revenue has increased from £2.7 billion to £3.4 billion, reflecting a CAGR of 5.6% (Source: LDC Report). The growth in the private club market over the past four years was primarily driven by the growth of value clubs. The private club market is fragmented, and the ten largest private club operators only accounted for 25% of the private club market (by number of gyms) as of December 2019. (Source: LDC Report). 128 ----- _Top 10 private club operators in the United Kingdom by number of members as of December, 2019 (Source: LDC_ Report, public filings) Private clubs are those funded and operated by commercial enterprises. The private club market is significantly larger than the public club market, with 889 clubs and 947 thousand members (Source: OC&C _Report), equivalent to an average of approximately 1,065 members per club. On average, private clubs charged_ monthly membership fees of £23 in 2019 (Source: OC&C Report). The number of private clubs increased from 762 as of December 2015 to 889 as of December 2019, reflecting a CAGR of 3.9% (Source: OC&C Report). Over this same period, the number of private club members grew from 756 thousand to 947 thousand, reflecting a CAGR of 5.8%, while private club market value increased from £241 million to £289 million, reflecting a CAGR of 4.7% (Source: OC&C Report). The growth in the private club market over the past four years was primarily driven by the growth of value clubs. The ten largest private club operators accounted for 54% of the private club market (by number of gyms) as of December 2019. (Source: OC&C Report). Section Title: INDUSTRY OVERVIEW
INDUSTRY OVERVIEW
Subsubsection Text: As compared to mid-market and premium private clubs, value clubs typically charge lower monthly membership fees, do not require their members to enter into fixed duration contracts, provide a smaller range of facilities and have longer opening hours. Mid-market and premium clubs are generally larger in size and usually contain a wider range of facilities including, for example, wet areas (e.g. swimming pools, spas and saunas), racquet sports courts (e.g. tennis courts and squash courts), and social areas for members (e.g. bars and cafes), in addition to standard gym equipment and exercise classes. As of December 2019, there were 3,827 mid-market/Premium clubs in the UK with 4.2 million members, equivalent to an average of 1.1 members per club. Members are often required to sign up to fixedduration membership contracts, which typically include early termination fees. Mid-market and premium clubs generally have higher operating costs than value clubs due to their larger size, increased number of facilities offered, greater number of staff (e.g. in-gym sales and marketing teams and 129 ----- fully staffed reception and refreshment areas) and higher maintenance costs (e.g. cleaning and maintenance of wet areas). Value clubs (consisting of “low cost” clubs as defined by LDC) are private clubs that in general charge £25 or less per month across the majority of clubs in the chain. Value clubs offer a more focused product that is designed for consumers who only want to pay for and use fitness equipment (e.g. cardiovascular machines, fixed resistance machines, free-weights and fitness studios), rather than wet facilities such as swimming pools. Accordingly, only 5% of value clubs offer wet facilities as compared to 32% for UK private club operators (Source: LDC Report). Members of value clubs are generally not required to sign up to fixed-duration membership contracts and can in general cancel their memberships at any time without material financial consequence. Value clubs also generally have longer opening hours than traditional private clubs (e.g., the majority of Pure Gyms are open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week and 365 days a year (“24x7x365 access”)). The largest value club operators are Pure Gym and The Gym. (Source: LDC Report). The value club market has experienced rapid growth over the past five years. Since December 2015, the number of value clubs increased from 319 to 683 as of December 2019, reflecting a CAGR of 21.0%, while the number of value club members grew from 1.3 million to 2.8 million, reflecting a CAGR of 21.1% (Source: LDC _Report). While value clubs only represented 9.4% of the total number of health and fitness clubs in the UK as of_ December 2019, they represented 26.9% of the total number of health and fitness club members. This is because value clubs have a substantially higher number of average members per club which was 4,100 members, as compared to both mid-market and premium clubs with 1,100 members. (Source: LDC Report). _Number of clubs and members in the private UK health and fitness club market by price segment as of December 2015 and December 2019 (Source: LDC Report)_

Section Title: INDUSTRY OVERVIEW
INDUSTRY OVERVIEW
Subsubsection Text: As illustrated above, the number of private clubs grew from 3,550 as of December 2015 to 4,510 as of December 2019, reflecting a CAGR of 6.2%. Similarly, the number of private club members grew from 5.5 million to 7.0 million over the same period, reflecting a CAGR of 6.5%. The growth of the private club market over the past five years has largely been driven by the growth of value clubs. From December 2015 to December 2019, the number of value club members increased from 1.3 million to 2.8 million, reflecting a CAGR of 21.1%. While the number of mid-market / premium club members grew modestly over the same period. Between December 2015 and December 2019 the number of mid-market / premium club members grew from 4.15 million to 4.21 million, reflecting a CAGR of negative 0.4%. This low growth is due to the competitive headwinds caused by the growth of value clubs and a number of mid-market operators exiting the market or downsizing their portfolios (e.g. LA Fitness was acquired by Pure Gym in 2015). 130 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY OVERVIEW
Subsubsection Text: The number of value clubs and value club members increased significantly over the past four years and as of December 2019, there were 683 value clubs in the UK with 2.8 million members (Source: LDC Report). As a result of the strong growth in value club gyms and members, the revenues received in the value club market increased rapidly over December 2015 to December 2019 from £0.3 billion to £0.6 billion, a CAGR of 23.3% (Source: LDC Report). Despite this strong growth, value clubs still only represented 9.4% of the total number of health and fitness clubs in the UK as of December 2019 (Source: LDC Report). _UK Penetration Rate of value clubs and number of value clubs (Source: LDC Report)_ 1,000 5.0% 4.2% 800 3.7% 4.0% 3.3% 683 598 600 2.7% 3.0% 515 450 2.0% 400 2.0% 319 200 1.0% 0 0.0% Dec 2015 Dec 2016 Dec 2017 Dec 2018 Dec 2019 The private club market has historically been served primarily by mid-market and premium private clubs. However, value clubs have made a significant entrance into the market by taking market share from mid-market clubs and growing the overall number of private club members by attracting new consumers to the market that have not previously been members of health and fitness clubs. We believe that value clubs have been able to take market share because they offer a more affordable, flexible and “value for money” product than other private clubs. According to a consumer survey conducted by the CSR Report on our behalf in January 2016, 27%, 27% and 26% of consumers surveyed listed their primary reason for selecting a gym as proximity, price and value for money, respectively. We also believe that value clubs have been able to grow the overall number of private club members as value clubs address the most significant barriers to UK consumers taking on gym memberships (high membership fees and the desire not to enter into a fixed-duration membership contract) and appeal to a broad range of consumers. The recent shift in UK consumer trends towards “value for money” is also prevalent in other industries such as the supermarket industry where value operators such as Lidl and Aldi have taken market share from incumbent mid-market operators such as Wm Morrison and Tesco, and in the airline industry where value carriers, such as EasyJet and Ryanair, have taken market share from traditional premium airlines such as British Airways. An underlying element of this trend is the simplicity and consistency of a high-quality, yet affordable offering that aims to perfect the core product with “no frills”, akin to Premier Inn or Travelodge in the hospitality sector. Despite expansion of the value segment over the past years, there is significant opportunity for growth of value operators in the UK. There is an estimated potential for 1,200 – 1,400 low cost gyms in the UK (Source: _PwC UK Low Cost Gyms Report), supported by overall increase in gym memberships penetration rates and_ increasingly polarized landscape of lower and higher cost options.

Section Title: INDUSTRY OVERVIEW
Subsubsection Text: The table below shows the ten largest value club operators in the UK. Pure Gym is the largest value club operator (263 clubs and 1,135,000 members as of December 2019 (Source: Management data)) and is 1.4 times larger (by number of members) than the second largest value club operator, The Gym (Source: Company _information). There can be significant differences in the product offering of value club operators. For example,_ only Pure Gym and The Gym generally offer 24x7x365 access to clubs. In addition, certain value operators, such as Xercise4Less, require a contractual commitment to receive the lowest available monthly membership fee rate. Furthermore, Pure Gym clubs generally have dedicated group exercise studios, including purpose built 131 ----- stationary cycling studios and offer a wide variety of instructor led exercise classes in such studios, while The Gym’s clubs generally do not. _Top 5 value gym operators in the UK by number of members as of December 2019. (Source: LDC Report)._

Section Title: INDUSTRY OVERVIEW
Subsection Title: Overview of the Danish health and fitness club market
Subsubsection Text: The Danish health and fitness club market has grown over the past four years from a total value of £300 million as of December 2015 to £326 million (converted using the rate of GBP 1.17109 to €1.0000 as at December 31, 2019, sourced from Oanda.com). As of December 2019, reflecting a CAGR of 2.1% (Source: OC&C Report). Over this same period, the number of health and fitness clubs grew from 1,299 to 1,426, reflecting a CAGR of 2.4%, while the number of health and fitness club members grew from 1.0 million to 1.1 million, reflecting a CAGR of 2.3% (Source: OC&C Report). As of December 2019, 19% of the Danish population was a member of a health and fitness club (Source: OC&C Report). The 2.3% CAGR in health and fitness club members from December 2015 to December 2019 reflects continuing volume migration towards the value segment and stabilization in market growth as the market reaches a higher maturity. On June 8, 2020, Danish gyms were able to re-open and membership trends in customers returning to our gyms have been positive, with 93% like-for-like paying members and 92% like-for-like member visits (as of October 18, 2020) in each case as compared to the same point in 2019. As for the UK market, the value segment growth is expected to be stimulated by the less favourable economic outlook in the years ahead. The Danish health and fitness club market is split into two main segments: public clubs and private clubs. The private clubs segment can be further split into: (i) premium clubs; (ii) mid-market clubs and (iii) value clubs. The table below shows the total number of clubs and total number of members within the Danish health and fitness club market split by these segments. We also believe that value clubs have been able to grow the overall number of private club members as value clubs address the most significant barriers to consumers taking on gym memberships (high membership fees and the desire not to enter into a fixed-duration membership contract) and appeal to a broad range of consumers (Source: CSR _Report)._

Subsubsection Text: The table below shows the ten largest value club operators in Denmark. Fitness World is the largest value club operator (185 clubs and approximately 485,690 members as of December 31, 2019 (Source: Management _data)) and is significantly larger than other value gym operators in Denmark such as Loop (approximately_ 110,000 members) and Sport og Fitness (approximately 26,000 members) (Source: OC&C Report). There can be significant differences in positioning of value club operators. For example, Loop focuses on circuit training and targets mainly elder population and Sport og Fitness functions has both normal and corporate gyms. Fitness World offers one of the lowest monthly fees available in the segment and broad product offering. (Source: _OC&C Report). Top 6 value gym operators in the Denmark by number of members[)] as of December 2019. (Source: OC&C Report)._
