Section Title: INDUSTRY OVERVIEW
Subsection Title: Overview of the Swiss health and fitness club market
Subsubsection Text: The Swiss health and fitness club market has grown over the past four years from a total value of £0.7 billion as of December 2015 to £0.8 billion as of December 2019, reflecting a CAGR of 2.3%. Over this same period, the number of health and fitness club members grew from 1.07 million to 1.16 million, reflecting a CAGR 136 ----- of 1.9%. As of December 2019, 14% of the Swiss population was a member of a health and fitness club (Source: _OC&C Report)._ The 1.9% CAGR in health and fitness club members from December 2015 to December 2019 reflects population growth driven by continued net positive immigration and penetration rate growth driven by increased fitness supply and health consciousness. The Swiss fitness market benefitted from a timely re-opening after a period of lockdown as of May 11, 2020. Because the Swiss market has been reopen longer than our other markets, membership trends in customers returning to our gyms have been increasingly positive, with like-for-like paying member levels reaching 93% and like-for-like member visits reaching 92% (as of October 18, 2020) in each case as compared to the same point in 2019. Switzerland has the highest average gym/fitness club membership fees in Europe (£51 / month vs. average of £28 / month), due to the high wage and price level in Switzerland (converted to GBP using the year end specific rate of EUR 1.1711 to £1.00000 as at December 31, 2019, sourced from Oanda.com). The Swiss market also has a smaller low-cost segment than similarly developed European markets (e.g. Northern Europe) (Source: OC&C Report). Value segment market share of approximately 23% (Source: OC&C Report) as of December 2019 in the Swiss fitness market is lower compared to European average or similarly developed countries (e.g. Northern Europe). Value segment share is historically low driven by limited availability due to the lack of major players in the market. The top 7 operators in the Swiss fitness market account for approximately 25% of the total membership base (Source: OC&C Report). Most health and fitness club operators in Switzerland offer fixed contracts of 12 months, requesting upfront membership fee payments. Basefit is the first to offer monthly rolling memberships in Switzerland. 137 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY OVERVIEW
Subsubsection Text: _The information in the following section has been provided for background purposes. The information has been extracted from a variety of sources released by public and private organizations. The industry information has been accurately reproduced and, as far as we are aware and are able to ascertain from information published by such sources, no facts have been omitted which would render the reproduced information inaccurate or misleading. Throughout 2020, COVID-19 caused unprecedented disruption to our industry. Any forward-looking statements contained in the industry and market data presented below were made prior to the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic (except where stated otherwise) and have not been updated to account for the impact of such pandemic. There can be no assurance that such forward-looking statements would not have been materially different if the COVID-19 pandemic had been taken into account. See “Information Regarding Forward-Looking Statements”._ Throughout the first ten months of 2020, the global COVID-19 pandemic surfaced in nearly all regions around the world, resulting in governments in affected areas taking unprecedented steps by enforcing lockdowns, in each case leading to business slowdowns and shutdowns. The spread of COVID-19 has had a material negative impact on the fitness industry, resulting in the temporary closure of a substantial number of gyms, which has led to an overall slowdown of the fitness market. Due to the closure of gyms, operators have increasingly frozen memberships in order to retain members, but have effectively ceased to generate revenue throughout the lockdown periods. As a consequence, gym operators have had to shift attention and resources from managing their business in an attractive environment to managing their cash burn rates in order to maintain sufficient liquidity during the lockdown period. Globally, various operators have not managed to retain sufficient capital and smaller, less profitable gym operators such as Xercise4Less and DW Fitness, in particular have experienced financial distress or filed for bankruptcy. In many regions, governments have offered support packages to support businesses and employees that are unable to operate due to COVID-19. Being among the most impacted industries, the fitness industry has benefitted from government support in many instances. These support measures include, but are not limited to, job-retention schemes, tax deferrals, business rates holidays and loan schemes. In addition, many operators have renegotiated their lease agreements, resulting in landlords allowing rent reductions and rent deferrals to share the burden of non-operating gym facilities. For more information about the risks associated with the impact of subsequent waves of COVID-19 and lockdowns on our ability to minimize cash burn via government aid, see “Risk Factors—The negative impact of COVID-19 on our business is significant and its effects will continue to _materially negatively impact our business, financial condition and results of operations due to many factors, some of which are beyond our control”._ Following the initial easing of the initial lockdowns towards the end of the summer of 2020, our industry was focused on re-opening. The first weeks of re-opening displayed positive membership trends in many regions, with a study conducted in Norway providing evidence that going to the gym does not increase the risk of becoming infected with COVID-19. In a swift response to the lockdowns, gym operators have quickly increased physical distancing between members by spacing equipment apart, in addition to introducing limits on the number of people using the facilities and enhanced cleaning protocols. At present, a "second wave" of the pandemic is currently underway across Europe, with many jurisdictions reimposing restrictions on movement, opening hours and required safety measures, all of which have impacted our industry. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, our industry is in the process of assessing the evolving COVID-19 situation, including an ongoing "second wave" across Europe, which remains dynamic and varied across and within the different countries in which we operate, including preparing for potential future local and national lockdowns. Regardless of the industry and governmental measures taken over the past months, the pandemic will have a lasting impact on industry dynamics post-lockdown. As a result of some operators struggling to re-open after business closures, there are expected to be opportunities for surviving operators to acquire the members that will be in search of a new gym as supply may be limited while the pandemic takes its toll on operators in the industry. A few of our competitors have already announced sale and closure, while others have been sold into administration shortly before or after reopening, and a few other competitors have either already faced liquidity issues or will possibly face liquidity issues in the near future due to lack of access to capital. 124 ----- The closure of other gym operators could lead to increased market share for the existing players. According to company information, these closures have already resulted in increased operational performance for Pure Gyms, as shown in the charts below: The charts above present a select number of Pure Gyms that we believe are currently drawing demand away from other, nearby gyms that have recently closed down or not reopened after the end of the first national lockdown period. Within the industry, there has been a rising trend of customers moving towards value operators and this trend is expected to accelerate in the near-term, as it did following the 2008 financial crisis, with consumer demand for the access to gyms, and particularly for access to Pure Gyms, likely to remain strong. According to a Sport England Survey of 311 respondents who were gym members as of May 4, 2020, 86% indicated that they would be likely to take out a gym membership. In the same survey of 1,575 respondents who were not gym members as of May 4, 2020, only 29% indicated that they would be likely to take out a gym membership, with the majority of cancellations in the non-gym member group being due to COVID-19 related reasons. The Sport England Survey also underscored the propensity of the younger demographic (ages 16-34) to want to start a gym membership following lockdown. Currently, 32% of total Pure Gym members are in the 16-24 age cohort and 36% are in the 25-34 age cohort, suggesting that our younger demographic is more likely to continue their gym membership across our estate. 125 ----- The recessionary environment that has resulted from months of lockdown is expected to further drive consumers to consider their gym budget and the value segment offers an attractive lower monthly cost. In addition, members are deemed less likely to be willing to engage in long-term contracts, as their spending budget generally remains uncertain throughout a crisis. The charts below demonstrate consumers’ willingness to continue spending on value gym offerings in a recessionary environment, as well as the leisure sub-sector’s overall growth during the prior economic downturn. Sources: Euromonitor, ONS, Mintel, LDC, OC&C analysis. 1. OC&C conducted a consumer survey in May 2017. The respondents were asked the following question: “Which of the following items would you be most likely to reduce spending on in the event of an economic downturn (Rank top 5)”. N = 1,779. Although a possible recession could change the dynamics in the fitness industry, the expectation is that members will continue to be willing to go the gym. Based on survey results, consumers were strongly considering going back to the gym at re-opening, which also reflects in the first months of data since re-opening. This is partly driven by the increased awareness of the importance of physical and mental well-being in a world shaken by a pandemic, which is strengthened by the extensive safety protocols operators have put in place. During lockdown there was, understandably, a rapid growth in consumers accessing online- and home-workout content. Although companies focused on these markets have benefitted from this trend, survey results show that users do not all view this as a replacement for the gym. Instead, alternative workout possibilities (online, at home, etc.) are expected to complement gym memberships, leading to a more integrated gym experience both offline and online. Gym operators also stand to benefit from online offerings as many have increased their online applications and virtual workouts. This could benefit gym operators by providing opportunities to further engage with their member base and help offset some of the costs of the lockdown. Prior to the COVID-19 outbreak, Pure Gym and Fitness World were operating in an attractive and growing market, within which the growing value segment continues to have a favourable outlook. The European health and fitness club market had a market value of £24.0 billion as of December 2019 (Source: OC&C Report) and fitness club memberships continue to increase across most of the European geographies. The European health and fitness club market covers 33 countries including Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, Russia, Ukraine and the UK. Over the four years from December 2015 to December 2019, members of the European fitness market increased from 54 million to 65 million, which reflects a compound annual growth rate (“CAGR”) of 4.5% (Source: OC&C Report). In the UK, the health and fitness club market continues to benefit from the UK population becoming more health-conscious and from various government initiatives designed to promote healthy living and active lifestyles. Further stimulation of mental and physical well-being is expected in the aftermath of COVID-19. The 126 ----- UK health market has also benefitted from the increasing prevalence of value gyms, which have increased the availability of fitness facilities to a larger proportion of the population. The value gym market share increased from 7% to 13% over the past four years between December 2015 and December 2019, as a percentage of total market value (Source: LDC Report, OC&C Report). Historically, the UK health and fitness market has been served by mid-market and premium private gym operators and by public gym operators. While the value gym segment has grown quickly over the past several years, we believe there remains significant opportunity for further growth due to value gyms’ broad consumer appeal, even more so in a recessionary environment. Currently, 16% of the United Kingdom population is a member of a gym, which is below equivalent penetration rates in Sweden (22%), Norway (22%) and the U.S. (20%) (Source: OC&C Report). In Denmark 19% of the Danish population are gym members, and in Switzerland and Poland it is 14% and 8% respectively indicating that further growth is possible in all of our markets. In Denmark, market share of the value segment increased from 44% to 57% over the past four years between 2015 and 2019, as a percentage of total market value. The high market share of value gyms is mainly driven by the clear leadership position of Fitness World in Denmark. The value gym market has demonstrated resilience during periods of economic decline and can also support growth in these conditions as consumers consider cost-conscious alternatives. Consumer spending on gyms has shown resilience during periods of decreased overall economic activity, as demonstrated by a 2.1% CAGR in total gym spend in the UK health and fitness club market between 2006 and 2012, during which period total gym spend did not fall during any individual year. From 2008 to 2012, value gyms grew significantly, with membership increasing by a CAGR of 121% (Source: LDC Report, OC&C Report).

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Pure Gym has a powerful and highly disruptive customer proposition that is differentiated from traditional gym operators and appeals to a broad range of consumers. The key elements of the proposition include affordable membership fees, no fixed term contracts and 24x7x365 access to high-quality gyms. The proposition is underpinned by the differentiated, capital efficient and technology-enabled gym operating model, which enables Pure Gyms to support high levels of membership, operate on low costs and generate strong unit economics, cash flow conversion and ROCE. As of December 31, 2019, Pure Gym operated 263 gyms in cities and towns across the UK, including 68 gyms within greater London, and had 1,134,683 members overall.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Since it was founded in 2005, Fitness World has disrupted the Danish fitness market with its convenient, value-for-money, flexible offer. Fitness World has a market-leading position in Denmark with an estimated 43% market share measured by members as of December 2019 (Source: Deloitte/EuropeActive Report). With a clear focus on property and ecosystem management, Fitness World created a smart footprint across cities with a complementary offering across clubs, creating local barriers to entry and satisfying the number one key purchasing criteria, which is proximity (Source: Fitness World Acquisition Report). 139 ----- Fitness World is a household name with membership including close to 10% of the population over the age of 14 in Denmark (as of December 31, 2019) and is proud of the contribution it has made to public health. Fitness World’s inclusive vision is to promote “healthy habits for all” and thereby enable people from all walks of life to live a healthier lifestyle through fitness training. As of December, 31, 2019, Fitness World had 185 gyms and 485,690 members overall in Denmark. For the year ended December 31, 2019, Fitness World generated revenue of DKK 1,362.1 million (£159.8 million) and Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of DKK 365.8 (£42.9 million) from its operations in Denmark, representing 83% of Fitness World’s total Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Fitness World entered the Swiss market in 2018 by acquiring Basefit, the second largest gym operator and the leading value operator in Switzerland. In 2019, Basefit was the first player in the Swiss market to offer a flexible monthly membership option, BaseFree, which has been well received by the market as 45% of joiners have opted for BaseFree since its launch in December 2019. As of December 31, 2019, Basefit was the largest Swiss value operator with 39 gyms and 78,677 members and a member churn rate of 46%. Prior to its acquisition by Fitness World, Basefit generated revenue of £11 million and had a Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of £4 million for the year ended December 31, 2016. This increased to revenue of £16 million and a Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of £6 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. Following its acquisition by Fitness World, Basefit’s revenue increased to £21 million and its Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA was £6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. Fitness World has continued to invest in the Basefit brand and its operations in Switzerland. For the year ended December 31, 2019, Basefit generated revenue of DKK 232.7 million (£27.3 million) and Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of DKK 69.0 (£8.1 million) from its operations in Switzerland, representing 16% of Fitness World’s total Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: In 2015, Fitness World entered Poland by acquiring Condizione and its three fitness clubs and has since grown organically through bolt-on acquisitions. In light of the government mandated closure of our Polish gyms, we have taken the strategic view that we will not be investing additional Group resources in our Polish business at this time. Consequently, we have decided to cease operating in Poland. Our Polish subsidiary has applied to the Polish courts to open an insolvency proceeding under Polish bankruptcy laws with the goal of appointing a trustee to oversee the orderly distribution of our Polish assets. For the year ended December 31, 2019, Fitness World generated revenue of DKK 46.9 million (£5.5 million) and Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of DKK 6.2 million (£0.7 million) from its operations in Poland, representing 1% of Fitness World's Total Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: On January 14, 2020, our business combined Pure Gym, a value gym operator that has rapidly become the largest operator of gyms in the United Kingdom both by number of gyms and members, and Fitness World, a leading European gym and value fitness operator with sites across Denmark and Switzerland. We believe that the Combined Group has strong growth prospects and common core competencies, including shared market leadership positions in the UK and Denmark, an inclusive philosophy, a modern technology-enabled customer offer based on high-quality, affordable gyms that can be accessed on a flexible basis, and a strong platform for expansion. Our vision is to provide affordable, flexible, and “value-for-money” memberships to high-quality gyms to all people who want to increase their level of fitness, as demonstrated by our inclusive “everybody welcome” philosophy. In response to COVID-19, governments globally (including within the markets in which we operate) have implemented strict social distancing measures, including varied approaches to lockdowns and closures of non-essential businesses, including ours. COVID-19 presents an unprecedented disruption to our business, and the wide variations in potential outcomes present a material challenge to our business and our industry. We believe that we have taken and are taking appropriate actions in response to COVID-19 in line with relevant government guidance and we continue to take every step that we believe is prudent to protect and manage our business, control our cost base and protect our operating cash flows. See “Summary—Recent Developments—Impact of _COVID-19”. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, it is not possible to accurately predict the short-,_ medium- or long-term impacts of COVID-19 on our business and our industry. Our strategic mission continues to be providing affordable and flexible memberships to high-quality fitness facilities balanced against the pressures of the macroeconomic environment in which we operate. Upon our acquisition of Fitness World, we were the market-leading operator in the Danish market, with a growing presence in Switzerland and amongst value operators in Europe, were number two by number of sites value operator in Europe and number three by revenue and member numbers. We believe that the strategic rationale for the acquisition of Fitness World remains intact for the long-term despite the significant immediate challenges faced in a COVID-19 world. For the year ended December 31, 2019, we derived 57% of our revenue from our operations in the UK, 36% from our operations in Denmark, 6% from operations in Switzerland and 1% from our operations in Poland. Our key geographic markets are the UK and Denmark and as such, Pure Gym and Fitness World will continue operating under their existing brand names in these key markets. As of December 31, 2019, the Combined Group operated 504 gyms in cities and towns across the four countries, with Pure Gym accounting for 52% of clubs and Fitness World accounting for 48% of clubs, and had approximately 1.7 million members in total. 138 ----- The table below displays the key European gym operators by number of members: (‘000 Members) (1) Source: Company information and Deloitte/EuropeActive Report. (2) Pure Gym excludes pre-opening members and includes members at Pure Gym branded gyms only. (3) Pure Gym, Fitness World and The Gym Group data is as of December 2019; Basic-Fit data is as of Q3 2019. Members of other operators are as per latest estimates included in the Deloitte/EuropeActive Report. Fitness World is a good strategic fit for Pure Gym due to its aligned low-cost operating model. The Combined Group is the third largest operator in Europe by membership and the second largest by number of gyms. With leading market positions in the UK and Denmark and as the second largest player in Switzerland, the Combined Group is a market-leading European value gym operator with diversification and scale benefits. Our disruptive customer value proposition, differentiated business model and well-managed growth strategy has allowed us to grow rapidly. For the year ended December 2019, the Combined Group generated revenue of £447.5 million and a Combined Group Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of £161.2 million after giving pro _forma effect to the Acquisition. In the same timeframe, Pure Gym’s UK operations generated revenue of £255_ million and Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of £105 million, representing growth of 12.1% and 41.0%, respectively, as compared to the previous year end.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Title: Attractive and resilient fitness market driven by established trends towards the value segment
Subsubsection Text: Pure Gym and Fitness World operate in an attractive and growing market within which the value segment is growing. The European health and fitness club market had a market value of £21.9 billion as of December 2019 (Source: OC&C Report) and fitness club memberships continue to increase across most of the European geographies. Over the four years from December 2015 to December 2019, members of the European fitness market increased from 54 million to 65 million, which reflects a compound annual growth rate of 4.5% (Source: _OC&C Report)._ In the UK, the health and fitness club market continues to benefit from the UK population becoming more health-conscious and from various government initiatives designed to promote healthy living and active lifestyles. The UK health market has also benefitted from the increasing prevalence of value gyms, which have increased the availability of fitness facilities to a larger proportion of the population. The value gym market share increased from 7% to 13% over the past four years between December 2015 and December 2019, as a percentage of total market value (Source: LDC Report, OC&C Report). Historically, the UK health and fitness market has been served by mid-market and premium private gym operators and by public gym operators. While the value gym segment has grown quickly over the past several years, we believe there remains significant opportunity for further growth due to value gyms’ broad consumer 140 ----- appeal. Currently, 16% of the United Kingdom population is a member of a gym, which is below equivalent penetration rates in Sweden (22%), Norway (21%) and the U.S. (20%) (Source: OC&C Report). There remains room for growth in gym market penetration in Denmark and Switzerland, with only 19% of the Danish population and 14% of the Swiss population having a gym membership. In Denmark, market share of the value segment increased from 45% to 56% over the past four years between 2015 and 2019, as a percentage of total market value. The high market share of value gyms is mainly driven by the clear leadership position of Fitness World in Denmark. The value gym market has demonstrated resilience during periods of economic decline and can also support growth in these conditions as consumers consider cost-conscious alternatives. Consumer spending on gyms has shown resilience during periods of decreased overall economic activity, as demonstrated by a 2.1% CAGR in total gym spend in the UK health and fitness club market between 2006 and 2012, during which period total gym spend did not fall during any individual year. From 2008 to 2012, value gyms grew significantly, with membership increasing by a CAGR of 12.1% (Source: LDC Report, OC&C Report). Throughout 2020, the COVID-19 pandemic caused unprecedented disruption to our everyday way of life and to our industry. Only those operators with the strong liquidity positions have been able to withstand a period of extended closure and therefore we anticipate some supply will exit the market as weaker operators fail. We believe demand will continue to be strong given the increased focus on health and well-being post COVID-19. We continue to believe we have the right business model, operating in the right market segment to be highly successful in a post-COVID-19 environment in the medium to long term.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Title: Clear market leader in the value segment
Subsubsection Text: We are one of the pioneering operators of value gyms in Europe and have been a leading contributor towards the growth of the value gym market over the past decade. Our scale and market leading position provide us with significant competitive advantages, including: _Commercial Offer—Our leading footprint of 263 gyms in the UK and 185 gyms in Denmark as of_ December 31, 2019 enables us to offer our members multi-site access in many locations. In addition, our scale enables us to pursue partnerships and other commercial arrangements that further differentiate our product offering and value proposition. _Property Acquisition—We have historically had a strong landlord covenant rating and have benefitted_ from “tenant of choice” status given our scale, strong brand and high quality product. As a result, we are generally able to secure our selected sites on attractive lease terms throughout the UK and Denmark. _Technology—We have invested heavily in building out our digital presence and software engineering_ teams and third-party technology relationships. As a result, we have a high and increasing degree of control over, and the ability to improve, our web, mobile and application-based offerings. We believe this will help reduce costs and increase revenues over time, particularly following the integration of technological systems between Pure Gym and Fitness World. Key features of our technology include: - Website and dedicated apps that, among other things, provide members the ability to enrol and upgrade into the various membership packages, utilize nutrition and exercise guides, view workout videos, find and book classes, see how busy their gym is, track their gym activity, follow workout plans and track body composition metrics. - Superior technology-enabled systems within individual gyms, including automatic PIN-based gym entry systems at all Pure Gyms, access card gym entry at all Fitness World clubs and “intelligent cycling” at certain Fitness World sites. _Brand—The Combined Group has national brands that benefit from higher levels of brand awareness_ than any other value gym operator in the UK and Denmark. The scale and nationwide footprint allow the business to effectively pursue national marketing campaigns such as TV advertisements. In the UK, the Pure Gym brand is also supplemented by a workout video YouTube channel with over 16,000 subscribers and an Instagram account with over 110,000 followers as of February 2020. In Denmark, Fitness World’s presence is supplemented by 32,300 followers on its Instagram account as of February 2020. Fitness World also uses its dedicated app to advertise services and 141 ----- products such as personal training and sports nutrition drinks from its Functional Nutrition line, which grows the brand and drives value added sales. _Ability to invest—Our scale and resources allow us to rapidly develop new sites and invest in other areas_ of our business, such as technology, that enable us to operate more efficiently and deliver a better customer experience. Our reinvestment and refurbishment capability further differentiates us from smaller cash-constrained competitors.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Title: Diversified operator with scale that is difficult to replicate
Subsubsection Text: We have become a market-leading value gym operator in the UK and Danish markets, with a growing presence in Switzerland. As a result, we are uniquely positioned to benefit from the outperformance in the countries in which we operate, including for the following reasons: - _Increasing scale and a healthy degree of geographic diversification—Upon is acquisition of Fitness World, the newly Combined Group was number two in Europe by number of gyms with over 500 sites (517 sites as of November 9, 2020, consisting of 253 open sites, 236 closed sites in England, six closed sites in Denmark, three closed sites in Switzerland and 19 closed sites in Poland due to COVID-19 restrictions) and had a Combined Group Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of £161.2 million as of December 31, 2019 (on a pro forma basis). We are geographically diversified with 43% of Combined Group revenue generated from operations outside of the UK. In the year ended December 31, 2019, we generated £255 million in UK revenue, £160 million in Danish revenue, £27 million in Swiss revenue and £5 million in Polish revenue. We have the largest gym estate and membership base in the UK market with 11% of total UK gym members and we are a leader in Danish fitness industry with an estimated 43% market share. We believe our expansive presence allows us to procure services and products on favourable terms due to the larger volume of our operations, which gives us superior purchasing power compared to smaller gym operators or new entrants into the market. - _High barriers to scale—We believe that new fitness brands would experience extreme difficulty in attempting to disrupt our strong presence and overall member loyalty, particularly in the UK and in Denmark. We are present in some of the most attractive locations, making it difficult for new entrants to open competing clubs given our accumulated expertise for identifying gym sites. We also have a diversified network of gyms which allows us to offer multi-site membership more effectively. Key features of our business that new entrants would have difficulty in scaling include: - _Expertise in property management—Given our established operating track record and position as the value gym industry leader in the UK and Denmark with national scale, we have acquired significant expertise in property acquisition and management. We are skilled at identifying site locations that will be successful and provide strong ROCE. In order to maintain our market-leading position, we have a strong site selection and property development team with industry expertise supported by an external team of professionals, such as lawyers, architects and planning consultants, as well as the technological tools at our disposal. In particular, we utilize a quantitative whitespace tool to identify attractive new locations in all geographies. The whitespace tool takes into account population statistics, drive time, local demographics, commercial space in catchment area, office locations data, competitor locations and infrastructure (for example, proximity to train stations) when analysing potential new sites. The whitespace tool both identifies attractive cities as well as optimal locations for rollout within a city. - _Industry leading technology platform—We continue to invest in our technology platform, consisting of both websites and mobile applications, where our members can book classes, pay for their memberships and other ancillary services. As the fitness industry increasingly converges with the digital sector, we believe that our technology platform allows our members to more easily access and purchase our services, which helps us attract and retain members. Additionally, our technology-enabled platform allows us to analyse user-specific data which in turn, supports our operational performance. This allows our management to better control all aspects of our pricing strategy, product development and promotional activities. Pure Gym and Fitness World have independently invested in their technological platforms and the Combined 142 ----- Group will benefit from the combination of IT capabilities across its operations as these systems converge. - _Leading marketing expertise driving strong brand awareness—We have an increasingly sophisticated, multi-channel digital-led marketing strategy which is not overly reliant on any single channel. We employ a range of marketing techniques through various media channels in order to promote a contemporary and differentiated brand, which would be difficult for new entrants to replicate given our resources and prior marketing experience. - _Superior convenience as a result of network scale—We have the largest gym network in the UK and Denmark, which allows us to capitalize on potential members’ desire for proximity. We believe this to be a competitive advantage, given that research indicates that proximity is among the top two most important factors for members when choosing a gym. - _Greater access to capital allowing for rapid growth—Based on our strong operating cash flow conversion, which is driven by our highly efficient and high-margin operating model, comparatively low maintenance capital expenditure requirements and positive working capital inflows, we are able to continue investing in new and existing sites. This allows us to protect and grow our market share, while we observe that some mid-market gym operators are often choosing not to reinvest in their existing sites or in expansion. - _Pricing sophistication—We have the ability to employ dynamic pricing at certain gyms in order to tailor our price points to the local market. This allows us to adapt to local markets by managing member enrolment and thus optimize revenues. - _Purchasing Scale—We believe we are the largest purchaser of gym equipment in our key geographies from leading suppliers including Matrix, Precor and Technogym, thereby reducing the costs of constructing and operating our gyms. - _Highly experienced team with significant industry know-how—Our team has exceptional local knowledge, which is based on strong relationships that they have developed over time. We have made, and continue to make, significant investments in our management team comprised of experienced professionals with established track records.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Title: Powerful and highly disruptive customer value proposition
Subsubsection Text: We believe that our customer value proposition, which is focused on providing affordable and flexible memberships to high-quality fitness facilities, is powerful and highly disruptive to the traditional gym and fitness industry. The strength of our customer value proposition has enabled us to grow rapidly by gaining significant market share from traditional mid-market and premium operators, as well as attracting consumers to our gyms who have never previously been a member of a fitness club. The key characteristics of Pure Gym’s customer proposition are as follows: _High-quality facilities and inclusive philosophy—Our gyms are equipped with a large number of pieces_ of high-specification gym equipment, including a broad selection of cardio machines, fixed resistance machines, free weights and functional and other exercise equipment, such as TRX bands and kettlebells. Our gyms are clean, well-maintained and are fitted out with high-quality changing rooms and shower facilities and audio/visual systems. We have welcoming environments and we seek to support all members in the pursuit of their fitness goals, regardless of their current abilities, as demonstrated by our “everybody welcome” philosophy in Pure Gyms and “create healthy habits for all” philosophy in Fitness World clubs. _Affordable pricing—Our flexible and low-cost membership structure provides excellent value for money_ for our members, with student discounts and day passes at Pure Gym locations and off-peak membership options. These options further minimize costs at Pure Gyms and Fitness World clubs, often enabling access to affordable fitness where there previously was none. 143 ----- _Flexibility—We offer a great range of flexibility through our enrolment offers, free classes, extended_ opening hours, premium membership options, and online membership management. - _Enrolment—Members can sign up with no fixed term contract in the UK, Denmark, and Switzerland. Accordingly, members have the freedom and the flexibility to leave at their convenience without incurring cancellation fees and have the ability to freeze their memberships for months at a time. - _Access—We generally offer 24x7x365 access in the UK and extended opening hours in Denmark. This contrasts with the opening hours of mid-market and premium operators, which tend to be more restricted. Clubs in Switzerland are open for 14 to 17 hours a day during weekdays with more limited weekend hours depending on each club. - _Free classes—We have dedicated group exercise studios, including purpose-built stationary cycling studios in many locations. Most Pure Gym clubs offer over 50 free classes per week taught by professional personal trainers. Fitness World incorporates a wide range of class offerings in their membership model. Other operators in the value market do not typically offer such an extensive range of classes. - _Premium Memberships—For an additional monthly premium, our members can choose to upgrade their enrolment options, which provides them with a number of additional benefits. For example, they may have the ability to book classes earlier than standard members, guest passes and larger discounts on sports and fitness brands or receive a set number of personal training sessions a year. - _Online Membership Management—Our online website and app platforms allow members to manage their membership online, freeze or cancel their membership, book classes, locate gym facilities, track fitness data and engage in fitness challenges.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Title: High cash flow generative profile underpinned by exceptional profitability and positive working capital cash inflows
Subsubsection Text: We believe that we have a low cost, capital efficient and technology-enabled gym operating model that provides a competitive advantage over mid-market and premium gym operators. The operating model allows us to offer a compelling customer proposition, support high levels of membership and require low levels of operating and Initial Capital Investment costs. Collectively, these factors drive strong unit economics and ROCEs. The key characteristics of the model are as follows: _Highly capital efficient—Greenfield gyms require a known level of maintenance and refurbishment_ capital expenditure post initial pre-opening investments relating to leasehold costs and fit-out. Landlords will often contribute to the initial fit-out of clubs and in Denmark, these landlord contributions are often significant. Gyms generate stable and predictable EBITDA at maturity (2436 months post opening), driving attractive ROCE. _Low personnel costs—We are able to operate our gyms with low levels of employed personnel primarily_ through the use of technology. For example, Pure Gym uses an online joining process and Fitness World offers in-app enrolment, both of which eliminate the need for a dedicated in-gym sales forces which are commonly used by mid-market and premium operators. Members at Pure Gym and Fitness World locations also use fully-automated PIN-controlled entry portals or member cards to facilitate secure access to gyms, which eliminates the need for additional staff. We believe that we can build upon existing commonalities between Pure Gym and Fitness World and further increase personnel cost efficiency by applying some UK best practices to Fitness World gyms through measures such as unmanned hours covered by video surveillance with tailored alert systems. _Highly effective utilization of space—Unlike most mid-market and premium operators, we do not install_ pools, spas, saunas, steam room, extensive cafes or other high-end amenities in our gyms. These amenities are generally expensive to construct, operate and maintain and take up a significant amount of leased space. We believe that these amenities are generally less utilized by members and that by eliminating them we are able to install a greater number of pieces of high utilization fitness equipment, such as treadmills, free weights and stationary bikes. As a result, our gyms in the UK, 144 ----- Denmark and Switzerland can support high levels of membership while operating on low operating and Initial Capital Investment costs. In addition to consistent and predictable growth, we have strong overall gym performance in the countries in which we operate. For our UK operations, revenue increased from £159.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 to £254.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, representing a CAGR of 16.8%. Similarly, Pure Gym Run-Rate Adjusted increased from £69.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 to £104.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, representing a CAGR of 14.5%. For the acquired Fitness World, revenue increased from £121.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 to £192.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, representing a CAGR of 16.6%. Fitness World Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA increased from £28.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 to £51.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, representing a CAGR of 22.3%. The Combined Group benefits from a highly cash generative business model, which is driven by manageable maintenance capital expenditure requirements and positive working capital inflows. The working capital dynamics are underpinned by rent free periods for new leases, favourable terms with our primary gym equipment providers, and payments from members being received in advance, while major suppliers are paid in arrears. Following the historical period of investment, there is limited further expenditure required in central functions (for example, a head office), which helps to ensure that we are a fully scalable platform going forward.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Our senior management has an established track record of delivering growth and operational excellence in their current roles at the company and in their prior roles at a range of other businesses. Senior management is supported by an experienced management team in key areas, including property acquisition, property development, operations, IT, marketing, human resources and finance. The experienced management team from Fitness World has proven capabilities to drive growth across multiple geographies. The individuals that form part of our property acquisition and development teams are highly experienced in the markets in which we operate. They have strong relationships with landlords, agents, developers and contractors and a proven ability to identify and develop a large number of successful sites while promoting consistent growth as evidenced by our estate growth. We believe that the strength and experience of the property acquisition and development teams ensures that we are well placed to secure attractive new gym sites. Under the current CEO, Pure Gym has grown from an operator of 84 gyms with £37 million of Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA to an operator of over 500 gyms with £161.2 million of Combined Group Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA as of December 31, 2019 (on a pro forma basis). In addition to a strong track record of operational excellence and property acquisition expertise, our leadership team also adheres to a balanced fiscal policy of deleveraging. Pure Gym has consistently reduced its leverage over the past three years. In November 2017, Pure Gym had a leverage ratio of 4.6x (calculated as senior secured net debt divided by Adjusted EBITDA). As of December 2018, this reduced to 3.9x and as of December 2019, the leverage ratio was further reduced to 3.6x, demonstrating a consistent organic deleveraging profile. Further, we have a clear deleveraging strategy for the future as we intend to: - deploy new equity capital in a considered and measured way to open new sites, improve existing sites and deliver technology assets; - reduce leverage by growing EBITDA through new site openings and deployment of technology assets in our core business and through capital-light franchising growth; and - balance capital deployment with cashflow generation and progressive deleveraging. Pure Gym has made substantial investments in management over the past two years and important business functions are now generally managed internally, which we believe provides us with a competitive advantage. For example, important IT functions were brought in-house in 2015 and the IT team was strengthened with a number of new hires. The senior management team is comprised of high calibre individuals with broad experience from various sectors and previous businesses. This ensures that our senior management and other important management teams are well invested and are capable of executing both our focus on performance delivery and our growth strategy. We have a strong and differentiated culture centred on collaboration, innovation and entrepreneurship and we believe that this culture has been a key driver of our ability to deliver strong historical growth and widen the gap between us and other operators in the value gym market. 145 ----- This culture has also helped us to attract and retain high quality personnel and create a highly motivated work force that is dedicated to delivering the best product possible. Pure Gym is recognized as an “employer of choice” after being placed in the Sunday Times 100 Best Companies to Work For in 2018 (the results of which are based on employee feedback).

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: We believe that our key strengths are as follows:

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Title: A rigorous focus on operational excellence to drive the growth and profitability of our existing estate
Subsubsection Text: We remain focused on maintaining the high-quality performance of all our gyms and delivering profitable growth across our existing estate. Management drives revenue performance in a number of ways, including: _Maintaining high standards through targeted investments—We are focused on carefully investing in our_ existing estate in order to maintain the high-quality of our gyms and we seek to continuously optimize the product offer and member experience. This in turn supports our ability to drive membership volumes and tenures, word of mouth recommendations and provide value for money for our members. _Driving Average Revenue Per Member (“ARPM”)—We take a multi-layered approach to increasing_ ARPM by: - _Developing new commercial products—We have implemented and continue to develop new membership options to attract certain types of new members to our gyms and increase our fee yields while consistently offering excellent value for money. For example, Pure Gym has continued to see an increase in penetration of its premium membership products across its gyms. These products take advantage of our technology platform to offer members the option to prebook classes on a priority basis, take a friend to the gym, obtain multi-site access and freeze their memberships. Similarly, Fitness World offers premium membership options for members who are interested in sports nutritional products or a set number of personal training sessions per year. - _Increasing ancillary sales per visit—Ancillary sales are an integral part of the initiative to increase ARPM. For example, Fitness World has successfully grown ancillary sales through its personal training programs and through developing its own successful brand of nutritional supplements by: - educating over 300 new personal trainers and over 400 new instructors through their Fitness Institute and Fitness World Academy; and - offering nutritional products ranging from sports and energy drinks, protein bars and protein powder for purchase through its on-site vending machines, at reception, or through membership options, such as Fitness World’s “All In” membership in its Denmark clubs, which entitles members to one nutritional product per day. - _Bringing the UK’s variable pricing expertise to Fitness World markets—Fitness World does not currently offer dynamic pricing in the same way that Pure Gym can in the UK. It is believed that there are potential upsides to bringing Pure Gym’s pricing expertise for setting membership fees specific to local markets Denmark and Switzerland. Our operational experts tailor pricing to specific local markets and monitor and change the specific prices over time as the market and our competition evolve. In turn, this allows us to monitor member enrolment, manage capacity and maximize revenue and returns. - _Optimizing site capacity—We seek to optimize the capacity of our existing gyms where this is possible and viable. Capacity optimization can involve the physical extension of gyms, or the 146 ----- redesign of certain aspects of gyms to eliminate site-specific utilization bottlenecks, such as the substitution of low utilization equipment, or the installation of additional automated entry portals or access gates to increase capacity. - _Marketing and CRM—We have strengthened our marketing approaches and we are taking a more sophisticated and data-driven approach to membership acquisition and retention. Pure Gym’s brand awareness is strong but has further room for significant growth in the context of our large estate of gyms. We utilize channels, such as television advertising and social media, to increase brand awareness and drive membership growth. Fitness World’s brand awareness is high in Denmark and we are continuing to build on this awareness by marketing services and products through the Fitness World designated app, social media, and through our association with brand ambassadors. - _Development of new sales channels and cross marketing—We are leveraging our nationwide scale in the UK and in Denmark to identify opportunities to partner and enter into commercial arrangements with large corporations that have the potential to deliver incremental membership volumes. - _Leveraging our technology infrastructure—We have made significant investments in our IT team and infrastructure and believe this helps us provide a value-added member experience and the opportunity for additional member sales. _Maintaining a rigorous focus on cost containment—Our ability to offer low membership fees and_ generate strong unit economics and ROCEs is underpinned by our low-cost operating model. As a result, we are focused on optimizing and controlling gym-level operating costs, as well as Initial Capital Investment Costs. These costs are controlled centrally and we intend to continue to leverage our growing scale in order to achieve more favourable purchasing terms with third-party suppliers, service providers and contractors. In addition, we are pursuing a number of ongoing operational efficiency projects, such as energy saving initiatives, to minimize future gym-level cost increases and improve returns. Following several years of investment into central functions such as IT, marketing and finance, we believe that our central functions are well invested and that we will not require significant incremental central cost expansion in the medium term.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Title: Increasing the number of high quality New Gyms and preserving the consistency and predictability of ROCE
Subsubsection Text: Pure Gym and Fitness World have significantly increased their number of gyms in recent years as a result of organic roll-out and selective acquisitions. We continue to focus on driving the operational and financial performance of New Gyms as they mature, with key areas of focus including: - Using our experience to select attractive gym locations where the demand and demographics result in predictable financial performance - Consistency of delivery and high standards - Leveraging our experience to adapt to local markets - Optimization of volume and ARPM in each gym - Driving scale benefits - Successfully increasing margins and member enrolment for newly-acquired businesses We plan to leverage our experience to continue the organic roll out of new gyms with strong ROCE. Future growth in the value segment will be driven by the development of new value gyms, continued market share gains from mid-market and premium operators, as well as public gyms operated by local authorities, and overall growth in gym participation rates due in part to the increasing awareness and availability of value gyms in each of our markets. The significant opportunity for further growth in the value gym market is evidenced by: - The significant success of the value gym concept to date and its broad consumer appeal. 147 ----- - The current overall penetration rates of gym membership in existing markets as of December 2019; only 16% of the British population, 19% of Danish population, 14% of the Swiss population, and 8% of the Polish population have gym memberships (Source: OC&C Report). We believe that we are ideally positioned to capitalize on this substantial market penetration opportunity as market leaders in the United Kingdom and Denmark with a long, successful track record of opening new gyms and rapidly growing membership, revenue and profitability. The Combined Group has a structured and disciplined approach to site identification, acquisition and development. Our property acquisition teams are highly experienced and have a strong network of property agents, landlords and developers that provide us with a substantial number of new site opportunities. Our gyms have been proven to work across the United Kingdom and Denmark in a wide variety of property types and, accordingly, management considers a broad number of locations for new gyms. We have also proven our ability to innovate through initially testing and now proving the SBF concept in the UK, which features gyms that are 6,000 to 9,000 square feet in size and enable us to adapt the Pure Gym model to smaller local markets. The UK and Denmark have similar levels of ROCE though different cost structures. Gyms in Denmark generate lower margins and require lower initial capital expenditure compared to UK gyms, due to sizeable landlord contributions and that are partly offset by higher rents. Landlords in Denmark frequently pay for a substantial part of the initial club fit-out costs, thus reducing the payback periods and increasing ROCE. We seek to grow our organic gym estate by both opening new Pure Gyms at sites that were not previously operated as gyms (“Organic Greenfields”) as well as sites that were previously operated as gyms (“Organic

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Our strategy is to continue to be a market-leading value gym operator by providing affordable, flexible and value-for-money memberships to high-quality gyms to anyone who wants to increase their level of fitness, while simultaneously delivering profitable growth. Our acquisition of Fitness World is a continuation of this strategy, strengthening our position as a market leader in Europe and in geographies outside of the UK. The key elements of our strategy include:

Subsection Title: Conversions”). We believe that there will continue to be new Organic Conversion site development opportunities
Subsubsection Text: as mid-market and premium operators continue to face structural and competitive market headwinds and smaller value operators seek to exit sites rather than reinvest when facing competition.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Pure Gym was established in September 2008 by entrepreneur Peter Roberts, who recognized that there was a significant opportunity in the UK health and fitness market for a value gym offering. Peter launched Pure Gym to disrupt the market by providing high quality exercise facilities to a broad consumer base at affordable prices and on flexible contract terms. In November 2009, the first two Pure Gyms were opened in Manchester and Leeds, with a third gym opened in Edinburgh in December 2009. Pure Gym built upon the success of its first three gyms and opened six new gyms in 2010. Since 2010, Pure Gym has increased the pace of roll out of new gyms. In the year ended December 31, 2019, Pure Gym opened 41 gyms. (See “Business—Estate Overview—Pure Gym”). In January 2015, Humphrey Cobbold, formerly the CEO of Wiggle, an online cycling goods retailer, joined Pure Gym as its Chief Executive Officer. In June 2015, Sir Chris Hoy, an eleven-time world champion and six-time Olympic champion track cyclist, invested in Pure Gym and was appointed as a special advisor and brand ambassador. In May 2015, Pure Gym acquired the LA Fitness Group and its 43 LA Fitness and LAX branded gyms. Subsequent to the acquisition, Pure Gym divested or closed 12 LA Fitness gyms while retaining 31 LA Fitness gyms and, in September 2017, Pure Gym completed the conversion of all 31 of the LA Fitness gyms to the Pure Gym format. In 2018, Pure Gym acquired Ovalhouse Limited (trading as Soho Gyms) consisting of ten fitness clubs based in prime locations throughout London. Four of the ten gyms were converted into the Pure Gym model in 2018, five Soho Gyms were converted in the first half of 2019 and the remaining site is pending conversion in 2020 subject to re-evaluation of the gym site for acoustics and leasing terms. In September 2018, Alex Wood joined Pure Gym as the new Chief Financial Officer (See “Management—Directors—Alex Wood, Chief Financial Officer”). In April 2019, Dina Asher-Smith, a professional sprinter and the title-holder of World Championship Gold and Silver medals, joined Pure Gym as a brand ambassador on an initial three-year contract. 148 ----- In December 2019, Pure Gym entered into its first lease in the United States with the aim of testing its low-cost, technology-enabled concept in a new international territory. This site is expected to open in late 2020. On January 14, 2020, Pure Gym completed the acquisition of Fitness World. The Acquisition resulted in the Combined Group becoming a diversified value gym operator which, upon the acquisition, was the number two value gym operator in Europe by number of gyms.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Fitness World was founded in 2005 by Henrik and Sophie Rossing and is headquartered in Rødovre, Denmark. Fitness World has grown both organically and through acquisitions and has changed ownership along the way. In 2011, Fitness World acquired Enjoy Fitness and its 11 fitness clubs. In 2012, Fitness World acquired Fitness One and its seven fitness clubs. This period of M&A activity continued in 2013 as Fitness World acquired SATS from Health & Fitness Nordic (HFN) along with its six fitness clubs and throughout 2015 when Fitness World acquired Fresh Fitness and its 23 fitness clubs. In 2015, FSN Capital bought 51% of the company from Henrik and Sophie Rossing. Also in 2015, Fitness World entered Poland by acquiring Condizione and its three fitness clubs. Fitness World adapted the Condizione brand and product to the local market and consumer dynamics throughout the course of 2016. At the end of 2016, Fitness World had 160 gyms in its estate, generated £121 million in revenue, had an Adjusted EBITDA of £25 million and had a Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of £28 million. Fitness World’s average revenue per member was £23 in 2016. In July 2017, Fitness World established its own sports nutrition brand, Functional Nutrition, and launched its ready-to-drink and powder supplementation products in Denmark at the end of 2017 and later expanded distribution from its Functional Nutrition line to local independent gyms across Denmark. At the end of 2017, Fitness World had 180 gyms in its estate, generated £147 million in revenue, had an Adjusted EBITDA of £30 million and had a Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of £34 million. Fitness World’s average revenue per member was £25 in 2017. In October 2018, Fitness World entered Switzerland by acquiring Basefit, the second-largest fitness operator in Switzerland and its 33 fitness clubs. At the end of 2018, Fitness World had 229 gyms in its estate, generated £164 million in revenue, had an Adjusted EBITDA of £35 million and had a Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of £47 million. Fitness World’s average revenue per member was £27 in 2018. In 2019, Fitness World established strong partnerships with Team Denmark, the organization that sponsors Denmark’s world-class athletes. As the official training partner for Team Denmark, Fitness World leverages the top Danish athletes as ambassadors for its facilities while supporting the athletes with their fitness goals and the Olympics. Also in 2019, Fitness World was awarded best digital consumer experience in Denmark by the Danish Digital Awards and was the overall highest rated gym brand in Poland in an independent consumer survey of leisure operators conducted by OC&C in 2019. During 2019, Fitness World started development of its new member system, “OneCore”, designed to decrease costs and enhance a data-driven approach to member acquisition and retention. The Core UK model delivers industry leading four-wall margins and return on capital, both of more than 40%. Fitness World also rolled out new membership options in Switzerland and became the first operator to launch monthly rolling memberships in Switzerland. Through its investment in its product offering and its digital platform, Fitness World has benefited from growing customer tenure. Fitness World’s continuous membership subscription increased from 29 months in 2016 to 30 months in 2017 to 32 months in 2018. As of December 31, 2019, Fitness World’s continuous membership subscription is 33 months. Fitness World currently operates two core brands: Fitness World and Basefit. As of December 31, 2019, Fitness World operates 241 clubs in total. Fitness World is a market-leading value gym operator in Denmark with 185 clubs. Fitness World has a growing presence in Switzerland, where it operates 39 clubs under the Basefit brand. Fitness World also continues to develop its own nutrition and sports products through its subsidiary, Functional Nutrition. As of December 31, 2019 Functional Nutrition has developed more than 50 products and has begun to sell the products outside of Denmark. In addition, Fitness World operates a small business called the Fitness Institute, which is a training academy for personal trainers. Fitness World educates more than 400 personal trainers each year through the Fitness Institute and its own Fitness World Academy. 149 ----- Fitness World’s history evinces a trend of improved key metrics across the business. As of December 31, 2019, Fitness World generated £193 million in revenue, had an Adjusted EBITDA of £43 million and had a Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA of £52 million, representing a CAGR of 16.6% in revenue and a CAGR of 22.3% in Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA between the years 2016 and 2019. Fitness World’s average revenue per member increased from £23 in 2016 to £28 in 2019, representing a CAGR of 4.7% during the period. Fitness World’s operating free cash flow also increased from £11 million in 2016 (42% operating free cash flow conversion) to £24 million in 2019 (55% free cash flow conversion), remaining stable throughout the majority of the period. On January 14, 2020, Fitness World was acquired by Pure Gym.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: _Pure Gym_ Since opening its first gym in 2009, Pure Gym’s estate has grown rapidly. In 2009, the Pure Gym estate consisted of three gyms with 12,000 members. By 2015, Pure Gym had 132 gyms with 622,000 members. For the year ended December 31, 2019, Pure Gym had 263 gyms with 1,135,000 members. As of June 30, 2020, Pure Gym had 505 gyms and 1,697 members. Pure Gym has largely grown its estate organically, primarily by opening Organic Greenfields. For an Organic Greenfield, Pure Gym enters into a lease directly with a landlord. Pure Gym has also driven growth by opening Organic Conversions and through M&A Conversions. For an Organic Conversion, Pure Gym takes on a lease directly from another gym operator via a lease assignment or a sublease agreement or enters into a new lease directly with a landlord following the relinquishment of a lease by another gym operator. Pure Gym has primarily developed its Organic Conversion gyms at sites that were previously operated by mid-market and premium operators, including Virgin Active (8 sites), Fitness First (12 sites including Klick), LA Fitness (3 sites) and Fit4Free (3 sites). Pure Gym has supplemented its organic growth through the acquisition of MegaGym (single site) in December 2014, the LA Fitness Group in May 2015 (31 sites), and Ovalhouse Limited, trading under the brand of “Soho Gyms,” (10 sites) in 2018. At an M&A Conversion site, Pure Gym acquires the gym and its membership for consideration and converts it to the Pure Gym brand and operating model. 150 ----- The following table sets out Pure Gym’s gym estate by type of site as of December 31, 2019.

Subsubsection Text: _Fitness World_ Fitness World’s estate has grown rapidly since 2008. In 2009, the Fitness World estate consisted of 52 gyms with 171,000 members. In 2015, Fitness World’s estate encompassed 151 gyms with 449,000 members. As of December 31, 2019, Fitness World had a gym estate of 241 fitness clubs and 589,000 members. Fitness World has largely grown its estate through Organic Greenfield and M&A activity. The following table sets out Fitness World’s gym estate by type of site as of December 31, 2019.

Section Title: BUSINESS
BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Pure Gyms are located in towns, cities and other populous areas and we have a balanced portfolio of gyms throughout the UK, including a strong presence in Central London and the Greater London area. The Pure Gym model has proven successful in a wide variety of property types, such as former retail park warehouses, offices, car showrooms and night clubs and demographic catchments, which Pure Gym believes indicates that there are a significant number of site alternatives that can be selected for future gyms. Fitness World gyms are located in towns, cities and other populous areas and Fitness World has a balanced portfolio of gyms throughout Denmark, including a strong presence in Copenhagen. The Fitness World 151 ----- model has proven successful in a wide variety of property types, such as former grocery stores, offices, basements and factories. Pure Gym and Fitness World’s gyms by site type as of December 31, 2019 are:

Pure Gym believes that this strengthens its membership proposition over its competitors by providing members with the flexibility and convenience to use multiple gyms (e.g., near both home and work) and strengthening the local Pure Gym brand. As at December 31, 2019, Pure Gym operates its clubs in the UK only; however, Pure Gym has entered into its first lease in the U.S. for a site that is expected to open in late 2020 or early 2021.
