Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: _Pure Gym_ Key to Pure Gym’s proposition is the simple and transparent “no contract” flexible membership. Members are not bound to any fixed term contract and simply pay on a monthly basis in advance for their membership, almost entirely by direct debit. Members have the ability to freeze or leave at any time, which provides flexibility that appeals to a broad market. The “Core” membership product provides unlimited access to a member’s chosen gym, and includes free group exercise classes. In addition to this “Core” membership, Pure Gym offers a number of additional options. There are discounted “Off Peak” memberships available in many gyms, where access is restricted to quieter times so pricing is lower. In addition, members can choose to pay a higher fee and select premium membership options such as “Multi” and “Plus” which provide additional benefits such as being able to access more than one gym, bringing a guest along to work out with, priority class bookings, or entitlement to additional services such as Yanga sports water and/or massage beds in some gyms. These options provide members with a range of flexibility to tailor their membership to best suit their personal needs. This also assists Pure Gym in optimizing revenue 159 ----- across gyms to leverage its nationwide footprint and optimizes value added sales since each premium products earns Pure Gym an extra £5-7 per month. As of December 31, 2019, 74% of members held “Core” memberships, 3% held “Off Peak” memberships and 23% held premium options. In addition to memberships, Pure Gym sells shorter term “day passes” which can be bought (at a slightly higher price) to access facilities for specific one, three, seven, or 30 days at a time. This is a useful “trial” option for prospects or people who travel repeatedly. These “pay as you go” options are not deemed memberships, so they do not form part of the membership count. _Fitness World_ Fitness World offers the widest range of flexible membership options in its home market of Denmark. Fitness Basic is the base membership that solely includes club access and membership options vary with access, pricing, and add-on features. On the other end of the spectrum, the Fitness Premium membership includes access to any Fitness World club, five personal training sessions per year, one sports nutrition product at the facility per day, and an option to freeze membership once per year. Fitness World tailors the membership options it offers in each region. For example, in highly concentrated gyms in Copenhagen, Fitness World does not offer the more basic gym-access only memberships. Basefit offers three membership options in its facilities in Switzerland. The first option is for base membership through a monthly or annual contract. The second option if members choose to commit to a 12-month binding period is to purchase an annual membership for off-peak gym access or an annual membership for regular hours access. The third option is a 24-month contract. Prices are generally higher in Switzerland given cost of living standards.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: _Pure Gym_ Pure Gym invests significant resources in revenue management and operates a dynamic pricing strategy with individual gym pricing. This is a key strategic differentiator to many other global value gym operators. Gym pricing is transparent on the Pure Gym website and mobile app and is a core component of its affordable value proposition, which also differentiates it from traditional mid-market and premium health and fitness operators. Pricing is managed centrally and is reviewed weekly by senior management, incorporating feedback from local and regional management. The goal of this dynamic variable pricing is to optimize revenue and consequently site profitability through the effective balancing of yield, volume and capacity in order to ensure member experience is also optimized. Internal and external factors are considered in pricing decisions to ensure site potential is realized from inception through to maturity. As of December 31, 2019, Pure Gym selling prices to new members were as follows: - “Core” monthly membership fees (including VAT and excluding pre-opening offers) ranged from £17.99 to £49.99 inside the M25 with an average of £28.72 - “Core” monthly membership fees (including VAT and excluding pre-opening offers) ranged from £12.99 to £25.99 outside the M25 with an average of £19.78 _Fitness World_ Fitness World members in Denmark pay the following amounts to join and use its gyms under the standard membership as of December 31, 2019 (all figures below are inclusive of VAT and exclude pre-opening offers): - a joining fee of DKK 299 (£35) in the absence of a promotional campaign; and - a monthly membership fee ranging from DKK 179 (£21) to DKK 399 (£47), depending on the location and services offered, with an average of DKK 235 (£28). Basefit members in Switzerland pay the following amounts to join and use its gyms under the standard membership as of December 31, 2019 (all figures below are inclusive of VAT and exclude pre-opening offers): 160 ----- - no joining fee but a charge of 20 CHF (£16) for each member to receive their gym membership badge; and - a monthly membership fee ranging from CHF 33 (£26) to CHF 59 (£46), depending on the location and services offered, with an average of CHF 39 (£31) per month.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Pure Gym utilizes direct debit for the collection of the majority of its membership fees; however, in all gyms, the joining fees and the first month’s membership fees are collected by credit cards in order to mitigate the risk of the first payment not being made. Membership fees are paid one month in advance, which minimizes customer credit risk. Fitness World Denmark subscriptions are renewed automatically so that the cost of a new period is automatically paid for by means of a pre-authorized charge to a credit card.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: _Pure Gym_ Pure Gym operates a fully automated and convenient online joining process. Prospective members may either join online through Pure Gym’s website or in person at a gym using internet-connected kiosks provided on the gym premises. Pure Gym’s in-house call centre is able to assist members with the joining process if required. Automated online joining is a key part of Pure Gym’s ability to operate on costs lower than traditional UK health and fitness operators as it enables Pure Gym to operate without an expensive sales force. Online joining also provides other benefits, including: - improves the customer experience as it is more convenient than joining in the gym and does not result in a high-pressure sales environment; - allows for the consistent collection of customer data; and - enables gym managers to focus on delivering the best in-gym experience to members, rather than spending time on tasks related to membership enrolment and management. In addition to joining, many aspects of a customer’s membership can be managed by members online or via the Pure Gym mobile app such as booking places in classes or upgrading, transferring and freezing memberships. Pure Gym believes its online membership management services are highly differentiated in the UK health and fitness market. _Fitness World_ Fitness World has a digital concept based on selling memberships through online e-commerce and inperson at a gym. Members can join online, sign up for personal training sessions and track their progress through the app. Members can also participate in challenges through the app.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: _Pure Gym_ Pure Gym believes that regular, relevant engagement with members results in a better customer experience and inspires members to use the gym more frequently and achieve their fitness goals. Higher satisfaction and more active gym usage in turn typically increases membership duration and leads to recommendations to family, friends, and relatives. Pure Gym seeks to engage with its current members in a number of ways. On a personal level, gym managers and personal trainers are encouraged to develop relationships with members and support the achievement of their fitness goals. Pure Gym also uses technology to engage with customers and educate them about fitness. See “Business—Technology—Pure Gym”. Pure Gym also seeks to engage with former members and encourage them to return to Pure Gym. This is done by email and outbound calls from the call centre. See “Business—Call centre”. Achieving high levels of customer satisfaction is Pure Gym’s key objective and management tracks satisfaction levels closely. Pure Gym gathers feedback from members largely through regular NPS monitoring 161 ----- and other feedback mechanisms and uses the results in all levels of decision making, including operations, product design, and site fit-out. Customer feedback scores are also used as a component of the incentive and bonus awards for gym managers and assistant managers. _Fitness World_ Fitness World invests heavily in member experiences through its on-site group class offerings, digital training and personal training programs. These initiatives drive member engagement both in and outside of Fitness World clubs. In 2018, Fitness World introduced personalized training and inspiring challenges as features on its branded personal training app which significantly increased the app’s usage and resulted in increased member engagement. In 2019, Fitness World launched “Healthkit” through its branded Fitness World app. “Healthkit” enables users to monitor their fitness data and share this data with other users. It also features seven minute training programs, fitness challenges that users can participate in and training for a number of outdoor classes including yoga and running programs. Fitness World has also streamlined its website to improve e-commerce sales flow for Functional nutritional products and sports drinks.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Pure Gym and Fitness World operate their own member services call centre. The objective of the call centre is to provide customer service to existing members (e.g. managing payment issues, resolving site access issues and answering general questions about members’ gyms) and enable prospective members to speak to a person regarding any questions they may have about our product. The call centre also has outbound calling capability and contacts certain members who have cancelled their memberships to encourage them to re-join. As of December 31, 2019, 151 people worked in the Pure Gym call centre (both full and part-time), which is based at Pure Gym’s headquarters in Leeds. As of December 31, 2019, 17 people worked full-time in the Fitness World call centre throughout Denmark, Poland and Switzerland. Pure Gym and Fitness World believe that the call centre is a valuable tool in maintaining high levels of customer service and enhancing the proposition and member experience.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: The majority of Pure Gyms are accessible by members seven days a week, 365 days a year and 24 hours a day. Entry and exit is controlled via automated and computer controlled entry portals and members have their own unique PIN-codes and/or RFID bands or key fobs which grant them access. Fraud prevention measures are in place to limit the risk of multiple individuals using the same membership or PIN number. The automated entry systems track and provide data on usage patterns so that gym managers can actively manage capacity and monitor key performance indicators. Fitness World clubs open as of December 31, 2019 were accessible by members seven days a week and 365 days a year. Over 20% of Fitness World clubs were accessible seven days a week/24 hours a day. Entry and exit is controlled via automated and computer controlled entry portals and members have their own membership card or token which grant them access. Fraud prevention measures are in place in all markets to limit the risk of multiple individuals using the same membership credentials.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: _Pure Gym_ Pure Gym’s overall strategic objective is to secure and develop gyms at properties that are well located, contribute to positive “cluster effects” and deliver attractive and sustainable returns on invested capital. A structured and disciplined approach has been crucial for successful site acquisition and has helped Pure Gym build a strong nationwide site portfolio. Pure Gym has a four-stage new site acquisition process which includes: (1) Initial Site Targeting; (2) Preliminary Screening of Opportunities; (3) Detailed Evaluation and Assessment of Priorities; and (4) Formal Feasibility Reports and Investment Decision Making (as described below). Pure Gym leases all of its gym sites. (a) The Property Acquisition Team Pure Gym has a dedicated six-person property acquisition team, headed by the property acquisition director, who is responsible for the acquisition of new gym sites. The team reports to the UK Finance Director, who provides oversight, strategic direction and leadership. The responsibilities of the property acquisition team include identifying potential site locations, evaluating their suitability as Pure Gyms, developing financial 162 ----- forecasts for prospective sites in conjunction with the operations, finance and development teams and negotiating lease terms with landlords. The individuals who form part of Pure Gym’s property acquisition team are highly experienced in the UK property market and have strong relationships with landlords, developers, agents and other gym operators who may be looking to divest sites. The property acquisition team uses extensive data and proprietary tools to identify and evaluate new gym sites. (b) Initial Site Targeting Pure Gym uses a number of approaches to ensure it is identifying a large number and broad cross section of potential new locations for its gyms across the UK: (i) First, Pure Gym has categorized the UK into different catchment areas from major conurbations to cities and towns to ensure it has a “top down” list of priority site locations from across the country. (ii) Second, Pure Gym has worked with external consultants to build a proprietary postcode driven assessment model to help it identify potentially attractive locations using demographic, socio-economic, and other data. The model forecasts estimated financial returns expected from gyms opened in those locations. The model is tested against proprietary data from Pure Gym’s portfolio of existing sites, which is the largest network of gyms in the UK This “bottom up” approach generates a prioritized list of over 200 locations which are a key focus area for the property acquisition team. (iii) Third, Pure Gym’s property acquisition team continually reviews sources such as planning registers as well as maintaining close contact with landlords, property agents and developers. (iv) Fourth, Pure Gym is active in seeking out and pursuing opportunities to take over leases from existing gym operators. Since inception, Pure Gym has taken on 34 leases of sites at which a gym was previously operated by another operator (excluding an incremental 41 M&A Conversions). (v) Lastly, Pure Gym consistently updates its processes and databases and analyses the performance of its existing gyms in order to identify similar locations that build on previous successes. (c) Preliminary Screening of Opportunities Given the number of locations and opportunities that it identifies, the Pure Gym business has developed a disciplined and efficient approach to screening opportunities. There are six key evaluation parameters to this screening process: - site characteristics; - headline population and demographic characteristics; - likely lease terms; - location characteristics; - local competitive dynamics; and - other important local considerations. The preliminary screening process uses data, analysis, internal tools and the judgment of the property acquisition team to decide whether or not to proceed with a given site opportunity. The key output of the preliminary screening stage is a decision to complete a formal site assessment. (d) Detailed Evaluation and Assessment of Priorities 163 ----- At this stage of the process, Pure Gym invests more time, effort and money to reach a decision on whether to prepare a formal feasibility report and ask the Capex Committee, which includes the CEO and CFO, for formal approval for the site. The key steps at this stage are: - two members of property acquisition team visit the site; - development team, architectural design team and a nominated contractor visit the site; - discussions and negotiations with the landlord, planners and potentially other leaseholders; - detailed analysis and consolidation of feedback from the operations and development teams; - creation of financial forecast and returns model; and - analysis of potential impact on existing sites, if relevant. (e) Formal Feasibility Report and Investment Decision Making If a site is deemed to be attractive following the detailed evaluation, a formal feasibility report is prepared. The work and documentation for these reports is standardized and they are prepared by the property acquisition team. If the Capex Committee approves a formal feasibility report, the lease for the site will be entered into, unless the circumstances change in the intervening period. Pure Gym believes that it has developed a rigorous, transparent and professional approach to identifying new sites and to guiding decision making over capital investment. Pure Gym also believes that the discipline of its property acquisition process, combined with the institutional knowledge gained from opening more gyms than any other private, low-cost gym operator in the UK since 2009 is a major contributor to its significant growth, competitive advantage and success. Pure Gym believes the power of its property acquisition team and process is evidenced by the fact that it has never closed an organic Pure Gym site and its Mature Gyms delivered an Average Gym ROCE of 43% in 2019. (f) Site Development Once a lease for a new site has been entered into, the development team takes responsibility for managing the construction of the gym. Pure Gym has robust processes, a proprietary data set of benchmark costs, and very strong contractor and supplier relationships to assist in the development of sites. These factors continue to be a major contributor to Pure Gym’s strong growth, competitive advantage and success. The development team consists of 31 people as at December 31, 2019, including the property development director and four project departmental leaders. The development team is responsible for managing the development of new sites and the refurbishment of existing sites. The development team uses third party contractors to execute actual site works. Each new gym fit out is put out to tender with at least two contractors. Pure Gym has longstanding relationships with its contractors as well as with other key third-party business partners such as architects, acoustic engineers and other building services providers. Pure Gym’s strong relationships and continuity with these partners has enabled it to cost effectively develop and open a large number of new gyms each year, while simultaneously delivering a consistent, high level of quality. Construction and development of each new gym generally takes 8 to 10 weeks and the costs and timings of developing an Organic Conversion gym is generally the same as for an Organic Greenfield gym. Pure Gym follows the traditional method of development in the UK health and fitness industry, by which the landlord is generally responsible for the shell of the unit, while the operator is responsible for the design and fit-out of the unit. (g) Gym opening targets and pipeline The Combined Group has had a strong pipeline of new organic gyms: we have opened 19 new locations in 2020 (12 in the UK, five in Denmark and two in Poland) with no further openings planned for this year. We are targeting to open approximately 25 to 40 organic gyms across the Combined Group in 2021, depending on the evolution of the COVID-19 pandemic. 164 ----- Pure Gym believes that it has a substantial advantage over competitors for acquiring leased space given its strong brand, leading market position, historically strong landlord covenant, excellent reputation and proven ability to drive foot traffic to landlords’ properties. Pure Gym believes that there is a market opportunity for around 1,200 to 1,400 value gyms and approximately 4.5 million to 5.0 million value gym members in the UK market. (h) Property leases Pure Gym seeks to enter economically feasible leases with sufficient terms to justify the development costs of gyms. In addition, Pure Gym also seeks to ensure that its leases protect it from substantial increases in rents due to potential future volatility in the commercial property market and provide it with sufficient flexibility to exit unprofitable locations. Pure Gym’s organic site lease agreements typically include the following key terms, which provide it with substantial visibility over its future property costs: - monthly or quarterly rents paid in advance based on a fee per square foot of leased space; - monthly or quarterly service charges, where relevant, paid in advance; - typically up to 12 months rent-free period at the start of the lease; - landlord contributions to fund a certain amount of fit-outs costs; - 15-year terms; - no landlord breaks; - tenant-only break rights at year 10; - rent reviews every five years, based largely on RPI with caps of approximately 3–4% per annum and collars of approximately 0–2% per annum in London and open market rent reviews typically outside of London; and - security of tenure at the expiration of the lease, whereby we have the right to apply for a new tenancy at the end of the term, and the landlord may only oppose the grant of a new tenancy on very limited grounds. While Pure Gym is generally able to standardize these terms for most of its gyms, many of the leases that were acquired from LA Fitness have different terms than described above. These alternate terms include longer lease terms, fixed rent uplifts not tied to RPI, open market rent reviews and no tenant break rights. Despite these differences, Pure Gym believes the leases acquired from LA Fitness are attractive. The following table sets forth the remaining lease lengths for Pure Gym’s estate of gyms. As reflected in the table below, 61% of Pure Gym leases have at least ten years remaining on their terms.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsection Title: As of December 31, 2019 Remaining Lease Length** **Percentage of Gyms (%)
Subsubsection Text: 15+ years ................................................................................................................................. 13 10-15 years .............................................................................................................................. 48 5-10 years ................................................................................................................................ 30 <5 years ................................................................................................................................... 8 Total ........................................................................................................................................** 100 _Fitness World_ Fitness World has a very similar property set up to Pure Gym, which is described above. The main differences are that the Fitness World estate is more mature in Denmark and consequently, the Danish acquisitions team is smaller than that of Pure Gym. The Combined Group will benefit from best practices application of site selection tools and analysis of new sites will be subject to the Combined Group’s Capex Committee approval process. 165 ----- (a) The Property Acquisition Team Fitness World has an experienced property team that is responsible for identifying potential targets and consistently tracking local competitors. The property team leverages its experience from Fitness World’s 241 club estate, its credibility with landlords and its strong relationships with local real-estate agents in order to leverage scale and negotiate the best possible rental deals. The property team uses multiple site identification methods to identify potential targets and establishes potential hurdles for each location with a focus on membership potential at each site. The team is also responsible for detailed property development specifications and ensuring consistent execution across the gym estate. Fitness World leases all of its gym sites. (b) Initial Site Targeting Fitness World Denmark has a dedicated two-person property acquisition team which is responsible for the acquisition of new gym sites. The responsibilities of the property acquisition team include identifying potential site locations, evaluating their suitability as Fitness World clubs, developing financial forecasts for prospective sites in conjunction with the operations, finance and development teams and negotiating lease terms with landlords. The individuals who form part of Fitness World’s property acquisition team are highly experienced in the Danish property market and have strong relationships with landlords, developers, agents and other gym operators who may be looking to divest sites. The property acquisition team uses a white space tool developed together with PwC to identify and evaluate new gym sites. In Switzerland, Fitness World has a similar site-targeting process but with only one employee in each country responsible for the acquisition of new gym sites. (c) Preliminary Screening of Opportunities When potential locations and opportunities are identified, Fitness World Retail Development screens the sites using different parameters such as proper retail and fitness space, fit into expansion strategy and eco-system, demographics and member potential, proper lease terms, and competitive strength in the area. The preliminary screening process uses data, analysis, internal tools and the judgment of the Fitness World Retail Development team to decide whether to proceed with a given site opportunity. The key output of the preliminary screening stage is a decision to complete a formal site assessment. (d) Detailed Evaluation and Assessment of Priorities If the site makes it through the preliminary screening phase, a more detailed evaluation of the site will take place. This evaluation includes, but is not always limited to: - A site visit with at least two people from the site evaluation team (Fitness World Retail Development and Fitness World Facility Management); - A meeting with the landlord and/or real estate agent to discuss initial commercial terms and plans for the location to see whether the site will satisfy Fitness World standards for reasonable member price points and competitive leasing terms; and - Taking photographs inside of the site including digital drawings. - Drawing the future Fitness World club images; - Negotiating commercial and rental agreements with the landlord and/or real estate agent and reaching an agreement; and - Developing a feasibility study or business case on the project with projected member potential, revenue, EBITDA, club contribution margin and the cannibalization effect from clubs in the potential eco-system based on the analysis from the white space tools and other resources. (e) Formal Report and Investment Decision Making If a site is deemed to be an attractive option following the detailed evaluation, a formal feasibility report is prepared and presented to the Capex Committee of the Combined Group, which includes the CEO and CFO. If 166 ----- the Capex Committee approves the site, Fitness World will enter into the lease for the site, unless there are changed circumstances in the intervening period. Fitness World believes that it has developed a rigorous, transparent and professional approach to identifying new sites and to guiding decision making over capital investment. Fitness World also believes that the discipline of its property acquisition process, combined with the industry knowledge gained from opening more gyms than any other gym operator in Denmark since 2005, is a major contributor to its significant growth, competitive advantage and success. (f) Site Development Once a lease for a new site has been entered into, the Fitness World Retail Development Team takes responsibility for managing the construction of the gym in cooperation with the Fitness World Retail Operations Team, which starts preparing for future staffing needs. Fitness World has robust processes, a proprietary data set of benchmark costs and has recently entered into strong contractor and supplier relationships to assist in the development of sites. These factors will continue to be a major contributor to Fitness World’s strong growth, competitive advantage and success. Fitness World uses third party contractors to execute actual site works. In rare cases, the landlord can build the club if it fits into a bigger project, but Fitness World prefers to carry out the site development itself. Fitness world has strong relationships with its contractors and third party business partners such as acoustic engineers and other building service providers. Construction and development of each new gym approximately takes three months. If another fitness club is acquired, the process takes a shorter amount of time, but can often be more complicated due to the members already in the club, their habits and preferences. Fitness World follows the traditional method of development in the Danish health and fitness industry by which the landlord is generally responsible for the shell of the club, while the operator is responsible for the design and fit-out of the club. (g) Property leases Fitness World seeks to enter into economically feasible leases with sufficient terms to justify the development costs of gyms. In addition, Fitness World also seeks to ensure that its leases protect it from substantial increases in rents due to potential future volatility in the commercial property market and provide it with sufficient flexibility to exit unprofitable locations. Fitness World lease agreements typically include the following key terms, which provide it with substantial visibility over its future property costs: - monthly or quarterly rents paid in advance based on a fee per square meter of leased space; - monthly or quarterly service charges, where relevant, paid in advance; - landlord contributions to fund a certain amount of fit-outs costs; - 10-year terms; - tenant-only break rights at year 10; and - and other attractive terms depending of the specific case and the terms that can be negotiated. The following table sets forth the remaining lease lengths for Fitness World’s estate of gyms. There is significant opportunity to review Fitness World leases that are approaching the ten-year mark on more attractive terms or relocate gyms to more favourable locations. 15+ years ................................................................................................................................. 7 10-15 years .............................................................................................................................. 3 5-10 years ................................................................................................................................ 33 167 ----- <5 years ................................................................................................................................... 57 Total ........................................................................................................................................** 100

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Pure Gym and Fitness World experience a small degree of seasonality. The majority of membership growth is in January, February, September and October. Seasonality is generally positively driven by consumers’ desire to improve their fitness at the start of the year and the start of new university/school terms and negatively driven by Christmas and summer holidays. Pure Gym generally focuses its marketing spend around peak joining periods, particularly the January/February period.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: _Pure Gym_ Pure Gym’s “everybody welcome” philosophy and marketing message positions it as an affordable provider of high-quality health and fitness facilities that welcome all people regardless of their current levels of fitness or fitness goals. Pure Gym’s marketing message and brand image focuses on affordable and transparent pricing, “no contract” memberships and convenient 24 hours a day, seven days a week, 365 days a year access to a national network of clean and well-maintained gyms that house high-quality equipment and offer a large number free exercise classes. With over 1.2 million members, Pure Gym is the “UK’s Favourite Gym” and this is central to marketing communication, helping to create distinction from competitors. Total marketing expenditure for the year ended December 31, 2019 was £12.9 million and both the efficiency and effectiveness of this expenditure are important focus areas for senior management. Pure Gym operates national, regional, and local/site-specific marketing campaigns and programs. Considerable focus and attention is placed on local advertising campaigns for gyms that are in the pre-opening phase or have recently opened. Approximately £50,000 is budgeted for each new gym opening to support all advertising in order to build high local awareness ahead of the open date. Pure Gym’s local, regional and national campaigns primarily consist of online marketing, hand to hand marketing through leaflets, out-of-home advertisements and TV advertisements. Pure Gym believes that as the largest UK gym operator, it has substantial marketing advantages as compared to other operators, particularly with regards to its ability to cost effectively pursue national brand building campaigns. Pure Gym has also made effective use of sporting celebrities to differentiate the brand, increase recall and build credibility. Sir Chris Hoy, an eleven-time world champion and six-time Olympic champion track cyclist, joined Pure Gym as a brand ambassador in June 2015 for an initial period of five years. He has since agreed to extend his association with Pure Gym for a further three years. Dina Asher-Smith joined as a brand ambassador in April 2019 on an initial three-year contract. Dina is a sprinter and the UK’s fastest ever woman, currently holding World Championship Gold and Silver medals. She is one of the UK’s leading sports celebrities with a strong reputation and a growing national presence in media, which will further increase her exposure and may support Pure Gym’s brand presence by association. Sir Chris Hoy will also play an active part in the Olympics, further increasing his exposure. Pure Gym monitors the visibility and preference of its brand on a quarterly basis. In November 2019, national brand awareness stood at 44%, over twice the level of the closest value-gym competitor and second in the whole of the gym sector. Within the important 18-34 old audience, Pure Gym leads the market with brand awareness at 58%. In recent years, Pure Gym has developed a strong product capability, developing and promoting new membership types and bolt-ons including premium membership options and other bolt-ons such as Yanga Sports Water and Bodytracker. With a strong sales and promotional capability, Pure Gym is well-positioned to continue to yield additional revenue from premium-priced member volume. _Fitness World_ Fitness World’s “create healthy habits” philosophy and marketing message positions it as an affordable provider of high-quality health and fitness facilities that welcomes all people regardless of their current levels of fitness or training goals. 168 ----- Fitness World places emphasis on local advertising campaigns for gyms that are in the pre-opening phase or have recently opened. Campaigns and advertising material are produced to be operative across markets in order to create effective intake of new members and secure a strong brand position locally, regionally, and nationally. Fitness World’s national, regional and local campaigns primarily consist of online marketing, out-of-home advertisements, TV advertisements, and through paid-search platforms such as Google. Fitness World believes that as the largest gym operator in Denmark, it has substantial marketing advantages as compared to other operators, particularly with regards to its ability to cost-effectively leverage media buying, engage new members and pursue national brand-building campaigns. Total media spend for the year ended December 31, 2019 was DKK 66.7 million (£7.6 million, as converted to pounds sterling using the year end specific rate of DKK 8.74687 to £1.00000 as at December 31, 2019) and both the efficiency and effectiveness of the total marketing expenditure is an important focus area for senior management. Marketing spend by channel is actively managed to drive results and minimize customer acquisition costs and is generally focused around key joining periods to maximize customer acquisition. Google analytics premium, channel attribution modelling, sales modelling and other techniques are used to ensure that Fitness World can track and measure CPA and marketing return on investment as accurately as possible. Based on Google analytics and search engine optimization reports, approximately 50% of customer acquisitions were online and 50% in club conversion. Fitness World has developed a mobile app as a platform for all members, which offers free training programs, an option to follow member training from any location in or outside of the fitness club with “healthkit” integration, free Bodytracker to track fitness metrics with data through a personal app and monthly challenges. The mobile app usage is an effective marketing tool and has resulted in increased retention of existing members. As of December 31, 2019, the app has more than one million unique downloads in Denmark and over 250,000 active monthly users. In 2019, Fitness World’s app was awarded best customer experience. Fitness World has established strong partnerships with Team Denmark, the organization that sponsors Denmark’s world-class athletes. As the official training partner for Team Denmark, Fitness World leverages the top Danish athletes as ambassadors for its facilities while supporting the athletes with their fitness goals and the Olympics. The Fitness World and Team Denmark partnership has yielded significant marketing benefits that gives Fitness World exposure on a national and international stage. Fitness World has also partnered with Nordic Race (the organizer of the largest obstacle course race in Denmark), Aarhus Motion (which has over 20 running events with more than 200,000 participants) and Sparta Copenhagen (Denmark’s largest mass-running event with over 200,000 participants). Fitness World leverages the partnerships with these organizations for brand exposure via social media and special benefits and discounts offered to competitors if they become Fitness World members. Fitness World is a household name in Denmark and its brand awareness is very strong with aided awareness in Denmark above 80%. Brand- tracking survey shows strong brand position and highest consideration of all operators in the market.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: _Pure Gym_ Technology is a critical component of Pure Gym’s business model. Pure Gym uses technology to enhance its customer value proposition and augment the membership experience, while simultaneously using it to drive operating and capital cost efficiencies and enable the senior management team to better manage the business. For members, technology enables convenient and easy online joining and membership management as well as 24 hours a day, seven days a week, 365 days a year access to the majority of Pure Gyms. Customers can sign up for memberships via the Pure Gym website, which can be accessed using the kiosks at Pure Gyms or anywhere else with internet access. Members can also use the Pure Gym website and mobile app to book places in exercise classes and manage their membership status. In addition to enhancing the proposition, Pure Gym’s technology infrastructure enables it to lower operating costs and more efficiently run its business. For example, Pure Gym uses an online member management system provided and hosted by eXerp to process new memberships, update member information and store member data. The eXerp system interfaces with the Gantner gym access system, which controls gym access for members 169 ----- via PIN, RFID wristband and key fob. These systems allow Pure Gyms to operate without a staffed reception. Pure Gym’s online joining process also allows it to operate without an expensive in-gym sales force. Technology is also used to reduce fit out and maintenance costs. For example, equipment heat maps are developed in partnership with suppliers and used to configure newly opened gyms to reduce wear and tear on equipment and provide equipment utilization reports. Pure Gym has also developed and uses a proprietary capacity management tool, which allows it to track and monitor the capacity of gyms and identify bottlenecks at different stages of the member journey. Eliminating these bottlenecks allows gyms to support higher levels of membership. Pure Gym has invested substantially in its internal IT capabilities and has brought a number of core IT functions in-house. Pure Gym’s IT team is led by a chief technology officer with over 20 years’ experience in the information technology industry and is supported by the principal architect, head of IT operations and head of IT delivery and 41 permanent and contract staff including software and quality assurance engineers. The role of the IT team is to oversee Pure Gym’s technology platform and work alongside the other business areas to explore new opportunities and support growth. Pure Gym believes that direct ownership of, and control over, its core technology interface with members and business partners is a source of competitive advantage for the company. In 2019, as part of the normal course of business, Pure Gym commissioned detailed and comprehensive cybersecurity reviews of its APIs, mobile app and new payment gateway and carried out a phishing simulation on all staff. Upon completion of the review, Pure Gym has a low cyber security risk profile. Individual gyms have IT infrastructures to provide local access network service, provide free Wi-Fi to members, ensure back-up PIN data for site access and enable in-gym TVs to display advertisement feeds. Each gym is equipped with continuously recording closed-circuit television security cameras. These are proactively monitored outside of normal staffing hours by an in-house team and video is recorded at each access control point for fraud detection and prevention. Pure Gym’s back office computer systems are comprised of a variety of technologies designed to assist in the management and analysis of its revenue, costs and key operational metrics as well as support the daily operations of Pure Gym’s office-based and remotely located staff. These include a third-party hosted financial system, a third-party hosted business intelligence system and third-party hosted call centre software to manage and track member-related requests. Our information technology strategy is aligned to support our business strategy and operating plans. Pure Gym maintains an ongoing comprehensive program to replace or upgrade key systems, enhance security and optimize performance. Pure Gym believes that its IT systems are scalable and can support its growth plans. _Fitness World_ Fitness World consistently tracks technological trends and customizes them based on consumer dynamics. Fitness World has invested heavily in digital platforms that allow consumers to complete fitness challenges, book training programs and group fitness classes and track progress through specific measurements. Fitness World has invested substantially in its internal IT capabilities and has brought a number of core IT functions in-house. Fitness World’s IT team is led by a chief information officer with over 20 years’ experience in the information technology industry who is supported by a team consisting of in-house developers. Fitness World uses external consultants for larger development projects. Fitness World believes that direct ownership of, and control over, its core technology interface with members and business partners is a source of competitive advantage for the company. Fitness World uses a centralized IT set-up in Denmark and is supported by local on-site teams in Switzerland. The IT department consists of 11 members and is newly established as a consequence of steady company growth. The IT department is comprised of both external and internal employees, which required internal insourcing within Fitness World to move employees from other departments in the organization to the IT team. The IT department is responsible for supporting clubs with other non-IT technical services such as: “Intelligent Cycling”, audio and TV. The IT department is also responsible for acquiring new software for the whole organization. Historically, each business unit or department acquired software individually. Fitness World continues to review its technological offerings in order to streamline its digital services and provide an enhanced member experience in line with its business strategy. 170 -----

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Pure Gym and Fitness World fully back up all of their membership and business information using thirdparty data locations and have a full business continuity plan in place. Pure Gym’s third-party technology systems are backed up regularly, with frequency varying depending on the third-party supplier. For example, eXerp provides daily back-up of Pure Gym’s operative systems, all client data are stored in Oracle with a daily incremental backup and a full backup twice per week. Nomical, the supplier for Pure Gym’s head office IT infrastructure, provides daily incremental backups and bimonthly full backups. All database backups for the content management system and assets such as images are stored in Azure geo-redundant storage and these are replicated across the datacentre and across the globe totalling six copies of the data. Fitness World’s third-party technology systems are backed up daily, with frequency varying depending on the third-party supplier. Client data are stored in Fitness World’s Microsoft BI-System with incremental backup and eXerp provides daily back-up of Fitness World’s operative systems. Fitness World’s supplier of IT infrastructure, Unit IT, provides daily incremental backups and monthly full backups. Fitness World uses Keepit to back up data in office 365 (such as mail and OneDrive) and data is stored for one year with two incremental backups per day.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: _Pure Gym_ Pure Gym outsources numerous functions of its business to third parties, which allows it to minimize fixed costs, maintain lean staff levels and scale rapidly. Services outsourced include maintenance and repair of fitness equipment, construction of new gyms, maintenance and repair of fixtures and fittings, cleaning, human resources support and various other professional services. Due to its leading position in the UK health and fitness market, Pure Gym is able to purchase equipment, supplies and services on a larger scale than most of its competitors, which Pure Gym believes allows it to purchase at lower prices. Pure Gym’s procurement is centrally managed by the Procurement Director. Pure Gym has good relationships with its suppliers and service providers, including its suppliers of fitness equipment, Matrix and Precor, and proactively use key performance indicators and a partnership approach to ensure consistent and improving levels of quality and service. See “Business—Suppliers—Pure Gym”. _Fitness World_ Fitness World outsources numerous functions of its business to third parties, which allows it to produce and distribute its nutritional product line, maintain and enhance its digital platforms, minimize fixed costs, maintain lean staff levels and scale rapidly. Services outsourced include production and distribution of the Functional Nutrition line, maintenance and repair of fitness equipment, construction of new gyms, maintenance and repair of fixtures and fittings, consultancy and advisory services, leasing services, electricity supply and various other professional services. Fitness World has good relationships with its suppliers and service providers, including its supplier of fitness equipment, Technogym, and proactively use key performance indicators and a partnership approach to ensure consistent and improving levels of quality and service. See “Business—Suppliers—Fitness World”.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Pure Gym owns registered trademarks in the UK, Ireland and Europe in respect of the PURE GYM name and logo in various classes of goods and services including fitness-related categories. Pure Gym also owns a registered trademark in the UK for a logo embodying our tagline “everybody welcome” in several classes of services. Additionally, Pure Gym has a registered “Purefitness” trademark in the U.S. Fitness World owns registered trademarks in Europe in respect of the “Fitness World” name and logo in various classes of goods and services including fitness-related categories. Basefit owns registered trademarks in Europe in respect of the “Basefit” name and logo in various classes of goods and services including fitness-related categories. Functional Nutrition owns registered trademarks in Europe in respect of the “Functional” name and logo in various classes of goods and services including fitness-related categories. These trademarks are registered in the relevant classes covering sports products and dietary supplements. Multiple trademarks are still pending with respect to the Functional Nutrition line. 171 ----- Pure Gym and Fitness World pursue registration of their trademarks in select international jurisdictions where they use or are intending to use the marks, and seek to proactively oppose and take prompt action with respect to any unauthorized use of their marks of which they become aware.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Pure Gym and Fitness World maintain insurance policies customary in its industry to cover certain risks. The principal risks covered by its insurance policies are public and employer liability, asset risks and business interruption resulting from riot and commercial crime and force majeure events. Pure Gym also has a cyberinsurance policy in place as of February 2020.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Pure Gym and Fitness World are deeply rooted in their values to provide a meaningful and valued service to society and to help people make a positive difference to their lives through being more physically active. By virtue of their low cost, no contract and flexible model, Pure Gym and Fitness World believe that they have opened up the opportunity for physical activity to many hundreds of thousands of people who would otherwise have been excluded from such activity. The Combined Group has encouraged widespread localized activities by its individual gyms and regions as well as empowering management teams in gyms to do what they feel makes a difference in their local communities. For example, over the last year, Pure Gym has supported local charity runs in Scotland, helped hospitals in Manchester, and supported collections for homeless people in the West Midlands while also working with charitable and other organizations such as the Macmillan Cancer Relief and Action Medical Research. More recently, Pure Gym raised over £350,000 for Mental Health UK by completing a seven day relay linking all Pure Gyms across the country. Fitness World also runs charity events throughout the year. The most notable of these events is the Team Rynkeby “Bike for the kids” initiative in which 70 Fitness World clubs coordinate nationwide cycling events. The proceeds from tickets to the cycling events are then donated to Child Cancer Foundation Denmark. Fitness World most recently donated DKK 0.6 million in 2019. In terms of governance and participation in the business, the Combined Group works to high standards. The management board of Pure Gym in the UK is chaired by the Chief Executive and three out of seven members including the MD of the UK business are women, which management believes is appropriate given that over 40% of Pure Gym’s members are women. An open and constructive culture is nurtured carefully and there are multiple routes for staff across the whole business to communicate and raise issues with members of the senior management team. There is a whistle-blowing policy in place in addition to a fully-equipped HR team that actively ensures there are alternative routes beyond line management through which staff can raise concerns. The Combined Group is focused on ways to reduce energy consumption in its gyms and has placed emphasis on designing its gyms with a number of energy saving and “green” features. The following is a selection of features that have been incorporated throughout the estate, where practically possible: - mechanical and electrical systems that comply with government energy-saving schemes, including HMRC’s Enhanced Capital Allowance scheme for energy-saving technologies; - LED energy-saving lighting and water-saving bathroom and shower facilities; - energy-efficient fitness equipment, including treadmills, exercise bikes and other self-powered cardio equipment that have display screens powered by batteries and user-generated electricity; and - recycling the building materials from the fit out of its gyms. Over the last 12 months, the Combined Group has commenced a more structured program to systematically analyse all areas of energy usage and environmental impact and to develop strategies to reduce these significantly over the coming years. This process is currently ongoing as of the date of this Offering Memorandum.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Pure Gym and Fitness World recognize that the health and safety of their employees, members, associates and business partners is of paramount importance and accordingly have adopted health and safety policies that 172 ----- comply with applicable health and safety legislation. Pure Gym and Fitness World believe that this ensures consistent application of their health and safety policies across their estate. Pure gyms incorporate a number of features to ensure the health and safety of its members, staff, associates and business partners. For example, Pure Gyms always have a Pure Gym employee, personal trainer or employee of a supplier or contractor present on site at peak times and all such staff are trained in first aid. In addition, each of the Pure Gyms have continuously recording closed-circuit television security cameras, which are proactively monitored during non-peak hours, for the monitoring and reporting of accidents and other emergencies. Furthermore, Pure Gyms have help points where members can speak live to the individuals who are monitoring the CCTV feeds and automated defibrillators are installed in all gyms. Pure Gym employees undergo a continuous and extensive training program in health and safety policies, which is conducted through e-learning modules. In the year ended December 31, 2019, of the approximately 70 million visits to a Pure Gym, only 0.01% resulted in health and safety incidents. Fitness World carries health insurance for the majority of its staff through an external pension fund, which enables employees to receive medical attention for psychological, psychiatric, dietary, and chiropractic needs without any fees. Fitness World also reviews and improves its monitoring and check-in procedures at the gates and entrances to its clubs to avoid intruders while ensuring that fire exits more easily accessible. Fitness World consistently monitors its health and safety policies and implements changes as needed on an ongoing basis.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: _Pure Gym_ As of December 31, 2019, Pure Gym employed 1,441 people, including 414 people in management and administrative roles and 1,027 in gym operational roles, and as of September 2020, this included 70 “core” inhouse engineers and analysts, 36 contracted workers, 12 workers in roles covering data science and business intelligence and five in business roles involving strong tech, content and data management. The business’ organizational and technology structures are specifically designed to minimize the number of employed staff at each Pure Gym location. A large number of gym functions, including maintenance and cleaning are outsourced to third parties. See “Business—Suppliers—Pure Gym”. 173 ----- The below table shows the breakdown of the number of Pure Gym employees as of December 31, 2019.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsection Title: As of December 31, Management and Admin:** **2019

Section Title: BUSINESS
BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2019, the majority of Pure Gym’s employees are employed on a full-time and salaried basis. Employee benefits currently include health and life insurance cover, 25 days of annual leave (plus bank holidays), contributory pension arrangements and a complimentary gym membership for each employee and an immediate family member. As of December 31, 2019, only 8 employees are parties to “zero hour contracts” and therefore few employees will be affected by any future regulation of such contracts. Pure Gym believes that attracting, motivating and retaining high calibre employees with the desire, ability and passion to operate within Pure Gym’s values and culture is key to our continued success. Pure Gym places importance on professional development and training and runs several programs aimed at improving employees’ management abilities, performance levels and retention rates. Pure Gym has a culture that promotes excellence irrespective of age, gender or seniority. Pure Gym believes that it has a good relationship with its employees. None of its gyms has suffered a material work stoppage or strike and Pure Gym is recognized as an employer of choice within the UK as evidenced by the fact that Pure Gym was placed in the Sunday Times 100 Best Companies To Work For in 2018. 174 ----- _Fitness World_ As of December 31, 2019, Fitness World employed 5,422 people, including 211 people in management and administrative roles and 5,211 in gym operational roles. The below table shows the breakdown of the number of Fitness World employees as of December 31, 2019.

Section Title: BUSINESS
BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: In August 2020, Fitness World reduced its staffing by approximately 400 employees in order to reduce operating costs. Fitness World Group A/S is not automatically included in collective bargaining agreements entered into by the Danish Chamber of Commerce. Fitness World Group A/S has a full service membership and is only covered by the collective bargaining agreements that Fitness World Group A/S has directly acceded to. Fitness World is part way through implementing plans to optimize its profitability by closing six Urban Gym clubs and two low-profit Fitness World clubs as well as converting four Urban Gym clubs to Fitness World clubs. In addition, Fitness World has recently announced a new and more efficient operating structure. This has impacted 328 Fitness World employees, with 86 of them being full-time club managers and the rest being parttime employees. The changes to the Fitness World operating model are to adjust to the new reality of the members’ needs and expectations while still delivering on the authorities requirements. This is not to increase profitability but to improve our member experience through a more skilled and smaller group of managers and centralizing functions at the head offices.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Title: The GDPR, UK Data Protection Act and the Danish Data Protection Act
Subsubsection Text: The EU-wide GDPR came into force on May 25, 2018, and is supplemented under UK law by the Data Protection Act 2018 (“UKDPA”), which replaced the former UK Data Protection Act 1998, and under Danish law by the Danish Data Protection Act (“DDPA”), which replaced the former Danish Act on Processing of Personal Data. The GDPR, UKDPA and DDPA altogether set out more onerous and stringent requirements for controllers and processors’ processing of personal data, including expanded disclosure requirements. For example, when collecting personal data, certain information must be provided to the individual whose data is being collected. This information includes the identity of the data controller, the purpose for which the data is being collected and other relevant information relating to the processing. In some cases, the consent of those data subjects may also be required to protect the personal data for the purposes notified to them. Personal data may only be used for the purposes notified to individuals. Additionally, regulators now have the ability to impose larger fines of up to the greater of £17 million (€20 million) or up to 4% of the total worldwide annual turnover of the preceding financial year. In addition to fines, regulators also have the ability to impose other sanctions such as injunctions and other prohibitive orders. 175 ----- Pure Gym has adopted policies and procedures designed to ensure compliance with the GDPR and the UKDPA. Pure Gym is registered as a data controller with the Information Commissioner’s Office, an independent governmental authority responsible for maintaining, upholding and promoting the best business practices and legislative requirements for processing personal data and safeguarding the information rights of individuals and their rights to access their personal data. Pure Gym regularly takes legal advice on GDPR and UKDPA-related matters and, where appropriate, involves its Board of Directors in GDPR and UKDPA-related queries. In addition, Pure Gym ensures that its staff and suppliers are aware of the GDPR and UK DPA’s requirements. Pure Gym’s policies and procedures are designed to restrict employee access to personal data (unless required in that employee’s role), ensure that secure methods are used in the collection and transmission of personal data and ensure that Pure Gym only enters into appropriate data sharing agreements with its suppliers. Fitness World is also a data controller and based on a full-scale GDPR-compliance project, Fitness World has adopted policies and procedures designed to ensure compliance with the GDPR and the DDPA, including ensuring that personal data on employees and members are handled and processed in accordance with applicable legislation and Fitness World’s own policies and procedures.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Title: Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard
Subsubsection Text: The UK PCI DSS is a proprietary information security standard for organizations that handle cardholder information for the major debit, credit, prepaid, e-purse, ATM, and point-of-sale cards. The PCI DSS helps to reduce the risk of theft of customers’ card data through controls concerning the storage, transmission and processing of cardholder data that businesses handle. It also includes standards that promote the detection of fraud and appropriate reactions to security incidents. All entities that store, process or transmit cardholder data must be PCI DSS compliant. It is not, however, mandatory for all entities to obtain formal validation of PCI DSS compliance. Formal validation requirements depend on the payment brand to which the merchant has subscribed or is in agreement. An organization’s compliance with the PCI DSS is validated annually, either by an external Qualified Security Assessor who creates a Report on Compliance for organizations that handle a large volume of transactions, or by a Self-Assessment Questionnaire for companies that handle a smaller volume of transactions. Pure Gym makes use of a third-party payment services provider and does not store cardholder information on its own systems; therefore, Pure Gym completes the self-assessment questionnaire (SAQ A) on an annual basis. Fitness World also makes use of a third-party payment services provider and does not store cardholder information on its own systems; therefore, Fitness World is not required to be PCI DSS compliant.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: _Pure Gym_ Pure Gym has been, and may from time to time be, party to various claims and legal proceedings arising in the ordinary course of its business, such as contract claims, employee claims and intellectual property disputes, among others. Pure Gym has not been within the last 12 months, and is not currently a party to any governmental, legal, administrative, arbitration or dispute proceedings, either individually or in the aggregate, that has had, or is expected to have, a material adverse effect on its financial position and results of operations. As a result of COVID-19, Pure Gym may be subject to increased risk of litigation following the end of the rent moratorium in the UK. For additional detail, see “Risk Factors—Risks relating to our business—We may face increased risk of _litigation following the period in which the UK rent moratorium is lifted”. Fitness World_ Fitness World has been, and may from time to time be, party to various claims and legal proceedings arising in the ordinary course of its business, such as contract claims, employee claims and intellectual property disputes, among others. Fitness World recently resolved a breach of contract claim relating to providers of construction services suppliers of equipment in the aggregate maximum amount of DKK 30 million (approximately £3.5 million). Fitness World included a provision in its 2019 financial statements for funds required to litigate or settle the pending claims. See Note 17 “Provisions” to the 2019 Fitness World Financial Statements. On August 5, 2020, the District Court in Frederiksberg ruled in favour of the claimant and, 176 ----- consequently, Fitness World A/S paid DKK 15.5 million (approximately £1.9 million), which includes the judgement award, litigation costs and interest, to the claimant. 177 -----

Mr. Cobbold was previously CEO of Wiggle Ltd, an online retailer of cycling and triathlon related products, during which time he launched the international business across Europe, Japan, Australia, the USA and China. He is a former Chairman of Fish4, a British classified advertising website, as well as the Director of Strategic Development and an Executive Committee member of Trinity Mirror, the newspaper publisher. Prior to joining Trinity Mirror, he was a partner and the co-head of the UK media and corporate finance practices for the global management consulting firm McKinsey & Company. He graduated in Natural Sciences from the University of Cambridge and holds an M.B.A. with Distinction from INSEAD. _Alex Wood, Group Chief Financial Officer_ Alex Wood joined Pure Gym in 2018 as Chief Financial Officer and currently serves as the Group’s Chief Financial Officer. His responsibilities include leadership of the finance, property acquisition and development activities of the business. Mr. Wood was previously CFO and Acting CEO of Gala Bingo, and coled a management buy-out of the business from Gala Coral Group in December 2015. Prior to this, Mr. Wood was M&A Director at Gala Coral Group and worked for over 12 years at KPMG where he led their East Midlands and Gaming Sector Corporate Finance businesses. Mr. Wood qualified as a Chartered Accountant during his time at KPMG and holds a 1st class master’s degree in Chemistry from the University of Nottingham. Rebecca Passmore ................................................. 38 UK Managing Director Fraser Inglis ........................................................... 46 UK Finance Director The business address of each of the senior managers listed above is Pure Gym Head Office, Town Centre House, Merrion Centre, Leeds, LS2 8LY. The management expertise and experience of each of the managers is set out below: _Rebecca Passmore, UK Managing Director_ Rebecca Passmore joined Pure Gym in October 2017. Ms. Passmore is an experienced Operations Director with over 15 years in the retail sector across food, general merchandise and DIY. She joined Pure Gym directly from Wickes where she held the role of Store Operations Director, leading the retail team through Wickes’ transformation program. Prior to Wickes, Ms. Passmore held various senior roles in Asda, TKMaxx and Aldi. She holds a BA Honours Degree in Business Management from the University of Nottingham and most recently attended the Program for Leadership Development at Harvard Business School. _Fraser Inglis, UK Finance Director_ Fraser Inglis joined Pure Gym in June 2015. Mr. Inglis has over 20 years’ experience in finance roles within consumer businesses; primarily rapidly growing multi-site leisure operations. Following 6 years at Costa Coffee (Whitbread PLC), he spent 9 years at Virgin Active in both UK and Group senior positions before joining Pure Gym to initially lead the integration of LA Fitness into Pure Gym following the 2015 acquisition. Mr. Inglis is a CIMA qualified finance director and holds a BA Honours degree in Business Studies from University of Plymouth.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Leonard Green & Partners, L.P. is a leading private equity firm, which since its inception has invested in over 90 companies with an aggregate value of over $165 billion. Founded in 1989 and based in Los Angeles, U.S.A., Leonard Green & Partners, L.P. invests in market leading companies across a range of industries. Leonard Green & Partners, L.P. seeks to back companies that are leaders in their respective industries, have robust growth potential and are led by exceptional management teams. Since its inception, Leonard Green & Partners, L.P. has raised more than $40 billion of committed capital across its eight funds, with consistently strong returns over its 30-year history. Other current and prior Leonard Green & Partners, L.P. investments include Equinox, SoulCycle, Life Time Fitness, Shake Shack, Whole Foods, BJ’s Wholesale Club, Troon Golf, Mister Car Wash and Activision Blizzard. 180 -----

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer is a public limited company incorporated under the laws of England and Wales. The Issuer was incorporated on October 30, 2017 and its registered office is at C/O Pure Gym Limited Town Centre House, Merrion Centre, Leeds, LS2 8LY, United Kingdom. The Issuer is registered with the Registrar of Companies for England and Wales under company number 11038859. The Issuer is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Pinnacle Midco 2 Limited, which in turn is an indirect wholly-owned subsidiary of Pinnacle Topco Limited, our ultimate parent. As of the Issue Date, our principal shareholder, LGP (together with minority co-investors), holds approximately 79% of the issued ordinary shares of Pinnacle Topco Limited, our ultimate parent. In connection with the Transactions, several current members of management of Pure Gym rolled their previous shareholdings in Topco into shares in Pinnacle Topco Limited. Management holds approximately 21% of the ordinary issued shares of Pinnacle Topco Limited, with certain of such management shareholders able to vote up to 20% of the ordinary shares. The Equity Injection brings LGP's total cash equity investment in our business to £381 million.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS Intercreditor Agreement
Subsubsection Text: On November 28, 2017, the Issuer, Pinnacle Midco 2 Limited (“Holdco”), the agent for the finance parties under the Original Revolving Credit Facility Agreement (the “RCF Facility Agent”), the lenders (the “RCF Lenders”) and arrangers (the “RCF Arrangers”) under the Original Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, and the Security Agent, among others, entered into an intercreditor agreement (the “Intercreditor Agreement”). The Trustee acceded to the Intercreditor Agreement in relation to the Existing Notes on January 24, 2018. The Fitness World Guarantors, collectively with the Issuer and the existing subsidiaries that are already party to the Intercreditor Agreement, the “Debtors”) are expected to accede to the Intercreditor Agreement on or about the Issue Date. The Trustee shall accede to the Intercreditor Agreement in relation to the Notes on or about the Issue Date. Certain hedging providers may accede to the Intercreditor Agreement in the future. By accepting a Note, the relevant holder thereof shall be deemed to have agreed to, and accepted the terms and conditions of, the Intercreditor Agreement and shall be deemed to have authorized the Trustee to accede to the Intercreditor Agreement on its behalf. The following description is a summary of certain provisions, among others, contained in the Intercreditor Agreement and which relate to the rights and obligations of the holders of the Notes following the Trustee’s accession to the Intercreditor Agreement on or about the Issue Date. It does not restate the Intercreditor Agreement in its entirety. As such, you are urged to read the Intercreditor Agreement because it, and not the description that follows, defines certain rights of the holders of the Notes. The Intercreditor Agreement sets out, among other things, the relative ranking of certain indebtedness of the Debtors, the relative ranking of certain security granted by the Debtors, when payments can be made in respect of debt of the Debtors, when enforcement action can be taken in respect of that indebtedness, the terms pursuant to which certain of that indebtedness will be subordinated upon the occurrence of certain insolvency events and turnover provisions. Unless otherwise defined in this section or elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum to the extent not defined in the Intercreditor Agreement, capitalized terms set forth and used in this section have the same meanings as set forth in the Intercreditor Agreement, which may have different meanings from the meanings given to such terms and used elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

Subsubsection Text: being the “RCF Lenders Discharge Date”), no member of the Group may make payments in respect of the Senior Liabilities without the Required Senior Consent (as that term is defined in the Intercreditor Agreement) except, and in addition to the paragraph above, as permitted by the Intercreditor Agreement including the following: (1) if: (a) the payment is of: (i) any of the principal amount of or capitalized interest on the Senior Liabilities which is either (1) not prohibited from being paid by the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, the Bridge Facility and/or Indenture or any Permitted Senior Secured Financing Debt finance document or (2) paid on or after the final maturity date of the relevant Senior Liabilities or, in each case, a corresponding amount of Holdco Liabilities; or (ii) any other amount which is not an amount of principal or previously capitalized interest (including any scheduled interest (whether cash pay or payment-in-kind) and default interest) or a corresponding amount of Holdco Liabilities; (b) no notice delivered pursuant to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement blocking payments in respect of the Senior Liabilities (a “Senior Payment Stop Notice”) is outstanding; and (c) no event of default under the finance documents in respect of the Senior Secured Debt Liabilities arising by reason of non-payment of any amounts due in connection therewith (a “Senior Secured Payment Default”) has occurred and is continuing; or (2) certain amounts due to any Senior Notes Trustee (as defined in the Intercreditor Agreement) for its own account; (3) costs and expenses of any holder of a mortgage, charge, pledge, lien or other security interest having a similar effect (“Security”) in relation to the protection, preservation or enforcement of such Security; (4) administrative and maintenance costs, taxes, fees and expenses of any Senior Debt Issuer (in its capacity as a borrower or issuer) incurred in respect of or in relation to (or reasonably incidental to) any Permitted Senior Debt Documents (including in relation to any reporting or listing requirements), provided that such costs and expenses are not incurred in respect of current, 185 ----- threatened or pending litigation against the Secured Parties (as such term is defined in the Intercreditor Agreement) (other than any Permitted Senior Financing Creditor); or (5) costs, commissions, taxes, fees, premiums and expenses incurred in respect of or in relation to (or reasonably incidental to) any refinancing of the Permitted Senior Financing Liabilities not prohibited by the Intercreditor Agreement, the Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, the Bridge Facility / Indenture and any Permitted Senior Secured Financing Document. Prior to the Senior Secured Debt Discharge Date, if a Senior Secured Payment Default is continuing all payments in respect of the Senior Liabilities (other than those for which Required Senior Consent has been obtained) will be suspended. 2) In addition, if an event of default (other than a Senior Secured Payment Default) under the finance documents in respect of the Senior Secured Debt Liabilities (each “Senior Secured Event of Default”) is continuing and any relevant Permitted Senior Financing Representative has received a Senior Payment Stop Notice from either the RCF Facility Agent or the Trustee or the Bridge Facility Agent or other relevant representative of the Permitted Senior Secured Financing Debt (each, a “Senior Secured Agent”), from the date the relevant Permitted Senior Financing Representative, the Security Agent and Holdco receive the Senior Payment Stop Notice, all payments in respect of Senior Liabilities (other than those for which Required Senior Consent has been obtained) are suspended until the earliest of: a) 179 days after the receipt by the relevant Permitted Senior Financing Representative of the Senior Payment Stop Notice; b) if a Senior Standstill Period (as defined below) is in effect at any time after delivery of that Senior Payment Stop Notice, the date on which that Senior Standstill Period expires; c) the date on which there is a waiver or remedy of the relevant Senior Secured Event of Default; d) the date on which the Senior Secured Agent which delivered the Senior Payment Stop Notice notifies (among others) the relevant Permitted Senior Financing Representative, the Security Agent and Holdco that the Senior Payment Stop Notice is cancelled;
